CHAPTER 701
General Provisions; Penalty
701.99   Penalty.
   701.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Business Regulation Code where
another penalty is not otherwise provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and
shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any such violation
shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued.
CHAPTER 705
Billiard Rooms, Poolrooms and Bowling Alleys
705.01   License required.
705.02   Fees; citizenship required.
705.03   License revocation.
705.04   Minors in bowling alleys.
705.05   Hours of operation.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51, 715.61
      Amusement centers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
707
   705.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall own or keep a public billiard room, billiard table,
poolroom, pool table or bowling alley within the Municipality without first
having obtained from the Safety-Service Director a license to do so. (Ord. 69-
53. Passed 12-9-69.)
   705.02  FEES; CITIZENSHIP REQUIRED.
   The Safety-Service Director may grant a license to any person of good moral
character who may apply therefore, to own or operate a public billiard room,
billiard table, poolroom or pool table, upon such person first paying the
Municipality an annual license fee as follows:
   (a)    For each person operating not less than one or more than five
billiard tables or pool tables for public use, whether coin operated or not, an
amount of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) shall be paid, and five
dollars ($5.00) for each additional table therein over five.
    (b)    Ten dollars ($10.00) for the first bowling alley and five dollars
($5.00) for each additional bowling alley placed in the place of business shall
be paid.
   However, no license shall be granted to any person who has been convicted of
any crime under the laws of the United States or of any state therein. No
license shall be granted to any person who is not an American citizen. A report
of investigation by the Chief of Police shall be filed with the license
application.
   "Person" for the purpose of this chapter, includes person, corporation,
officer, partnership and association. (Ord. 69-53. Passed 12-9-69.)
   705.03  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The Safety-Service Director shall have full power and authority to revoke
the license of any person who is convicted of a violation of any criminal law
of the United States or any state therein. (Ord. 65-18. Passed 3-9-65.)
   705.04  MINORS IN BOWLING ALLEYS.
   No person who has not attained the age of fourteen years shall bowl or be
permitted to remain in a bowling alley after 6:00 p.m., unless accompanied by
his parent or guardian.
(Ord. 65-18. Passed 3-9-65.)
   705.05  HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)    No bowling alley operating under a license issued under this section
shall be open or be permitted to operate except during the following hours:
      (1)    Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 a.m. the next day;
      (2)    Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 2:30 a.m. the next day. No bowling alley
shall be  open or be permitted to operate on Sunday except as a continuation
of  Saturday hours as provided in subparagraph (2) herein, and on Sunday 
between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 4:00 a.m. the next day.
   (b)    No billiard room operating under a license issued under this section,
or poolroom, shall be open, or be permitted to operate except during the
following hours:
      (1)    Monday through Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. the following day;
      (2)    Where a valid liquor license is in effect, the closing hours shall
be governed by such permit despite the provisions of subparagraph (1) herein.
(Ord. 65-18. Passed 3-9-65.)
CHAPTER 707
Amusement Centers
707.01   License required.
707.02   Definition.
707.03   Fees.
707.04   License revocation.
707.05   Hours of operations.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Billiard rooms, poolrooms and bowling alleys - see BUS. REG. Ch.
705
   707.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall own, operate or have an interest in an amusement center
within the Municipality without first obtaining from the Safety-Service
Director a license to do so.
(Ord. 65-17. Passed 3-9-65.)
   707.02  DEFINITION.
   "Amusement Center" means an area of not less than five acres, comprising
both indoor and outdoor amusement skills, providing thereon sufficient off-
street parking within such five acres for at least fifty cars.
   Such amusement centers shall consist of one indoor and one out-door activity
and shall comprise at least two of the following activities:
   (a)    Bowling alley.
   (b)    Miniature or putt-putt golf.
   (c)    Billiard or poolroom,
   (d)    Golf driving range.
   (e)    Trampoline devices.
   (f)    Kiddie land riding or amusement devices.
   (g)    Golf course.
(Ord. 65-17. Passed 3-9-65.)
   707.03  FEES
   The Safety-Service Director may grant a license to any person of good moral
character who may apply therefore to own or operate an amusement center, upon
such person first paying the Municipality an annual license fee as set in
accordance with the fees and schedules for each activity as set forth in Part
Seven of the Codified Ordinances of Sharonville.
   No license shall be granted to any person who has been convicted of any
crime under the laws of the United States or of any state therein, and no
license shall be granted to any person who is not an American citizen.
(Ord. 65-17. Passed 3-9-65.)
   707.04  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The Safety-Service Director shall have full power and authority to revoke
the license of any person who is convicted of a violation of any criminal law
of the United States or any state therein. (Ord. 65-17. Passed 3-9-65.)
   707.05  HOURS OF OPERATION.
   Amusement centers shall be open or be permitted to remain open except during
the following hours: Sunday through Saturday, 4:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 65-17. Passed 3-9-65.)
CHAPTER 709
Frozen Desserts
709.01   License required.
709.02   Application; investigation.
709.03   Photograph for license.
709.04   License transfer; fee.
709.05   Exceptions.
709.06   Hours regulated.
709.07   Selling unfit food products.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
725
   709.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   A special peddler's license shall be required of all persons who wish to
engage in the sale of various ice creams, custards, frozen sherbets or other
frozen desserts during the summer months from pushcarts, wagons or other
vehicles.
   Such license shall be issued to no person under the age of eighteen years. A
condition precedent to the issuance of a license shall be a duly authenticated
birth certificate, and the applicant shall also obtain, at his own expense, a
certificate of health from the Sharonville Board of Health. (Ord. 61-20. Passed
5-16-61.)
   709.02  APPLICATION; INVESTIGATION.
   An application shall be secured from the Safety-Service Director and after
the requirements of Section
709.01 have been complied with, the application shall be submitted to the
Police Department, who shall investigate and determine that the person has no
known police record, to the best of their knowledge. (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-
61.)
   709.03  PHOTOGRAPH FOR LICENSE.
   After certification by the Police Department, a photograph to be furnished
by the applicant, shall be affixed to the license.
   The license shall contain a description of the peddler, showing his height,
age, weight, color of eyes, color of hair and any other pertinent physical
aspects which the Police Department shall deem necessary.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   709.04  LICENSE TRANSFER; FEE.
   The license shall not be transferable to any other person. The Safety-
Service Director shall issue a license upon compliance with the provisions of
this chapter and the payment of a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per year. (Ord.
61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   709.05  EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not pertain to religious, fraternal or any other
nonprofit organization. (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   709.06  HOURS REGULATED.
   No person shall sell any of the products mentioned in Section
709.01, on any day, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. the next day.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   709.07  SELLING UNFIT FOOD PRODUCTS.
   No person operating under a license as required by Section
709.01 shall sell, offer or expose for sale, any food product which is unfit
for human consumption.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
CHAPTER 713
Hotels, Motels and Tourist Courts
713.01   Indecency prohibited.
713.02   Register of name, residence, arrival and departure of guests.
713.03   Registration by false name.
713.04   Assigning of rooms.  (Repealed)
713.05   Numbering of rooms.
713.06   Registration record.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Guests to register - see Ohio R.C. 3503.31
      Hotels - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3731
      False registration - see Ohio R.C. 3731.17

      Indecency and immorality - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
533
      Trailers and trailer parks - see BUS. REG. Ch.

   713.01  INDECENCY PROHIBITED.
   No person whether as an owner, proprietor, lessee or keeper shall permit a
lodging house, inn, motel or hotel to be used as a home of ill-fame, brothel,
bawdy house or disorderly house, for the purpose of prostitution, fornication
or lewdness, or allow any lascivious adultery. (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   713.02  REGISTER OF NAME, RESIDENCE, ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURE OF GUESTS.
   (a)   Every owner, proprietor, lessee or keeper of a lodging house, inn,
motel or hotel located within a registration precinct shall keep a register in
which shall be entered the name, residence, date of arrival and departure, and
room occupied by each of his guests. This register shall be so arranged that
there shall be a space on the same line which such guests shall sign his name.
(ORC 3503.31)
   (b)   A hotel or motel which utilizes an electronic registration card need
not obtain the signature of each guest who utilizes such a card.
(Ord. 2008-46.  Passed 9-9-08.)
   713.03  REGISTRATION BY FALSE NAME.
   No person shall register for accommodations at any lodging house, inn, motel
or hotel under a false, fictitious or assumed name without first making his
true name known to the person in charge thereof. (ORC 3731.17)
   713.04  ASSIGNING OF ROOMS.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
713.04 was deleted by Ordinance 2015-25.)
   713.05  NUMBERING OF ROOMS.
   Every owner, proprietor, lessee or keeper of a lodging house, inn, motel or
hotel shall cause each sleeping room and apartment therein to be numbered in a
plain and conspicuous manner, the number to be placed on the outside of the
door to such room, and no two doors shall bear the same number. (Ord. 61-20.
Passed 5-16-61.)
   713.06  REGISTRATION RECORD.
   Every owner, proprietor, lessee or keeper of a lodging house, inn, motel or
hotel shall maintain his or her register records for a period of at least four
years after entry of same on his or her records.  (Ord. 2015-25.  Passed 8-25-
15.)
CHAPTER 714
Short Term Residential Real Estate Rentals
714.01    Purpose.
714.02    Short term rentals prohibited.
714.03    Short term rentals defined.
714.99    Penalty.
   714.01  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety, welfare, and
quality of life within the City of Sharonville, because the City desires to
preserve existing single family residential neighborhoods and structures. 
Residents of the City of Sharonville should have reasonable expectations that
single family residential neighborhoods and structures within the City will be
characterized as quiet, clean, orderly, safe and stable and generally free of
private businesses such as Short Term Rentals except those provided under
current City of Sharonville ordinances.  (Ord. 2019-49.  Passed 7-16-19.)
   714.02  SHORT TERM RENTALS PROHIBITED.
   The short term rental of any single family residential structure or portion
thereof within the City of Sharonville is prohibited and shall constitute a
nuisance.
(Ord. 2019-49.  Passed 7-16-19.)
   714.03  SHORT TERM RENTALS DEFINED.
   (a)   If the owner or lessee of a single family residential structure or
part thereof leases or rents the residential structure or part thereof, located
in any Single Family Zoning District of the City of Sharonville, for any period
that is thirty or fewer calendar days in length, such lease or rent shall be
considered a “short term rental”.
   (b)   “Owner or lessee” shall be interpreted to include sub lessees,
assignees, operators, agents and any other person who rents or leases a
particular single family residential structure or part thereof.
   (c)   Leases and rentals shall be interpreted to include the sublease or
assignment of any single family residential structure or part thereof.
(Ord. 2019-49.  Passed 7-16-19.)
   714.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Persons who may be charged with a violation of this chapter include
owners, operators, rental agents, tenants, lessees, sub lessees, and any other
person using the single family residential structure or part thereof where the
violation has been committed.
   (b)   Whoever violates any provision of this Business Regulation Code where
another penalty is not otherwise provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and
shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).  Any such violation
shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued.
(Ord. 2019-49.  Passed 7-16-19.)
CHAPTER 717
Junk Dealers, Junk Yards, Motor Vehicle
Salvage Dealers, and Impound Lots
717.01   Definitions.
717.02   License required.
717.03   Bond.
717.04   Hours of business; purchase from minors.
717.05   Licensing of junk yards, motor vehicle salvage dealers, or impound
lots.
717.06   Fence required.
717.07   Storage outside fenced area prohibited.
717.08   Procedures for Architectural Review Board hearings.
717.99   Penalties.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61, 4737.07
      Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
      Motor vehicle salvage - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4738
      Dealing with minors prohibited; hours regulated - see Ohio R.C. 4737.03
      State licensing and required fencing - see Ohio R.C. 4737.05 et seq.
      Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
 545.18
      (Section of Zoning Ordinance concerning prohibition of junk yards)
      Outdoor storage - see Industrial Districts
1137.05
   PREAMBLE: The Municipality has enacted this chapter to efficiently and
adequately regulate the businesses contained herein in order to protect the
community's safety and aesthetic concerns. In addition to possible dangerous
and unsightly conditions these businesses may produce, such business operations
also provide opportunities for a harboring and exchanging of stolen goods, even
if such legal status is unknown to the operator of the business. It has been
determined by this Municipality that these provisions should fairly protect the
interest of the community and the businesses covered herein. In addition, this
chapter regulates uses not permitted under the Municipality's zoning code which
are tolerated only as legal non-conforming uses. Such businesses often involve
outdoor storage of materials which may present health, safety and aesthetic
problems and are illegal under the zoning code.
   717.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Impound Lot" means a facility, business or property which stores,
parks, or retains operable or inoperable motor vehicles, which possession of
such vehicles was not voluntarily given to the facility or business by the
owner, for an indefinite amount of time, and returns such vehicles to their
rightful owners in consideration of a fee payable to such owner of the facility
or property. An impound lot does not include a facility, business or property
which temporarily holds motor vehicles, for a period of 60 days or not longer
than customarily and reasonably necessary, for purposes of repair or sale or
resale without alteration, such as a new or used automobile dealership or
mechanical repair business.
   (b)    "Junk " means old or scrap iron, metals, brass, steel, canvas, rope,
branded bottles, junk or lead pipe, rubber, plastic, glass, paper, rags, trash,
waste, appliances, furniture and other household items, damaged or unused water
craft, yard maintenance equipment, farm equipment; salvage motor vehicles which
are wrecked, dismantled, or unfit for operation as a motor vehicle, and any
motor vehicle parts; and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous materials
which are not held for smelting purposes by an establishment having facilities
for
processing such materials.
   (c)    "Junk Dealer" means any person who purchases, sells, exchanges,
stores, or temporarily holds secondhand, used or old articles of any kind that
can be defined as junk or who owns or operates a junk yard.
   (d)    "Junk Yard" means an establishment or place of business that is
maintained or operated for the purpose of storing, keeping, buying or selling
junk; or a salvage motor vehicle graveyard or storage lot, or motor vehicle
impound lot. A junk yard does not include a lot or property which temporarily
holds motor vehicles, for a period of 60 days or not longer than customarily
and reasonably necessary, for purposes of repair or sale or resale without
alteration, such as a new or used automobile dealership or mechanical repair
business.
   (e)    “Person" means any individual, corporation, limited liability
company, partnership, trust, or other legal entity.
   (f)    "Salvage Motor Vehicle" means any motor vehicle which is in a
wrecked, dismantled, or worn out condition, or unfit for operation as a motor
vehicle.
   (g)    "Salvage Motor Vehicle Dealer" means any person or entity who engages
in business primarily for the purpose of selling salvage motor vehicle parts
and secondarily for the purpose of selling at retail salvage motor vehicles or
manufacturing or selling a product of gradable scrap metal.  (Ord. 2002-71. 
Passed 12-10-02.)
   717.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No junk dealer, motor vehicle salvage dealer, or impound lot shall engage in
the businesses as set forth in this chapter, without first having obtained and
paid for a license as hereinafter provided.  Any individual or entity which
operates more than one such business shall obtain licenses for each business.
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   717.03  BOND.
   All license applications shall be accompanied by a bond to the Municipality
approved as to form by the Law Director in the penal sum of five hundred
dollars ($500.00), with a surety or collateral security approved by the Safety-
Service Director conditioned upon the due observance during the term of the
license of all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations which are now in force
or may hereafter be adopted by duly constituted authorities applicable to junk
dealing, motor vehicle salvage dealing, or impound lots.
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   
   717.04  HOURS OF BUSINESS; PURCHASE FROM MINORS.
   No business under this chapter shall purchase or receive by sale, barter,
exchange or otherwise, any article covered by this chapter. of a minor, knowing
or having reason to believe him to be such. A junk dealer and a motor vehicle
salvage dealer shall not conduct business with any person between the hours of
9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. There shall be no time restriction for an impound lot.
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   717.05  LICENSING OF JUNK YARDS, MOTOR VEHICLE SALVAGE DEALERS, OR IMPOUND
LOTS.
   (a)    Operation of Junk Yard. Motor Vehicle Salvage Business, or Impound
Lot Without License Prohibited.  No person shall operate or maintain a junk
yard, motor vehicle salvage business, or impound lot within the Municipality
unless they have first obtained a license issued under this section. No
licensee shall operate or maintain a junk yard, motor vehicle salvage business,
or impound lot in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any other
chapter of this Municipality's Code.
   (b)   License Application; Renewal.  Upon the filing of the application and
bond, or renewal application, as herein provided, the Safety-Service Director
may, upon his or her approval of such application after investigation and of
such bond as to sufficiency of and the payment to the Municipality of the
license fee herein provided, issue to the applicant a license to engage in
business as provided in this chapter. Only legal nonconforming uses, as allowed
by the Municipality's Code, specifically the Zoning Code, may apply for a
license to operate a business under this chapter. All licenses shall be
numbered in the order in which they are issued and shall state clearly the
location of the business, the date of issuance and expiration of the license
and the name and address of the licensee. The nonrefundable fee for a license
application is two hundred dollars ($200.00). All licenses issued shall expire
on January I following the date of issue. A license may be renewed from year to
year upon paying the City a nonrefundable one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each such renewal application.
   (c)    Violation;, Loss of License.  If the licensee is operating a business
under this chapter in violation of the Municipality's Code, the Safety-Service
Director shall issue a written notice of such violation(s), sent certified mail
or delivered in person to the licensee or its agent, and shall include a
specific time limit in which the licensee shall cure the violation(s). After
such time limit has ended, the Safety-Service Director or his or her designee
may inspect the business to verify that the violation(s) have been
satisfactorily cured, and to inspect for any other violations. If the violation
has not then been cured, criminal proceedings may be initiated against the
licensee. as well as any equitable order providing for an injunction or other
relief and all such other penalties' as provided herein. In addition, the
licensee may be subject to all penalties and proceedings as contained in
Section
717.08 herein.
   Whenever a license has been revoked, the Safety-Service Director shall not
issue another license to such licensee, to the husband or wife, or offspring of
such licensee, or to any partnership or corporation of which such licensee is
an officer or member unless a licensee should prevail on appeal.
   If a licensee fails to renew its license by February 1, or if one's
application has been denied, or if a licensee's license is revoked, or a
licensee is awaiting the decision of an appeal under subsection (d) or a
decision of a court action concerning the revocation of its license, the
licensee shall cease business operation covered by this chapter until a valid
license is obtained.
   A failure to cease business operations may result in substantial penalties
and criminal
prosecution (see Section
717.99). In addition, continuation of business operations in violation of this
chapter shall constitute a nuisance.
   In the event the licensee's license has been revoked, the licensee may
attempt to obtain a re-instated license by appeal to the Architectural Review
Board.
   (d)    Appeal of a Loss of License.  In the event the Safety-Service
Director revokes a valid license, or refuses to issue a renewal of a previously
valid license, or denies one's application for a license, the licensee or
applicant may appeal to a hearing before the Architectural Review Board (ARB).
The appeal must be made in writing and submitted to the ARB within fifteen (15)
days of the licensee's receipt or constructive receipt of written notice of its
revoked license or denied application. The licensee's appeal must specifically
include its name, location, violations charged against it, date the business
first began operations, and all other relevant facts. The decision of the ARB
is a final decision of the Municipality. The ARB may overturn a decision by the
Safety-Service Director and require a license to be issued only if:
      (1)   The ARB unanimously determines that the Safety-Service Director has
arbitrarily or capriciously decided to revoke or deny a license;
      (2)   The ARB determines by a majority that the licensee is in fact not
in violation of the charges of the Safety-Service Director or of the grounds
contained under subsection (e);
      (3)   The ARB determines by a majority that the licensee has adequately
remedied the violations within the specified time frame [see subsection (c)],
so that the licensee is no longer operating in violation of the Municipality's
Code.
   (e)    Grounds for Denial or Revocation of License.   In addition to other
grounds provided in this chapter or as expounded by the Municipality, the
renewal, or validity of an
existing license under this chapter may be denied or revoked upon any of the
following:  The applicant or licensee has:
      (1)   Made a false statement of material fact in its application;
      (2)   Is not in compliance with this chapter or any chapter in the
Municipality's Code;
      (3)   Been guilty of a fraudulent act in connection with dealing junk or
motor vehicles;
      (4)   Been charged of a felony in connection with the operation of the
business;
      (5)   Failed an inspection of the business and not fully remedied the
reason for such failure within the specified time limit;
      (6)   Been charged with two (2) or misdemeanors within any eighteen (18)
month period;
      (7)   Been operating the business in such a manner so as to constitute a
nuisance.
   (f)   Application.  Application for a license to operate and maintain a
business under this chapter, or for a renewal thereof, shall be made in writing
on a form approved by the Safety-Service Director, accompanied by the proper
fee, to the Safety-Service Director seeing forth: the name and address of the
applicant; the location of the junk yard; if the applicant is a firm,
partnership, or association, the names and addresses of each member; if the
applicant is a corporation, the date and place of incorporation and the names
and addresses of its officers and directors, a description of the fence to be
used; and such other reasonable information as the Safety-Service Director
deems necessary. The application shall be signed and sworn to by the
applicant.
   (g)    Inspection.  At least twice annually the Safety-Service Director, or
an officer or official appointed by the Safety-Service Director, such as the
Building Planning Department, shall inspect every junk yard, salvage motor
vehicle lot and impound lot that is located within the Municipality and for
which a license has been issued, to obtain information with regard to whether
the licensee's business has been and is being conducted in accordance with this
section. An additional subsequent inspection shall be allowed to verify
compliance with the Municipality's Code after a failed inspection or
application for a license.
   The Chief of Police may, for the purpose of public safety and enforcement of
the Municipality's Code, have free access to the grounds and buildings used in
the conduct of the business by the licensee. Such inspections may be made at
any reasonable time, at the option of the Chief of Police, during the regular
work hours of the licensee or between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through
Friday.
   
   (h)   Variance Request.  In addition to the right of appeal to the
Architectural Review Board as provided in this section, an applicant or
individual or business entity subject to the restriction of this Chapter may
file with the Architectural Review Board a written request for a variance from
the literal interpretation of this Chapter. The procedures used by the
Architectural Review Board in considering such variance requests are specified
in Section
717.08 hereunder. 
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   717.06  FENCE REQUIRED.
   (a)   Businesses under this chapter shall conceal outside storage areas with
a fence or enclosure around the perimeter of the business operations. A fence
is an enclosure which shall be non-transparent and be at least eight (8) and no
more than ten (10) feet in height (notwithstanding any zoning requirements),
and such height used must be consistent for the entire fence. The fence shall
be kept in good order and repair, in a neat and safe condition, and care shall
be taken to prevent deterioration. No advertisement shall be permitted on a
fence other than the name of the person under whose name the license has been
issued and the nature of the business conducted therein.
   (b)   Such fence shall be constructed of materials intended by the
manufacturer and industry for the purpose of a fence or enclosure. All fence
materials shall be treated or conditioned with an application, procedure, or
product to prevent deterioration. The materials used in the construction of the
fence shall eliminate all visibility through the fence for the entire height
required for the fence.
   (c)   A fence shall not consist of any other materials other than described
in this section. Trees, bushes, shrubbery or any other vegetational growth
shall never constitute a fence. The business junk shall never be kept, piled or
stored in such a manner so as to be greater in height than the fence. Such
fence must be in compliance with all other chapters of the Municipality's Code,
including, but not limited to, setback distances where applicable, unless
otherwise specified herein.
   (d)   A fence otherwise required by this Chapter shall not be required for
the specific portion of the business property which directly abuts the right of
way for an interstate highway and for entrance and exit ramps from any such
interstate highway within the City of Sharonville.  (Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-
10-02.)
   717.07  STORAGE OUTSIDE FENCED AREA PROHIBITED.
   No person who operates or maintains a business under this chapter inside the
Municipality shall place or permit any junk to remain in a manner or location
so that it is not obscured by the required fence.
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   
   717.08  PROCEDURES FOR ARCHITECTURAL REVIEW BOARD HEARINGS.
   The Architectural Review Board has authority and jurisdiction to hear
appeals filed pursuant to the provisions of Chapter
717 and to hear requests for variance from the literal interpretation of
Chapter
717. Any hearing held by the Architectural Review Board shall be open to the
public. and the Architectural Review Board may, at its discretion, hold public
hearings at such times as it determines to be appropriate. The Board shall make
a determination within thirty days from the conclusion date of any appeal
hearing and variance hearing held before such Board. All deliberation and
discussions by the Board shall be confidential and not subject to public
participation. The failure of the Board to act within the thirty-day period
shall not be determined to be either an approval or disapproval of the request
being sought by the applicant.
   (a)    In appeal hearings, the Board shall review any order, decision or
determination made by the Safety Service Director or his designate concerning
the enforcement or application of the requirements of Chapter
717 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Sharonville.  The Board may
reverse, affirm, modify or otherwise alter the contents and timing of any such
decision. The Board may swear in witnesses, record any such hearings and may
issue findings of fact and conclusions of law. The Board shall allow any
individual to testify at such hearing and to have an authorized agent or
attorney represent such individual at the hearing. The Board shall allow any
such party to subpoena witnesses and to subpoena documents and other tangible
evidence.
   (b)    The Board may authorize variances from the strict application of the
regulations of Chapter
717 by reason of exceptional lot configuration, unusual relationship between
the lot and adjoining properties and adjoining rights of way, or other
extraordinary situations which create an undue hardship based upon the strict
application of Chapter
717. No such variance shall substantially impair the public good or the
aesthetics of the surrounding community or the public safety considerations
benefited by the provisions of Chapter
717. The Board may reverse, affirm, modify or otherwise alter the contents and
timing of any such decision. The Board may swear in witnesses, record any such
hearings and may issue findings of fact and conclusions of law. The Board shall
allow any individual to testify at such hearing and to have an authorized agent
or attorney represent such individual at the hearing. The Board shall allow any
such party to subpoena witnesses and to subpoena documents and other tangible
evidence. A variance maybe granted by the Board if it finds by a preponderance
of the evidence that all of the following conditions exist:
      (1)   The granting of the variance is reasonably necessary to relieve a
hardship, to preserve the applicant’s right to continue operating a legal and
conforming business, not merely for the financial or practical convenience of
the applicant.
      (2)   The requested variance shall not constitute an increase in the
nonconforming use of the regulated business without proof that such extension
of a nonconforming use has been approved by the Sharonville Planning Commission
pursuant to the Zoning Code of the City of Sharonville.
      (3)   That special circumstances or conditions apply to the property and
the business in question and are unique to such property.
      (4)   That the special circumstances which are unique to the property in
question are not the result of previous actions taken by the applicant.
      (5)   The aesthetic and safety considerations of adjoining properties,
including public rights of way, will not be detrimentally affected by the
granting of the variance.
In a request for a variance, the applicant shall clearly state in writing the
above five criteria and how the requested variance shall address all of the
required criteria.    
   (c)   After the determination by the Architectural Review Board concerning
appeals and variances, the decision of the Architectural Review Board shall be
final. Any further remedy shall involve Court appeals at the discretion of the
applicant. No further action shall be necessary from the Safety Service
Director, the City Council or any other administrative body of the City of
Sharonville to enact the decision of the Architectural Review Board.
      (Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
   
   717.99  PENALTIES.
   (a)    Procedure against Violators.  Whenever the Safety Service Director
believes that a business under this chapter is being operated or maintained in
violation of any of the provisions of this section, he or she may apply, in the
name of the Municipality, seek any criminal charges as detailed herein to a
court of competent jurisdiction, alleging the violation complained. In
addition, the Safety Service Director may seek civil relief by praying for an
injunction or other proper relief. In such a case the court may order such
business abated as a nuisance or make such other order as may be proper. In
addition, the criminal complaint may be initiated in conjunction with, or
independent of, any other action.
   (b)    Penalty.  Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and subject to criminal prosecution. In addition,
a business in violation of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100) per day for
every day such business is in violation of this chapter. Upon a third (3)
violation charged within any eighteen (18) month period. such charge shall be a
fourth degree misdemeanor, and may be sought in conjunction or independently of
other relief. A licensee may further be subject to other claims, such as loss
of nonconforming status or operating a nuisance, when so warranted by law or by
the Municipality's Code.
(Ord. 2002-71.  Passed 12-10-02.)
CHAPTER 719
Secondhand and Precious Metal Dealers
719.01   Definitions.
719.02   License required; fee and revocation.
719.03   License application.
719.04   Duties of secondhand and precious metal dealers.
719.05   Forbidden transactions with minors.
719.06   Mandatory retention of items.
719.07   Altered and defaced items.
719.08   Permissible proof of identification.
719.09   Forbidden transactions.
719.10   Inspection.
719.11   Forbidden firearms and weapons transactions.
719.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
      Record of transactions required - see Ohio R.C. 4737.01, 4737.04
      Dealing with minors prohibited; hours regulated - see Ohio R.C. 4737.03
      Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
   719.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, certain terms are defined as follows:
   (a)    "Secondhand articles" includes secondhand articles of any kind, scrap
iron, old metal, canvas, rope, bottles, junk, lead or copper pipe, gold,
silver, platinum, diamonds and other precious metals, coins, firearms, knives
and stamps.
   (b)    "Secondhand dealer" means any person who purchases, exchanges, trades
or receives secondhand articles for profit; provided, however, that any person
who deals in scrap iron, canvas, rope, bottles or junk on an irregular basis
shall not be considered to be a secondhand dealer. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-
81.)
   719.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE AND REVOCATION.
   (a)    No person, including an individual, partnership, corporation or
association, shall purchase, exchange, trade or receive secondhand articles
within the City for profit without first obtaining a secondhand and precious
metal dealer's license from the office of the Safety-Service Director. The fee
for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year, renewable in
January of each year. License fees shall be prorated based upon the number of
months remaining in the year for licenses purchased after January 31, in any
year.
   (b)    Any license issued under this section may be revoked by the Director
after reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard, for any violation of this
chapter, by the licensee or by any of his officers, agents or employees.
Whenever a license has been revoked under this chapter, the Director shall not
issue another license to such licensee, to the spouse of such licensee or to
any partnership or corporation of which he is an officer or member, until such
licensee complies with all of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 81-64.
Passed 10-13-81.)
   (c)    For all shows, conventions and exhibitions provided in convention
centers and other exhibition facilities in the City, the requirements for a
license shall be satisfied by the issuance of the license to the individual or
business entity which is responsible for the show, convention or exhibition.
The Safety-Service Director shall prepare written regulations which shall be
complied with for any such show, convention or exhibition, including, the
following data: the name, date of birth (or date of incorporation), social
security number (or tax identification number) and other critical data, such as
prior criminal record, for all participants in the show, convention or
exhibition. The individual or business entity responsible for the show,
convention or exhibition, shall provide assurance to the Director that all
Federal laws are being complied with by the participants in the event, and that
all participants have been provided with a copy of the regulations required for
second hand and precious metal and weapons dealers provided for under Section
719.04 hereunder, prior to the commencement of the show, convention or
exhibition. (Ord. 94-32E. Passed 3-8-94.)
   719.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Each applicant for a license to engage in the business of secondhand and
precious metal dealer shall file with the Safety-Service Director's office a
written application upon a form prescribed by the Director and signed by the
applicant. Such application shall state:
   (a)    The names and residences of the applicants and the type of business
entity of the applicant; and
   (b)    The premises where such business shall be located.
      (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.04  DUTIES OF SECONDHAND AND PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS.
   All secondhand and precious metal dealers shall:
   (a)    Post in a conspicuous place in his shop or other place of business a
sign having his name and occupation legibly inscribed thereon;
   (b)    Prepare on forms, provided by the Chief of Police, accurate daily
transaction records containing a description of the articles purchased or sold,
the name, description and residence of the person from whom the items were
purchased and received and the date and hour when such purchase or exchange was
made. In addition, the form shall include any names, dates, words, numbers or
initials inscribed upon the property;
   (c)    Require valid identification from all persons from whom the
secondhand and precious metal dealer purchases or receives any secondhand
articles;
   (d)    Demand and examine the driver's license or identification card plus
one additional type of card typically used for identification purposes of the
individual with whom the secondhand or precious metal dealer engages in any
business transactions; and
   (e)    Return the completed forms to the Chief of Police before 10:01 a.m.
of the next business day after the transaction. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.05  FORBIDDEN TRANSACTIONS WITH MINORS.
   No secondhand or precious metal dealer shall purchase, exchange, trade or
receive any secondhand article from a minor knowing or having reason to believe
such person to be a minor. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.06  MANDATORY RETENTION OF ITEMS.
   No secondhand or precious metal dealer shall sell, transfer, alter in any
way, or dispose of any items purchased or in any way obtained by him without
allowing a period of at least three days to elapse, not including Saturdays,
Sundays or holidays.
(Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.07  ALTERED OR DEFACED ITEMS.
   No secondhand or precious metal dealer shall purchase or in any manner
accept in the regular course of his business any item which contains a serial
number or other identifying number on which the number has been in any way
defaced or altered.
(Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.08  PERMISSIBLE PROOF OF IDENTIFICATION.
   A secondhand or precious metal dealer need not accept the identification
offered by any person who offers to transact business with such dealer in the
event that the dealer has reason to believe that the seller is not the owner of
the merchandise offered to the dealer. In any such case, the dealer may require
a sworn and notarized statement from the individual claiming to be the owner of
any such item. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.09  FORBIDDEN TRANSACTIONS.
   No secondhand or precious metal dealer shall purchase, exchange, trade or
receive any secondhand article from any individual who fails to provide the
identification that is required under this chapter. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-
81.)
   719.10  INSPECTION.
   Twice annually the Chief of Police shall inspect each premises upon which a
license under this chapter has been issued, in order to obtain information with
regard to whether the licensee's business has been conducted in accordance with
this chapter. The Chief shall submit a written report of such examination to
the Safety-Service Director. The Chief shall, for the purpose of this
examination, have free access to the grounds and buildings used in the conduct
of the business by the licensee. Such inspections may be made at any time, at
the option of the Chief, during the regular business hours of the licensee. No
secondhand or precious metal dealer shall deny access to the Chief to make the
inspection as provided for in this section. (Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
   719.11  FORBIDDEN FIREARMS AND WEAPONS TRANSACTIONS.
   (a)    No person shall sell, attempt to sell or display for the purposes of
sale any gun, knife or other weapon outside of the premises which it utilized
for any show, convention or exhibition at which the sale of guns, knives or
other weapons is permitted by a secondhand and precious metal dealers license
when any such activity takes place within 1,000 feet of any portion of the
structure in which the show, convention or exhibition has been licensed.
   (b)    A violation of this section shall be a fourth degree misdemeanor,
punishable as provided by Section
501.99 of the Codified Ordinances. (Ord. 94-32E. Passed 3-8-94.)
   719.99  PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates Section
719.02 shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months,
or both.
   (b)    Whoever violates any provision of Sections
719.03 to
719.10 inclusive shall be guilty of a third degree misdemeanor and shall be
fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than
sixty days, or both, for the first offense; and shall be guilty of a first
degree misdemeanor for any subsequent violation thereof.
   (c)    Conviction of a third offense under this chapter shall result in the
permanent loss of any person's secondhand or precious metal dealer's license.
(Ord. 81-64. Passed 10-13-81.)
CHAPTER 721
Mechanical Amusement Devices
721.01   License and compliance required.
721.02   Definitions.
721.03   License fees.
721.04   License application.
721.05   Residence requirements.  (Repealed)
721.06   Mechanism requirement. (Repealed)
721.07   Operation near schools prohibited.
721.08   Playing by minors prohibited.  (Repealed)
721.09   Transferability.
721.10   Change of location.
721.11   Police inspection.
721.12   Information to be furnished by distributor.
721.13   License revocation.
721.14   Gambling prohibited.
721.15   Seizure and destruction of  pinball machines.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to destroy gambling devices - see Ohio R.C. 715.51
      Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
      Tampering- see GEN. OFF.
545.12
   721.01  LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of selling,
leasing, renting, operating or exhibiting pinball machines, without first
obtaining a license to do so and conforming to the regulations provided for
such business in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Pinball machine" means any machine or device commonly or popularly
known as a pinball machine, any electronic game and any machine or device which
registers a score and in which or on which a person can shoot or roll, either
manually, mechanically or electronically one or more pellets, balls or marbles,
or play any electronic insertion of a coin, disc or other insertion piece or
upon the payment of a consideration. (Ord. 81-2. Passed 2-10-81.)
   (b)    "Distributor" means any person, firm or corporation which sells,
leases, rents or otherwise distributes pinball machines within the City.
   (c)    "Exhibitor" means a person, firm or corporation owning or conducting
a place of business in the City and operating or exhibiting one or more pinball
machines at such place of business. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.03  LICENSE FEES.
   Every distributor shall pay an annual license fee of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) and every exhibitor shall pay an annual license fee of seven
dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) plus a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for
each pinball machine maintained or exhibited. An exhibitor operating at more
than one location shall pay a license fee for each location.
(Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.04  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Applications for distributor, exhibitor and pinball machine licenses shall
be made to the Safety-Service Director on forms provided by him. An application
for a distributor's license shall set forth the place of business and residence
of the distributor. If the distributor is a firm, the place of residence of all
the partners shall be furnished. If the distributor is a corporation, the place
of residence of the chief business manager or other controlling executive
officer shall be furnished. An application for an exhibitor's license shall, in
addition, state the number of pinball machines for which licenses are
requested, the trade name, design or operation of each such machine and the
location of the premises and the particular room on the premises in which such
pinball machines are to be exhibited. If the Director is satisfied that the
applicant has complied with all the provisions of this chapter and is otherwise
eligible to be a licensee, he shall issue the license on payment of the license
fees. The Director shall, if necessary, inspect any machine sought to be
licensed in order to determine whether it complies with the provisions of this
chapter. If a location consists of more than one room, the particular room
shall be specified. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70; Ord. 81-2. Passed 2-10-81.)
   721.05  RESIDENCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 81-2, passed February
10, 1981.)
   721.06  MECHANISM REQUIREMENT.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 81-24; passed May 26,
1981.)
   721.07  OPERATION NEAR SCHOOLS PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall maintain or exhibit a pinball machine
on any premises situated less than 300 feet from the building and grounds of
any elementary or high school. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.08  PLAYING BY MINORS PROHIBITED.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 90-46, passed June
26, 1990.)
   721.09  TRANSFERABILITY.
   When the business of a distributor or exhibitor is sold or otherwise
transferred, the license of such distributor or exhibitor may be transferred to
the transferee with the consent of the Safety-Service Director, for the
remainder of the license period, if the latter shall be satisfied that such
successor would be eligible to receive a new license. The transfer of an
exhibitor's license shall carry with it the transfer of the pinball machine
license issued, but such transfer shall be noted on the books of the Safety-
Service Director and upon the license stamp of each machine transferred. (Ord.
70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.10  CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   No licensed pinball machine shall be removed from one premises to another or
from one room to another room on the same premises, unless the new location is
approved by the Safety-Service Director and duly noted on his records.
(Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70; Ord. 81-2. Passed 2-10-81.)
   721.11  POLICE INSPECTION.
   All pinball machines and all premises in which such machines are maintained
or exhibited, shall be open to inspection by the police at all times. (Ord. 70-
62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.12  INFORMATION TO BE FURNISHED BY DISTRIBUTOR.
   Not later than the fifth day of each month, every distributor shall furnish
the Safety-Service Director with a list of all new contracts for the sale,
leasing or renting of one or more pinball machines entered into during the
preceding month, with persons residing or doing business in the City, giving
the names and addresses of such persons, the dates of the contracts and the
identifying number or mark of each machine, if the machine is so identified.
The Director shall file such reports and maintain them for the inspection of
the police for a period of not less than one year. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-
70.)
   721.13  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Should any distributor or exhibitor violate or fail to comply with any of
the provisions of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the Safety-Service
Director to revoke his license. In case of the revocation of an exhibitor's
license, the licenses of all machines operated by him or on his premises shall
be revoked and such machines removed from the premises within twenty-four
hours. A distributor or exhibitor whose license has been revoked shall not be
eligible to apply for or receive a new license for one year after the
revocation.
(Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
   721.14  GAMBLING PROHIBITED.
   No distributor, exhibitor or any of their employees or agents, shall use or
permit to be used for gambling, any pinball machine located on premises owned
or leased by them, or under their care and control. (Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-
70.)
   721.15  SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF PINBALL MACHINES.
   If any pinball machine is used as a gambling device or is held, exhibited or
operated contrary to the provisions of the laws of the State or this chapter,
such machine may be seized by any police officer acting pursuant to orders of
the Safety-Service Director and upon seizure may be destroyed by order of the
Director.
(Ord. 70-62. Passed 11-24-70.)
CHAPTER 725
Peddlers
725.01   Vehicle peddlers; fee.
725.02   Cart peddlers; fee.
725.03   Hand peddlers; fee.
725.04   Indigent peddlers.
725.05   Signs required.
725.06   Personal products.
725.07   Selling unfit food products.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Frozen dessert peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
709
      Solicitors and canvassers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
733
   725.01  VEHICLE PEDDLERS; FEE.
   All peddlers and vendors of food, vegetables, farm products, butter, eggs,
fish, poultry, meat, coal, candy, bakery goods and other merchandise of any
kind, from vehicles drawn by animals or motor power, shall pay a license fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) per annum, for each vehicle used for such purposes.
Provided, however that if the licenses shall be procured on or after July 1 of
any calendar year, the license fee shall be five dollars ($5.00). (Ord. 61-20.
Passed 5-16-61.)
   725.02  CART PEDDLERS; FEE.
   Peddlers selling foods, vegetables or goods of any kind from vehicles drawn
by hand, shall pay a license fee of five dollars ($5.00) per annum for each
vehicle used for such purpose.  (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   725.03  HAND PEDDLERS; FEE.
   Peddlers selling goods carried by hand, shall pay a license fee of five
dollars ($5.00) per annum; provided, however, that free licenses may be issued
to indigent peddlers in accordance with the provisions of Section
725.04 of this chapter.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   725.04  INDIGENT PEDDLERS.
   Any legal resident of the Municipality desiring an indigent license to
peddle by hand shall first make written application therefor to the Safety-
Service Director. The Safety-Service Director shall have an investigation made
as to applicant's moral character, physical health and means of support. If
upon investigation it is determined that applicant is a proper person to be so
licensed, the Safety-Service Director shall issue to the applicant a free
license to peddle by hand only for a period not to exceed three months. Any
license so issued may be revoked by the Safety-Service Director upon
recommendation of the Police Chief.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   725.05  SIGNS REQUIRED.
   The Safety-Service Director is required to furnish every license issued for
every vehicle used upon the streets of the Municipality one sign having
printed, painted or stamped thereon the year for which the license has been
taken out, together with the character and number of the same. (Ord. 61-20.
Passed 5-16-61.)
   725.06  PERSONAL PRODUCTS.
   It is provided that any person peddling farm or dairy products of his own
production shall not be charged the license fee provided herein, but may
receive a license upon the payment of one dollar ($1.00) and the giving of
satisfactory evidence of the character of his products.  (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-
16-61.)
   725.07  SELLING UNFIT FOOD PRODUCTS .
   No person shall sell, offer or expose for sale, any food product which is
unfit for human consumption.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61,)
CHAPTER 729
Shows and Exhibitions
729.01   License required.
729.02   Application for license.
729.03   License fee; revocation.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63
      Shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
   729.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall exhibit, or participate in exhibiting within the
Municipality, any theatrical performance, circus, menagerie or show of any
kind, other than a theater or moving picture show permanently located in the
Municipality, and established in a building, not a tent, or give any concert or
entertainment for which money or other reward is in any manner demanded or
received, without first having obtained a license therefor from the Safety-
Service Director.
   Lectures on scientific, historical or literary subjects, or permanently
located theaters or moving picture shows, or concerts or literary
entertainments given or conducted by any school, church or fraternal society or
organization, shall not come within the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 61-
20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   729.02  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE .
   Any person desiring a license shall make written application therefor to the
Safety-Service Director, stating therein the date or dates as nearly as
possible, the kind or character of such entertainment and the name of the owner
or manager thereof. Upon payment to the Safety-Service Director, of the license
fee hereinafter stipulated, the Safety-Service Director shall issue a license
in accordance with such application, subject to the provisions hereinafter
mentioned, and shall register the applicant's name, the date and character of
such entertainment and the amount of license fee so paid. (Ord. 61-20. Passed
5-16-61.)
   729.03  LICENSE FEE; REVOCATION.
   For each license issued by the Safety-Service Director there shall be paid a
fee which shall not be less than one dollar ($1.00), nor more than ten dollars
($10.00) per day.
   The Safety-Service Director shall, upon proper application, accompanied by
the fee hereinafter provided, grant to the owners or managers of halls, a
yearly license, the fee for which shall not be less than fifteen dollars
($15.00), nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). Any license may be revoked for
good cause by the Safety-Service Director.
(Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
CHAPTER 733
Solicitors
733.01    Definition.
733.02   Permit and license required.
733.03   Application; fee; expiration.
733.04   Investigation and issuance.
733.05   Badges.
733.06   Hours of solicitation regulated.
733.07   Notice prohibiting solicitation/duty of solicitors.
733.08   Violations.
733.09   Duty of police to enforce.
733.10   Records.
733.11   Revocation of license.
733.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      License revocation - see Ohio R.C. 2961.03
      Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
      Peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
725
      Temporary stores and transient dealers - see
         BUS. REG. Ch.
741
733.01  DEFINITION.
   (a)   As used in this chapter, “canvasser” or “solicitor” means a person
performing any of the following:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or publication;
      (3)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for gas or electric
companies or any other utility company and cable television companies; or
      (4)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals
and every other type or kind of publication.
   (b)   Neither “canvasser” or “solicitor”, as defined above apply to
political or religious solicitation or canvassing of other free speech
expression, nor does it apply to non-profit solicitation conducted by minors in
connection with fund-raising or to solicitation by a newspaper carrier of
customers for a newspaper for which he regularly delivers or will regularly
deliver. 
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.02  PERMIT AND LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No solicitor or canvasser shall engage in such business within the corporate
limits without first obtaining a permit and license therefor in compliance with
the provisions of this chapter.  (Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.03  APPLICATION; FEE; EXPIRATION.
   Applicants for permit and license under this chapter must file with the
Safety-Service Director an application in writing on a form to be furnished by
the Safety-Service Director which shall give the following information:
   (a)   Name and description of the applicant (all agents of the applicant who
will offer or sell goods or services within the City must separately apply);
   (b)   Social security number, permanent home address, full local address,
phone number and email address, if any, of the applicant;
   (c)   A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be
sold;
   (d)   If employed, contact information (name, address, phone number and
email address, if any);
   (e)   The length of time for which the right to do business is desired
provided, however, that this right may not exceed a period of three (3) months
per application;
   (f)   Vehicle information (make and year of vehicle; license plate number)
that will be used by applicant;
   (g)   Driver’s license number of applicant;
   (h)   A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty days immediately
prior to the date of the filing of the application, showing the head and
shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner;
   (i)   The fingerprints of the applicant;
   (j)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of
any felony or misdemeanor or violation of any Municipal ordinance, the nature
of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor other than a
traffic moving violation; and
   (k)   The City’s income tax form must also be filled out and filed with the
application.
   At the time of filing the application, a non-refundable administrative fee
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the City to cover the cost of
investigation of the facts stated therein.  An additional non-refundable fee of
forty-five dollars ($45.00) is required per applicant for criminal background
assessments.  All permits issued hereunder shall be for a period of ninety (90)
days from the date of issuance.
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.04  INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Upon receipt of the completed application and required fee, the Chief
of Police shall cause an investigation of the applicant to occur.
   (b)   If as a result of the investigation, it is deemed that the applicant
has had any felony conviction within the last five (5) years related to
deception, fraud, sex offense, drug offense, any crime of violence which may
present a danger to the public, or any other crime of moral turpitude, or three
(3) or more misdemeanors within the last three (3) years, other than for a
traffic offense, the application may be denied.  If such application is denied,
the Chief of Police shall endorse such denial upon the application, state the
reasons for the same and forward the application to the Safety Service Director
or his or her designee, who shall notify the applicant that his application is
disapproved and that no license will be issued.
   (c)   If as a result of the investigation, no conviction as detailed in
subsection (b) hereof is discovered, the Chief of Police shall endorse on the
application his approval, execute a permit, and forward the permit, along with
the application to the Safety Service Director or his or her designee, who
shall deliver to the applicant the permit and license.
   (d)   If the permit is not denied within ten (10) business days, it is
deemed approved and a license shall be issued.
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.05  BADGES.
   The Safety-Service Director shall issue to each licensee at the time of
delivery of his license a badge which shall contain the words “Licensed
Solicitor”, the period for which the license is issued and the number of the
license, in letters and figures easily discernible from a distance of ten
feet.  The badge shall, during the time the licensee is engaged in soliciting,
be worn constantly by the licensee on the front of his outer garment in such a
way as to be conspicuous.  (Ord. 2013- 50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.06  HOURS OF SOLICITATION REGULATED.
   No solicitation shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. on
weekdays, Saturdays and Sundays, or at any time on a state or national holiday.
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.07  NOTICE PROHIBITING SOLICITATION/DUTY OF SOLICITORS.
   (a)   Notice by the owner or occupant of any residence or place of business
of the determination to refuse to receive any uninvited solicitors shall be
given by displaying a weatherproof card, decal or sign, not less than 2" by 3"
in size, not more than one square foot in total surface area, upon or near the
main entrance door to the residence or place of business indicating such
determination by the owner or occupant containing the words “No Solicitors
invited” or words of similar import, with letters at least one-third of an inch
in height.  Such card, decal or sign so exhibited shall constitute sufficient
notice to any solicitor of the determination by the owner or occupant of the
information contained thereon.  Any sign that complies with the requirements of
this section shall be exempt from any additional or different requirements
contained in the provisions of these Ordinances, including, but not limited to,
the Planning and Zoning Code.
   (b)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether
invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the owner or occupant.  (Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.08  VIOLATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, organization or entity regulated by
this chapter to:
   (a)   Go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near the door, rap
or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to
attract the attention of any occupant of such residence or business for the
purpose of solicitation in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence or
place of business in accordance with the provisions of Section
733.07;
   (b)   Solicit or canvass contrary to the hours listed in Section
733.06;
   (c)   Solicit or canvass without appropriately obtaining a permit in
advance;
   (d)   Solicit or canvass without wearing the badge as indicated in Section
733.05;
   (e)   Remain on property without permission of the occupant or property
owner after the solicitor or canvasser has been requested by the occupant or
owner to leave such private premises;
   (f)   Make any false statement or misrepresentation in the process of
applying for a solicitor permit; or
   (g)   Violate any other section of this chapter not specified in Section
733.08.
      (Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.09  DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE.
   It shall be the duty of any police officer of the Municipality to require
any person seen soliciting or canvassing, who is not known by the officer to be
duly licensed, to produce his solicitor’s or canvasser’s license and to enforce
this chapter against any person found to be violating the same.  (Ord. 2013-
50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.10  RECORDS.
   The Chief of Police shall report to the Safety Service Director all
convictions for violations of this chapter and the Safety Service Director
shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of
violations therein.
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.11  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   Permits and licenses issued under this chapter may be revoked by the
Safety-Service Director after notice and hearing for any of the following
causes:
      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for license;
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of
carrying on his business as solicitor or as canvasser;
      (3)   Any violation of this chapter;
      (4)   Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude;
or
      (5)   Conducting the business of soliciting or of canvassing, in an
unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of  the peace or
to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public.
   (b)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and
place of hearing.  The notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee
at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for
hearing.  Said hearing shall be conducted by the Safety-Service Director, or
designee.  Witnesses may attend.  The Safety Service Director’s decision shall
be rendered within ten (10) calendar days of the hearing and shall be rendered
in writing with a copy mailed, postage prepaid, to the solicitor at his or her
address.
   (c)   An issued permit will be immediately suspended upon the issuance of a
notice of hearing under this section and will remain suspended pending a
decision to reinstate the permit by the Safety Service Director.  (Ord. 2013-
50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
733.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor subject to the maximum fine allowed by law.  Each day on which such
activities are conducted in violation of this chapter shall constitute a
separate offense.  In addition to any legal remedy, as described above, an
offender who violates this chapter for a third time, regardless of the
timeframe, shall be prohibited from soliciting within the City.
(Ord. 2013-50.  Passed 12-17-13.)
CHAPTER 737
Taxicabs
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Chapter
737 was repealed by Ordinance 98-75, passed December 8, 1998.
CHAPTER 741
Temporary Stores and Transient Dealers
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   No temporary stores or transient dealers.
741.03   Exceptions.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.64
      Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
545.18
      Peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
725
      Solicitors and canvassers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
733
   741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Temporary store" or "transient business" means a store, storeroom,
office building, lot, railroad car or other place opened and maintained for the
sale to the public of goods, wares or merchandise where the transient dealer,
to-wit, the seller or owner of the goods, wares or merchandise operates the
place of business for a period of less than one hundred twenty business days.
   (b)    "Transient dealer" means a person who opens and maintains a temporary
store or transient business; and such store and/or place which shall be opened,
operated and maintained in the Municipality shall, prima-facie, be presumed to
be a temporary store or transient business, within the meaning of this chapter,
but the presumption may be overcome by evidence satisfactory to the Safety-
Service Director that the place of business is not a temporary store or
transient business, and that the person is not a transient dealer as herein
defined, in which case the Safety-Service Director shall not be required to
issue a license or to take a bond in lieu of payment therefore as required by
Section
741.03 of this chapter.
   (c)    "Person" means any individual, association, partnership or
corporation or the operator for or the agent of such person as herein defined,
who sells to the public at wholesale or retail through or by means of a
temporary store or transient business any goods, wares or merchandise except as
herein provided. (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   741.02  NO TEMPORARY STORES OR TRANSIENT DEALERS.
   (a)   No person shall engage in operating a temporary store for transient
business, nor shall any person act as a transient dealer within the City of
Sharonville.
   (b)   Failure to comply with this section shall constitute a minor
misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
violation.
   (c)   Each day of operation in violation of this section shall constitute a
separate offense.  (Ord. 2001-29.  Passed 5-29-01.)
   741.03  EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to persons selling by sample only, nor to any
agricultural articles or products offered or exposed for sale by the producer,
nor to persons selling articles of their own manufacture, nor to sales pursuant
to the order of any court of competent jurisdiction, nor to any person owning
or operating a branch store or stores within the Municipality, provided such
person or the principal of such person has been engaged in the same kind of
business in the Municipality for a period of more than one hundred twenty
business days prior to the date of the opening of the branch store or stores.
   However, persons selling agricultural articles or products produced by them,
shall, prior to sale of such articles or products, submit to the Municipality
an affidavit affirming that they produced such agricultural articles or
products, the location where such products were produced and other information
as may be required by the Safety-Service Director for the regulation of such
sales.
(Ord. 71-45. Passed 12-14-71.)
CHAPTER 745
Trailers and Trailer Parks
745.01   Definitions.
745.02   Safety and sanitary conditions.
745.03   Zoning ordinances not to be violated.
745.04   Records to be kept.
745.05   Trailers to be parked in designated areas.
745.06   Right of entry.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Trailer parks - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3733
      Tax levy upon house trailers - see Ohio R.C. 4503.06 et seq.
      Hotels, motels and tourist cabins - see BUS. REG. Ch.
713
      Garbage and wastes - see S. & P. S. Ch.
911
   745.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Trailer" means and includes a trailer, house car, camp car or any
vehicle or structure mounted on wheels or capable of being propelled from place
to place either by its own power or power supplied by some vehicle attached
thereto, or to be attached thereto, and being used for living or sleeping
quarters.
   (b)    "Trailer park" means any lot or parcel of ground within the limits of
the Municipality, where accommodation is provided for one or more automobile
trailers or house cars used as living or sleeping quarters.
      (Ord. 61-20. Passed 5-16-61.)
   745.02  SAFETY AND SANITARY CONDITIONS.
   It shall be the duty of any person, firm, partnership or corporation
conducting a trailer park to maintain the same in a safe and sanitary condition
at all times and subject to the following regulations, to wit:
   (a)    The trailer park site shall be of adequate area and each unit
reserved for the accommodation of any automobile trailer or house car shall be
not less than twenty-five feet by thirty-five feet, and shall be clearly
defined by proper markers at each corner. The site shall be level, free from
rocks and weeds and well drained. No trailer or house car shall be located on
any unit where there is less than ten feet between each trailer or house car
and other building, trailer, house car or other structure, or within ten feet
from the property line separating the park from adjoining properties.
   (b)    Each trailer park shall be supplied with pure and wholesome running
water.
   (c)    All drain water from drives and roofs shall be properly tiled to a
storm or sanitary sewer, and drain water shall not be permitted to collect upon
the premises nor drain to adjoining property.
   (d)    A covered metal garbage pail and a covered metal rubbish container
shall be provided for each four or less units and shall be of such capacity as
to properly take care of all garbage and rubbish emanating from the units
intended to be serviced. All garbage shall be wrapped in paper before the same
is placed in a metal container.
   (e)    No garbage, refuse, sewage or waste shall be dumped upon the premises
or any adjoining property.
   (f)    Each site for which a trailer park license is obtained shall be
provided with toilets, urinals, wash basins, showers or baths, water faucets,
etc., in accordance with the following specifications:
      (1)    The trailer park shall be provided with adequate and proper toilet
facilities, comprising water-flushed plumbing equipment connected to a sanitary
sewer, and separate toilet facilities provided for each sex. The use of
chemical toilets or privies shall be prohibited, and each trailer park shall
provide not less than one water-flushed toilet for each sex for every ten units
or fraction thereof.
      (2)    Each toilet room provided for men shall have, in addition, one
urinal stall.
      (3)    Each toilet room shall be provided with one wash basin with
running water for each three toilets.
      (4)    One shower or bath tub shall be provided for each sex for each ten
units or fraction thereof.
      (5)    All toilets, sinks, showers, urinals, etc., shall be placed in
properly constructed buildings located not more than 150 feet from each trailer
unit which they are supposed to service.
      (6)    Toilet buildings shall be well-lighted at all times, day or night,
well- ventilated with screened openings and constructed of such moisture proof
material as shall permit rapid and satisfactory cleaning, scouring and washing.
      (7)    The floors shall be of concrete or similar material, elevated not
less than four inches above grade, and shall slope to the floor drain located
in each room.
      (8)    One slop sink or basin with water supply shall be provided to
serve each four trailer units, and shall be constructed in accordance with an
approved design, size and material.
      (9)    Where toilet and bathing facilities are provided for both sexes in
the same building, a tight, soundproof wall shall be constructed between the
male and female sections.
   (g)    Waste cans for emergency toilet use shall be prohibited in any and
all trailers.
   (h)    All trailers using gas, kerosene, gasoline or fuel oil for heating or
cooking purposes shall have their stoves properly vented together with flues of
adequate size and construction; and with the exception of a supply container
for each trailer, no gasoline, kerosene or fuel oil shall be stored on the
premises. The supply container must be approved by the Fire Chief.
   (i)    All trailers shall be maintained in a portable condition (on wheels)
at all times. No person shall move or cause to be moved, the wheels or tires
from any trailer within the Municipality, except for the purpose of repairing
or replacing, which repairing or replacing shall be done immediately. No person
shall, in any manner, elevate, block or stabilize any trailer. No one shall
permit the occupancy of a trailer by a greater number of persons than those for
which the trailer was designed to accommodate.
   (j)    Each trailer park shall be under the direct management of the owner
or his agent or representative. Such person or persons must be of good
reputation and character, and shall operate such park from an office located on
the grounds, in which office shall be maintained registration records. It shall
