   915.04  APPLICATION FOR MEMBERSHIP.
   Memberships in and for the use of such municipal recreation facilities shall
be made on the application of a parent or guardian, husband or wife, or
individual, in which such applicant shall submit all residence requirements and
ages of all members of that family desiring to become members.  Upon payment of
all the aforesaid stated fees for such family, and each member having his
photograph taken and identification cards completed, the Recreation Director
shall issue their membership thereto.
(Ord. 78-28.  Passed 3-28-78; Ord. 2006-47.  Passed 9-26-06.)
   915.05  COMPLIANCE WITH RULES.
   It is further provided that all memberships shall be subject to all the
rules and regulations set forth by the Recreation Director and that all members
shall abide by all such rules and regulations that the Recreation Director
shall set forth for the safety, protection and orderly use of such facilities,
and members thereof.
(Ord. 78-28.  Passed 3-28-78.)
915.06  BANNING REGISTERED SEX OFFENDERS FROM MEMBERSHIP AT SHARONVILLE
RECREATION FACILITIES.
   Any membership in the Sharonville Recreation Facilities shall be denied, or
if already issued, rescinded, and the membership fee refunded, for any
individual who, pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 2950, has a duty to register in
Ohio, and who appears, or should appear, on the Sex Offender Registry
maintained by the Ohio Attorney General or the Hamilton County Sheriff’s Office
or the National Sex Offender Registry.  The required application for membership
shall include an inquiry about whether the applicant, or if applying for a two-
person or family membership, any adult family member of the applicant, is an
individual presently required to register as a sex offender.  The Sharonville
Recreation Department shall examine the membership applications for all
individuals applying for and holding memberships at the Sharonville Recreation
Facilities to determine whether such individuals are mandated to register as
sex offenders in the State of Ohio.  In such event, the Sharonville Recreation
Department shall inform the individual that the membership application is
denied or rescinded as to any family member who is required to register as a
sex offender, except those adjudicated as a sex offender in Juvenile Court, and
any prorated fees for such member’s application shall be refunded to such
individual by the Recreation Department.  The Recreation Director or the
designee of the Recreation Director shall adopt reasonable rules to calculate
the amount of refund owed to such individual in the event that such individual
is a member of a family or other multiple individual membership at the
Sharonville Recreation Facilities.  The term “Sharonville Recreation
Facilities”, as used in this section shall apply to all Sharonville Recreation
Department facilities which are accessed by Sharonville Recreation Facilities
Membership Cards.  No individual who is banned for membership by this section
shall be presented at Sharonville Recreation Facilities which require
membership cards.  This ban applies to all individuals who request guest passes
to Sharonville Recreation Facilities as well as annual memberships.  Violation
of this restriction shall represent Criminal Trespass, a violation of Codified
Ordinance
541.05 (Criminal Trespass).
(Ord. 2014-13.  Passed 4-8-14.)
CHAPTER 917
Golden View Acres
917.01   Eligibility requirements.
917.02   Rental agreement.
917.03   Future vacancies; waiting list.
917.04   Duties of Safety-Service Director.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Nursing and rest homes - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3721; OAC Ch. 3701-17
      Existing nursing and rest homes - see OAC Ch. 4101:2-90
   917.01  ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS.
   The eligibility requirements for tenancy in Golden View Acres are hereby
stated for lessees:
   (a)   Primary Lessee.
      (1)   Resident of Sharonville for at least one year and minimum age 57.
      (2)   Parent, grandparent, or child of Sharonville resident, if such
resident has lived in Sharonville for one year and if such parent or
grandparent is a minimum age 57.
      (3)   Brother or sister of Sharonville resident, if such resident has
lived in Sharonville for one year and if such brother or sister is a minimum
age 57.
      (4)   Each applicant shall also submit the name of at least one
individual to be contacted in the event of illness or death.
   (b)   Secondary Lessee.
      (1)   Shall be minimum age 57.
      (2)   Initial residency requirements do not apply to secondary lessees,
when a party to the primary lessee’s original lease; otherwise, the initial
residency requirements apply.
   (c)   Additional Resident.
      (1)   An additional resident is not a primary or secondary lessee and has
not signed the lease.
      (2)   If the primary or secondary lessee dies, an additional resident
that is said lessee’s surviving spouse shall be entitled to an assignment of
the lease at the rental rate in effect at the time of assignment.
      (3)   If primary or secondary lessee dies, an additional resident that is
not a surviving spouse has no rights in the lease and will be required to
vacate the premises within sixty days, contingent upon receipt of rent.
      (4)   Lessee is required to notify City of an additional resident within
ten days of inhabiting the premises.
      (5)   Additional resident must be minimum age of 57, unless spouse.
   (d)   Guests. 
      (1)   Lessees shall be permitted to have guests staying for a period not
to exceed 14 days within 60 consecutive days.
         (Ord. 2004-19.  Passed 4-27-04; Ord. 2009-51.  Passed 10-27-09.)
   (e)   No Smoking.
      (1)   No tenant or guest of a tenant or other individual in the premises
shall be permitted to smoke inside the premises or within 25 feet of the
structure of Golden View Acres, with the exception that smoking is allowed in
clearly designated areas outside the physical premises of Golden View Acres. 
Violation of this rule shall authorize the management of Golden View Acres to
cause the tenancy to be terminated and the tenants to be removed from the
premises.
(Ord. 2013-26.  Passed 5-14-13.)
   917.02  RENTAL AGREEMENT.
   Each lessee occupying Golden View Acres shall sign a rental agreement, which
provides for the following items:
   (a)   The monthly rental rates for lessees who move into Golden View Acres
shall be determined by the Safety Service Director, or his authorized designee
based upon the costs and expenses associated with the operation and maintenance
of The Sharonville Golden View Acres.  Such rental rates shall be established
such that they shall cover the cost of maintenance, capital improvements,
operating expenses and long term borrowing costs with no additional profit to
be generated by the City of Sharonville in connection with the operation of the
Golden View Acres facility.  Once a lessee occupies a unit at Golden View
Acres, his or her rent shall not be altered during his or her entire lifetime. 
The Safety Service Director shall also establish appropriate penalties for late
payments.  The rental rates established by the Safety Service Director shall be
renewed and reevaluated on an annual basis by the Safety Service Director.
   (b)   An initial security deposit equal to one month’s rent shall be
required.
   (c)   If a lessee wishes to move to another apartment, a new rental
agreement shall be executed for rent at the then current rate and subject to
the waiting list requirements provided for.  The balance from the former
security deposit can be applied towards the new security deposit.
   (d)   The maximum number of occupants shall be two persons for a one-bedroom
apartment, and three persons for a two-bedroom apartment.  This limitation is
inclusive of guests.
   (e)   If an additional resident is added to rental unit, the primary lessee
shall pay an additional monthly sum and security deposit for as long as the
additional resident lives there unless the additional resident is the spouse of
the primary lessee.
   (f)   The additional resident may, individually, register for the waiting
list and, if they become eligible for a lease, may sign a joint lease with the
primary or secondary lessee at the rental rate in effect at the time of
signing.
   (g)   Pets shall be permitted at Golden View Acres pursuant to the
administrative regulations provided by the Safety Service Director and his
authorized designees pursuant to the provisions of Section
917.04.  Guests will not be permitted to bring pets.
   (h)   Adequate provision shall be made for termination of a lease.  At least
thirty days’ written notice shall be required of the lessee before terminating
a lease.  In addition, the rental agreement shall provide for automatic
termination upon default by the lessee of any of the material obligations of
the lessee, the death of all lessees occupying one unit, and abandonment of the
premises and shall result in the loss of the security deposit.
   (i)   The agreement shall also obligate the lessee to pay all utility
payments; to faithfully observe all of the rules and regulations of the
premises; and to maintain the premises in the same condition as at the
commencement of the lease, with the exception of reasonable wear and tear.
   (j)   Adequate provision shall be made to permit the City, acting through
its agents, to enter the premises at reasonable times in order to inspect for
fire hazards, to advertise or show the premises, and to regain possession upon
default or abandonment by the lessee.
   (k)   No right to assign or sublet shall be granted to the lessees, except
as stated in Section
917.01(c)(2).
      (Ord. 2013-19.  Passed 4-30-13.)
   (l)   The Rental Agreement shall further provide that no tenant or guest of
tenant or any other individual in Golden View Acres shall be allowed to smoke
inside the premises or within 25 feet of the structure of Golden View Acres,
with the exception that smoking is allowed in clearly designated areas outside
the physical premises of Golden View Acres.  If a lease is terminated by the
management of Golden View Acres as a result of violation of the No Smoking
Rule, then the security deposit to the extent not needed to repair the
premises, shall be returned to the tenant.  The security deposit shall not be
returned if the tenant is removed forcibly by an eviction legal procedure.
      (Ord. 2013-26.  Passed 5-14-13.)
   917.03  FUTURE VACANCIES; WAITING LIST.
   (a)   A waiting list shall be established when any of the following four
categories become filled: one bedroom, first floor; two bedroom, first floor;
one bedroom, second floor; two bedrooms, second floor.  Application for
placement on a waiting list shall require a fifty dollar ($50.00) refundable
application fee.  An application for placement on a waiting list may be
cancelled only by the written request of the applicant.
   (b)   The four waiting lists that are current on July 1, 2004 shall be fixed
in the current listed order.  Additional applicants after the July 1, 2004
established ranking will be added based on their application date.  If an
applicant on a waiting list declines an available lease, they will remain on
said list in their current established order.  All applicants must meet the
eligibility requirements described in Section
917.01 when they apply for the waiting list and when they sign a lease.  In the
event that an applicant on the waiting list dies, the surviving spouse can be
substituted on the same waiting list.  Otherwise, the application fee will be
refunded to the applicant’s estate.
(Ord. 2013-19.  Passed 4-30-19.)
   917.04  DUTIES OF SAFETY-SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   There shall be delegated to the Safety Service Director or to his duly
appointed assistants, all of the following responsibilities:
   (a)   The preparation and execution of the necessary rental agreements.
   (b)   Creation and maintenance of a reasonable set of rules and regulations
that are not inconsistent with this chapter.
   (c)   The establishment of a procedure whereby complaints or grievances may
be resolved.
   (d)   All other things necessary for the operation of the Golden View Acres
facility in the City of Sharonville.
   (e)   The Safety Service Director has the right to modify existing leases,
when appropriate, to conform them to the current policies, as long as such
modifications benefit the lessee.
   (f)   The Safety Service Director has the right to offer credits and refunds
to the lessee when deemed necessary by the Safety Service Director.
      (Ord. 2004-19.  Passed 4-27-04.)
   (g)   The Safety-Service Director and the management of Golden View Acres
shall designate certain areas outside the physical premises where smoking will
be permitted in such a manner as to not harm the occupants inside the
premises.  These locations shall be clearly marked to permit smoking.  The
Safety-Service Director shall further issue such rules and regulations as are
necessary to prohibit smoking within the premises and within an area of 25 feet
immediately adjacent to the structure of Golden View Acres.
      (Ord. 2013-26.  Passed 5-14-13.)

CHAPTER 1111
Definitions
1111.01   Meaning of words and phrases.
CROSS REFERENCES
         See sectional history for similar State law
         State definitions - see Ohio R.C. 711.001
   1111.01  MEANING OF WORDS AND PHRASES.
   (a)   For the purposes of these Platting and Subdivision Regulations,
certain terms and words are hereby defined as follows:
      (1)    "Alley" means a minor right of way used primarily for vehicular
access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street.
      (2)    "Assurance of completion" means a contract secured by a
performance bond or other guarantee or security satisfactory to Council,
guaranteeing completion of public improvements, which are shown on the
subdivision improvement plan, as the responsibility of the subdivider.
      (3)    "Building setback line" means the line indicating the minimum
horizontal distance between the street line and buildings or any projection
thereof, other than steps or porches.
      (4)    "Crosswalk way" means a right of way used primarily for pedestrian
travel through or across any portion of a block.
      (5)    "Cul-de-sac" means a short minor street having but one opening for
motor traffic, the other being permanently terminated by a vehicular turn-
around.
      (6)    "Easement" means a grant by a property owner of the use, for a
specific purpose or purposes, of a designated strip of land to the general
public, a corporation or other individuals.
      (7)    A.    "Expressway" means a motorway of considerable continuity
designed for a fast uninterrupted flow of vehicular traffic, having a right of
way of varying width, with no direct access from abutting property to express
traffic lanes, and no street crossing or intersection at grade.
         B.    "Expressway, modified" means an expressway whose potential
traffic volume does not justify all of the expressway features.
      (8)   "Lot" means a unit area of land within a subdivision intended for
transfer of ownership or for building development.
      (9)    "Lot, double frontage" means a lot with opposite ends abutting on
streets.
      (10)    "Master Plan" means the comprehensive plan adopted by the
Planning Commission indicating the general location recommended for motorways,
parks and other public open spaces, public building sites, public utilities and
the character and extent of neighborhood and community development.
      (11)    "Motorway" means a principal arterial route designated on the
master plan as an expressway, modified expressway or thoroughfare.
      (12)    "Motorway Plan" means the comprehensive plan adopted by the
Planning Commission indicating the general location for motorways.
      (13)    "Plat of Subdivision" means a map showing the division of any
tract of land into two or more parcels, and prepared for the purpose of
recording. (See Section
1117.03 for the items of information which the Plat normally includes).
      (14)    "Public improvements" means any of the following: roadway
pavement, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, water mains, sanitary and storm sewers and
other appurtenant construction as related to the Subdivision Improvement Plan.
      (15)    "Protective covenant" means a restriction on the use of private
property within a subdivision for the purpose of providing mutual protection
against undesirable aspects of development.
      (16)    "Right of way" means the entire strip of land lying between the
property lines of a street or other motorway, alley, crosswalk or easement.
      (17)    "Street" means a right of way designed for vehicular and
pedestrian traffic, regardless of its designation by name, such as street,
avenue, lane, place or the like.
      (18)    "Street, important neighborhood" means a street designed to serve
as an important trafficway for a neighborhood or as a feeder to a thoroughfare.
The determination of such street classification in any specific instance shall
rest within the Planning Commission.
      (19)    "Street, minor" means any street other than an expressway,
modified expressway, thoroughfare or important neighborhood street.
      (20)    "Subdivision" means:
         A.    The division of any parcel of land shown as a unit or as
contiguous units on the last proceeding tax roll, into two or more parcels,
sites or lots, any one of which is less than five acres, for the purpose,
whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership; provided, however, that
the division or partition of land into parcels of more than five acres not
involving any new streets or easements of access, and the sale or exchange of
parcels between adjoining lot owners, where such sale or exchange does not
create additional building sites, shall be exempted; or
         B.    The improvement of one or more parcels of land for residential,
commercial or industrial structures or groups of structures involving the
division or allocationof land for the opening, widening or extension of any
street or streets, except private streets serving industrial structures; the
division or allocation of land as open spaces for common use by owners,
occupants or lease holders or as easements for the extension and maintenance of
public sewer, water, storm drainage or other public utilities. (ORC 711.001)
      (21)    "Subdivision Improvement Plan" means a drawing showing a proposed
subdivision of land together with the public improvements which are to be
installed therein. Such drawing is not recordable. (See Section
1115.04 for the items of information which the Plan normally includes).
      (22)    "Thoroughfare" means a street of considerable continuity designed
as a major trafficway and designated as such in the Master Plan. This category
does not include an expressway or modified expressway.
      (23)    "Zoning" means regulation by districts of the height, area and
use of buildings, use of land and density of population.
      (24)    "Platting and Subdivision Regulations" means the provisions
contained in
Title Three of this Planning and Zoning Code.
         (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
CHAPTER 1113
Approval Without Plat; Variances; Charges

      Inspection and testing of physical improvements - see P. & Z. 
1119.05
   1113.01  APPROVAL BY PLANNING AUTHORITY WITHOUT A PLAT.
   (a)    A proposed division of a parcel of land along an existing public
street, not involving the opening, widening or extension of any street or road,
and involving no more than five lots after the original tract has been
completely subdivided, may be submitted to a representative designated by the
Planning Commission for the purpose of reviewing such proposed division for
approval without plat. If such representative is satisfied that such proposed
division is not contrary to applicable platting, subdividing or zoning
regulations, he shall within seven working days after submission approve such
proposed division, and, on presentation of a conveyance of such parcel, stamp
the same "Approved by the Sharonville Planning Commission; no plat required"
and have it signed by the Planning Commission Clerk, Secretary, or other
official as may be designated by it. Such representative may require the
submission of a sketch and such other information as is pertinent to his
determination hereunder. (ORC 711.131)
   (b)    Plats for subdivision will not be required for subdivisions as
defined in Section
1111.01(a)(20) or for subdivisions not involving the opening or extension of
any street or easement of access and in which past subdivision and development
has proceeded so far that the preparation and recording of a plat would serve
no public or planning purpose. The representative authorized to approve
conveyances without a plat under the authority of subsection (a) above shall
likewise be authorized to approve conveyances without a plat in such cases as
are excepted herein. In case of doubt, such representative may refer the
question to the Planning Commission. If such representative refuses approval
for a subdivision without a plat, the applicant may appeal to the Planning
Commission.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1113.02  VARIANCES.
   (a)    Hardship. Where the Planning Commission finds that extraordinary
hardships may result from strict compliance with these Platting and Subdivision
Regulations, it may vary the standards or requirements so that substantial
justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that such
variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of the
Master Plan or these Regulations.
   (b)    Conditions. In granting variances and modifications, the Planning
Commission shall require such additional conditions as will, in its judgment,
secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied
or modified.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1113.03  CHARGES FOR PLAN REVIEW, FIELD ENGINEERING AND INSPECTION.
   (a)    Reimbursement Required. For any private improvement project plan
check or review of the engineering details of water mains, drainage structures
and/or sewers, and also for any field engineering and/or inspection and testing
services, the developer shall reimburse the Municipality, based on the actual
time, at the then current rates of pay or salaries and the then current rates
of actual charges for the inspection and/or testing of materials. Payment for
these items shall be made by the developer or his agent upon the presentation
of a bill for such services as rendered by the Municipality.
   (b)    Plan Review and Testing. In the instance of plan review of water
mains, draining structures or sewers, a bill shall be presented and must be
paid prior to approval of the tentative approved Improvement Plan.
   In the instance of testing services for materials used for construction of
drainage structures and/or storm sewers, a bill shall be presented and paid for
such services, prior to final acceptance and approval of such drainage
structures and/or sewers.
   (c)    Improvement Estimate, Application and Charges. At the time of
completion of the Improvement Plan review and at the time of approval, a
preliminary estimate will be made for the proposed construction work involved
for water mains, sanitary sewers and appurtenances. Based upon this estimate
the developer or his agent shall, upon forms furnished by the Municipality,
make request for permission from the Municipality, to construct at his own
expense the approved drainage structures, sewers and/or water lines, together
with the necessary appurtenances thereto in the development. He shall describe
the improvement and shall further agree that all of the work is to be performed
in accordance with the plans, specifications and estimate on file in the office
of the Municipal Engineer.  He further shall agree to pay for all inspection at
the then current rates of pay for inspectors, plus the inspection or testing of
materials used. He shall further agree to hold the Municipality free and
harmless from any and all damages or anything which might arise from the
construction of the requested permission for the improvement.
   All of the foregoing charges and items shall be paid before final approval
for acceptance will be made for dedication and recording of such development or
improvement.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
CHAPTER 1115
Subdivision Improvement Plan
1115.01   Purpose; preparation by qualified technician.
1115.02   Charges for Plan review.
1115.03   Engineering features not to be changed.
1115.04   Required information.
1115.05   Vicinity sketch to accompany Plan.
1115.06   Shade trees.
CROSS REFERENCES
      State registration of engineers and surveyors - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4733
      Subdivision Improvement Plan defined - see P. & Z.
1111.01(a)(21)
      Central provisions for plats or plans - see P. & Z.
1117.01
      Required information on Plat of Subdivision - see P. & Z.
1117.03
      Responsibility of public improvements - see P. & Z.
1119.04
      Injury or destruction of trees - see GEN. OFF.
541.06
   1115.01  PURPOSE; PREPARATION BY QUALIFIED TECHNICIAN.
   The Subdivision Improvement Plan is intended to precede and supplement the
Plat of Subdivision which is to be recorded. Its purpose is to show all facts
needed to enable the Planning Commission and the administrative officers of the
Municipality or the County to determine whether the proposed layout of land in
question and the proposed public improvements are satisfactory from the
standpoint of the public interest. The Subdivision Improvement Plan must be
made by a qualified technician, trained in the layout of subdivisions. All
required engineering and surveying work must be performed by and under the
supervision of a registered engineer or surveyor, as the case may be, who is
registered in accordance with the provisions of the Engineers and Surveyors
Registration Act of the Ohio Revised Code. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1115.02  CHARGES FOR PLAN REVIEW.
   The Improvement Plan shall be reviewed for engineering features by the
Municipal Engineer or his agent. A charge shall be made for this review based
on the actual time and current rates and salaries.
   The engineer, whose seal appears on the Improvement Plan, shall be billed
for the review at the time the marked copy is sent to him for correction of his
tracing. The bill must be paid before or at the time he returns the three
prints of the corrected tracing to the Municipal Engineer.
   Failure to pay the bill for review at this time will stop all processing of
the Subdivision Plat or Improvement Plan.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1115.03  ENGINEERING FEATURES NOT TO BE CHANGED.
   After approval of the Improvement Plan, no change in engineering features
will be permitted until such changes have been approved by the Municipal
Engineer.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1115.04  REQUIRED INFORMATION.
   The following graphic and descriptive items shall normally be required to be
shown on the Subdivision Improvement Plan:
   (a)    Items Pertaining to the Title.
      (1)    Proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate or too
closely approximate, phonetically, the name of any other subdivision in
Hamilton County.
      (2)    Location by section, township, range, county, state.
      (3)    Names and addresses of the owner, developer, technician who made
the Plan, and engineer responsible for the engineering details.
      (4)    Scale of the plan at any of the following: 1 inch = 60, 50, 40, 30
or 20 feet.
      (5)    Date.
      (6)    North point.
   (b)    Existing Items Pertaining to the Plan.
      (1)    Boundary of the proposed subdivision accurately indicated by a
heavy, solid line, and the acreage comprised therein.
      (2)    Location, widths and names of all existing or platted streets or
other public ways, railroad and utility rights of way, parks and other public
open spaces, permanent buildings, section and corporation lines, within or
adjacent to the tract.
      (3)    Existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground items
within the tract or immediately adjacent thereto, with pipe sizes, grades and
locations indicated.
      (4)    Names of adjacent subdivisions and owners of adjoining parcels of
unsubdivided land shall be shown by dotted lines.
      (5)    Zoning districts, if any.
      (6)    Existing contours with intervals of not more than five feet.
Elevations shall be based on sea level datum.
      (7)    Drainage channels, and any other significant physical items.
      (8)    Description of bench mark used.
   (c)    Items Pertaining to the Proposed Development.
      (1)    Layout of streets, including names and widths of proposed streets,
and widths of alleys, crosswalks and easements. Proposed street names shall not
too closely approximate, phonetically, the name of any other street in Hamilton
County.
      (2)    Layout, numbers and the approximate dimensions of lots.
      (3)    Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved
for public use, or to be reserved by deed covenant for use of all property
owners in the subdivision, and the conditions, if any, of such dedication or
reservation.
      (4)    Typical cross-sections (or half-sections) at the scale not smaller
than one- fourth inch equals one foot, showing widths of roadways, and location
and widths of sidewalks. Where considerable cut and fill are involved, or
wherever grading will affect adjacent properties, several actual cross-sections
showing proposed grading may be required, and their locations indicated on the
Plan.
      (5)    Profile of each street, with tentative grades including adequate
extension where necessary beyond the subdivision boundaries, and including any
proposed sewer lines and manholes. Scale: Horizontal, same as plan; Vertical, 1
inch = 10 feet.
      (6)    Plan and profiles of proposed sanitary, storm water, or combined
sewers, with grades and pipe sizes. These shall include connections to outlets
which might be beyond boundaries of subdivision. (Subparagraphs (5) and (6)
hereof may be shown on a separate drawing.)
      (7)    Statement that water mains and appurtenances shall be installed in
accordance with the rules and regulations and under the supervision of the
agency supplying water to the subdivision.
      (8)    Building setback lines, shown graphically along all streets, with
dimensions. This requirement is applicable wherever there are no zoning
provisions or wherever such setbacks are greater than those required by
prevailing zoning.
      (9)    Indication of any lots on which a use other than residential is
proposed by the developer.
      (10)    A detailed section of the proposed streets.
      (11)    The streets delineated in Plan, showing radii, functions of
curves, etc.
      (12)    Existing ground profile and proposed grades. Where a street ends
at a subdivision property line the profile shall be shown for 200 feet beyond
the subdivision property line.
      (13)    All necessary proposed sewers and other necessary drainage
structures shall be shown in Plan and profile. Water lines shall be shown in
Plan or covered by a note which states the manner in which the water lines and
appurtenances shall be designed and determined.
      (14)    A statement that all work shall be done under the supervision of
the Municipal Engineer and in accordance with the Sharonville Platting and
Subdivision Regulations. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
      (15)    Electrical Requirements. Unless waived by the Planning
Commission, the developer shall be required to provide underground electrical
service, plans and agreements as indicated hereinafter prior to subdivision
improvement plan approval.
         A.    Definitions.
            1.    "Facilities" mean wires, cables, transformers and
appurtenances;
            2.    "Developer" includes any owner, builder or developer;
            3.    "Electric distribution facilities" include only those
distribution facilities serving homes in subdivisions of the kind described
above, and does not include distribution or transmission facilities which
deliver power through such subdivisions or transmission facilities which
terminate in such subdivisions;
            4.    "New" residential subdivisions mentioned in this subparagraph
means such subdivisions built after the effective date of this subparagraph
(Ordinance 70-59, passed February 9, 1971),
            5.    "The Company" means The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company. 
         B.    In all new residential subdivisions containing two or more
contiguous lots:
            1.    The Company shall install the electric distribution
facilities and facilities for street lighting, serving such subdivisions
underground within or along the right of way of existing or proposed public
streets, provided, prior to installation of such facilities, the developer pays
the Company therefor in accordance with the Company's schedule and gives the
Company a written commitment to pay the Company for the cost of any relocation
of such facilities and to provide all easements necessary for relocation and
for any extension;
            2.    The developer shall provide necessary easements to the
Company at no cost to the Company;
            3.    All service lines connecting the ultimate customer's service
entrance equipment to the Company's main line facilities shall be installed by
the developer, at the developer's cost, to a point determined by the Company,
the actual connection at the Company's main line to be made by the Company;
            4.    The Company is permitted to install pad-mounted transformers,
and nothing in this subparagraph shall be construed as requiring the
installation of underground transformers, except on payment of an additional
charge therefor in accordance with the Company's schedule; and
            5.    Prior to the paving of any street, the developer, at his
cost, shall install conduit crossovers for electric facilities as specified by
the Company.
         C.    This subparagraph shall not be construed to prohibit the
installation or maintenance of street lighting poles or standards or to require
the undergrounding of existing overhead or other electric facilities.
            (Ord. 70-59. Passed 2-9-71.)
      (16)    All new subdivision improvement plans shall show all easements
reserved for the proper development of the subdivision which relate to any and
all utility improvements thereafter installed together with street lighting
plans, pole locations and connecting circuits for power relating thereto. (Ord.
70-60. Passed 2-9-71.)
   1115.05  VICINITY SKETCH TO ACCOMPANY PLAN.
   A vicinity sketch, at legible scale, showing relation of the proposed
development to its general surroundings, shall accompany the Subdivision
Improvement Plan. Proposed streets on the Plan shall be shown, with connections
to existing or proposed streets and alleys in neighboring subdivisions. In case
the Plan forms only a part of an ownership holding, all of the latter shall be
shown, with a tentative street layout for the remainder of the tract shown by
dotted lines.  (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1115.06  SHADE TREES.
   The Planning Commission is hereby authorized to require, restrict or
regulate the planting of trees within a public way, street or alley in any new
subdivision, prior to acceptance thereof by the Planning Commission. The
Planning Commission may require any and all such restrictions or regulations to
be made a part of the recorded plat for any and all new subdivision plats
presented for approval to such Planning Commission.
(Ord. 67-36. Passed 4-11-67.)

1119.03
   1117.01  GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR PLATS OR PLANS.
   All plats or plans submitted for study and containing engineering features
must show the seal and signature of a registered engineer eligible to practice
in the State.
   All elevations shall be referenced to sea level datum, and each plat shall
show the description and elevation of the bench mark used for the subdivision
survey which shall be referenced to the Hamilton County bench mark system.
   The plan for street improvements in the subdivision shall show the stations
and angles to all intersecting streets and turnarounds. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-
14-60.)
   1117.02  PLAT SUBMISSION AND APPROVAL.
   No subdivision as defined in Section
1111.01(a)(20) shall be made of land within the jurisdiction of the Planning
Commission without preparation of a record Plat of Subdivision in accordance
with the provisions of these Platting and Subdivision Regulations except as
exempted from such platting by Section
1113.01.
   The Plat of Subdivision is the official record plat. It may be submitted
concurrently with the Subdivision Improvement Plan or at any time within three
years following the Planning Commission's authorization to proceed under the
provisions of the Subdivision Improvement Plan.
   The Plat of Subdivision shall not be approved by the Planning Commission
prior to the completion or assurance of completion of all public improvements
in accordance with the Subdivision Improvement Plan.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1117.03  REQUIRED INFORMATION.
   The following items shall normally be required to be shown on a Plat of
Subdivision:
   (a)    Items Pertaining to the Title.
      (1)    Name of subdivision.
      (2)    Location by section, township, range, county, state.
      (3)    Names and addresses of owner and engineer.
      (4)    Scale not smaller than 1 inch = 50 feet.
      (5)    Date.
      (6)    North point.
   (b)    Items Pertaining to the Plat.
      (1)    Boundary to the Plat, with accurate distances and bearings, and
its acreage.
      (2)    Exact location and width of all streets, alleys and crosswalk ways
within and adjoining the Plat.
      (3)    Bearings and distances to the nearest established street lines,
political subdivision boundaries, section or patent corners or other official
monuments.
      (4)    Names of streets and alleys within and adjoining the Plat. The
names of new streets shall not duplicate or too closely approximate
phonetically the name of any other street in Hamilton County.
      (5)    Lengths of all arcs, radii, internal angles, points of curvature
and tangent bearings.
      (6)    All easements for rights of way provided for public services or
utilities and any limitations of such easements.
      (7)    All lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and
hundredths, and with bearings or angles related to street and alley or
crosswalk lines.
      (8)    An accurate description of location, material and size of all
monuments of which there shall be not less than three.
      (9)    Accurate outlines of any areas to be dedicated for public use,
with the purpose indicated thereon, and of any area to be reserved by deed
covenant for common use of all property owners in the subdivision.
      (10)    Building setback lines, shown graphically along all streets, with
dimensions. This requirement is applicable wherever there are no zoning
provisions or wherever such setbacks are greater than those required by
prevailing zoning.
      (11)    Notation regarding protective covenants, if any are to be
incorporated in deeds.
      (12)    Certification by a registered, professional civil engineer or
surveyor to the effect that the Plat represents a survey made and closed by him
and that all the monuments shown thereon actually exist, and that their
location, size and material are correctly shown.
      (13)    A signed and notarized certification by the owner or owners, of
his or their adoption of the Plat, and dedication of streets, easements and any
other public areas.
      (14)    Notation giving deed reference of last transfer of title to owner
making dedication.
      (15)    Description of restrictions on sewer easements, if such easements
are involved.
      (16)   Space for statement of approval by the Planning Commission with
lines for signature and date.
      (17)    Space for statement of acceptance of land dedicated by the owner
for streets or other public areas with lines for signature and date.
      (18)    Where physical improvements are not complete, a note to the
effect that streets and crosswalk ways dedicated by this Plat are not accepted
for public use and will not be so accepted until all physical improvements are
completed according to the authorized Subdivision Improvement Plan and/or
revisions thereto, on file in the office of the Planning Commission. (Ord. 60-
11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1117.04  PLATTING ON COUNTY TAX MAPS; CLOSURES AND REFERENCE POINTS.
   No Plat of Subdivision will be accepted for platting on the Auditor's tax
maps which does not comply with the following rules:
   (a)   Closure Calculation. Any Plat of Subdivision, submitted to the County
Auditor for platting on the tax maps of Hamilton County by the County Engineer,
shall have attached thereto a copy of the closure calculations of the perimeter
or boundary of such subdivision on forms supplied by the County Engineer. This
closure calculation shall show the courses and distances around the perimeter
or boundary of the subdivision, the northings, southings, eastings and westings
of such courses and distances and the individual sums of their closures east
and west and north and south. The Plat shall also bear the seal and signature
of a registered surveyor eligible to practice within the State. All irregularly
shaped lots shall have positive courses and distances shown on the boundaries
of such lots. All irregularly shaped lots shall have a closure error of not
more than one in 3,000.
   (b)    Reference Points. All conveyances submitted to the Hamilton County
Auditor for platting on the tax maps by the County Engineer shall contain
sufficient description or dimensions so that the area described can be platted
and surveyed, and shall be referenced or tied in to some well established and
recorded point or monument as stated below.
   All subdivision plats shall be referenced or tied in to one or more of the
following:
      (1)    A corner of a lot in a recorded subdivision.
      (2)    A corner of a recorded subdivision.
      (3)    The definite intersection of two intersecting dedicated and
accepted or established streets or roads.
      (4)    A section corner, a patent corner of a military survey or a
quarter section corner.
      (5)    The intersection of a section line, a patent line of a military
survey or half section line with a dedicated and accepted or established street
or road.
      (6)    The intersection of a dedicated and accepted or established street
and a lot line of a recorded subdivision.
         (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1117.05  CORNERSTONES, MARKERS AND PINS.
   For the purpose of this section, the term “corner” shall be considered any
change in direction of a property line.  Curved property lines may be exempt
from placement of permanent markers at all corners as determined by the
Planning Commission.   
   (a)   When and Where Required.  At the time of surveying and laying out a
subdivision, as defined in Chapter
1111 Definitions, the proprietor or developer of such subdivision shall direct
the surveyor to place and set at least four permanent markers, one such marker
to be located at each corner along the perimeter of the subdivision. 
Additionally, one such marker shall be placed at all corners of each interior
lot.  All permanent markers shall be placed in a manner so that the line of
sight between such markers can be observed from one marker to the other.
If the location for a permanent marker is originally determined to be in an
area of solid rock it may be relocated and offset from its original position. 
Such relocation must be noted on the plat.
   (b)   Type of Cornerstones, Markers, and Pins Required.  All permanent
markers shall be made of either stone or concrete at least four inches in
diameter, or four inches square, and properly marked.  The markings on such
markers shall consist of a cross cut with the legs of the cross at least three
inches long and at least one-eighth inch deep.  All stone and concrete markers
shall be at least thirty inches long and the bottom of such markers shall be
set at least thirty inches below finished grade.
   (c)   Designation on Plat.  All permanent markers shall be clearly
designated on the plat before it is presented to the Planning Commission for
approval.
      (Ord. 2006-3.  Passed 2-28-06.)

   EDITOR'S NOTE: Sanitary sewer construction, maintenance, repair and

1117.03
   1119.01  POSTING BOND IN LIEU OF ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION.
   In lieu of actual construction of the physical improvements, the subdivider
may assure completion of construction by furnishing a performance bond or other
guarantee or security, to the satisfaction of and in favor of Council, in an
amount equal to the Municipal Engineer's estimate of the cost of the
construction of the physical improvements within the portion of the subdivision
submitted for recording, which shall include outlet sewer and water supply
where available. Actual construction shall be as shown on the Improvement Plan
and in accordance with these Platting and Subdivision Regulations. (Ord. 60-11.
Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.02  APPLICATION TO CONSTRUCT; PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE.
   The developer(s) and/or owner(s) and his (their) contractors shall, before
any construction may start, sign an application for a permit to construct the
physical improvements as shown on the Subdivision Improvement Plan. This
application may be written to apply to sections and/or blocks of the entire
Subdivision Improvement Plan as such sections and/or blocks are constructed.
The form of application shall contain the following:
   The undersigned agrees to do all the work in accordance with the Sharonville
Platting and Subdivision Regulations and Amendments thereto in effect on the
date of approval of the Subdivision Improvement Plan and further agrees that at
the end of one (1) year after completion and acceptance of the improvements, he
will correct any defects which in the opinion of the Municipal Engineer are due
to inferior workmanship, defective materials or the settlement of the
foundation.
                     ______________________________
                     Developer(s) and/or Owner(s)
                     _______________________________
                     Address
                     ________________________________
                     Contractor(s)
                     ________________________________
                     Address
   
   Forms may be obtained at the office of the Building Official.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1119.03  PLATTED MONUMENTS TO BE PLACED.
   Improvements shall not be accepted until the Municipal Engineer has verified
in the field, that monuments, shown on the plat and certified by the surveyor
and/or engineer, have been placed. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.04  RESPONSIBILITY OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS.
   All public improvements shown on the Subdivision Plan are the responsibility
of the subdivider, unless otherwise expressly indicated and shall be installed
in accordance with these Platting and Subdivision Regulations. (Ord. 60-11.
Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.05  INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   The developer, his engineer or his contractor, shall give notice to the
Municipal Engineer at least twenty-four hours in advance of any construction of
physical public improvements, including grading of such public improvements, in
order that an inspector may be assigned. The contractor shall be billed for all
inspections at the currently prevailing rate for inspectors.
   All necessary testing of materials will be done by a testing laboratory at
no cost to the Municipality. It is customary for the contractor to be billed by
the testing laboratory for any testing of materials incorporated in the paving.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.06  SEWER AND WATER LINES TO BE INSTALLED PRIOR TO PAVING.
   Sewer and water line house connections or crossovers shall be installed
before the paving of the streets, unless written permission has been obtained
from the Municipal Engineer to do otherwise. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.07  STREET CONFORMITY TO MASTER PLAN; DEDICATION AND ACQUISITION.
   All streets shall have concrete combined curbs and gutters and shall conform
substantially to the Master Plan adopted by the Planning Commission and any
revisions or amendments thereto. Whenever a tract to be subdivided includes any
part of a street indicated as a thoroughfare in the Master Plan, such part of
the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider, except as provided below. This
required dedication shall also apply to the widening of existing bordering
streets except in cases where the proposed subdivision is limited to a tier of
lots fronting on such bordering street and where the subdivider owns or
controls no adjoining land beyond the rear line of such tier of lots. In no
case shall the required dedication exceed forty feet in width as measured from
the center line of the bordering street. If a thoroughfare within a proposed
subdivision has a recommended width in excess of eighty feet, the Planning
Commission shall recommend to Council that such additional width be acquired by
the Municipality by purchase or appropriation proceedings. If within a maximum
of ninety days thereafter, Council has not indicated its intention or
proceeding with such acquisition, either by passage of a resolution agreeing to
purchase such property at a price agreed to by the subdivider and Council, or
by the passage of a resolution declaring its intent to appropriate such
property to a public use, then the recommendation by the Planning Commission
for a width in excess of eighty feet shall not be used as grounds for
disapproval of either the Subdivision Improvement Plan or the Plat of
Subdivision. Whenever a tract to be subdivided includes any part of an
expressway or modified expressway wherein the right of access is denied the
subdivider, then the Planning Commission shall recommend to Council that the
right of way for such expressway or modified expressway be acquired by the
Municipality by purchase or appropriation proceedings. If within a maximum of
six months thereafter, Council has not indicated its intention of proceeding
with such acquisition, either by passage of a resolution agreeing to purchase
such property at a price agreed to by the subdivider and Council, or by the
passage of a resolution declaring its intent to appropriate such property to
public use, then the recommendation by the Planning Commission for such right
of way shall not be used as a ground for disapproval of either the Subdivision
Improvement Plan or the Plat of Subdivision.
   In the case of either a thoroughfare in excess of eighty feet or an
expressway or modified expressway, if Council advises the Planning Commission
prior to the maximum time limits set out above that it has no intention of
proceeding with the desired acquisition, then the Planning Commission shall
consider a design for the subdivision which does not deny the immediate lawful
use of the property within such proposed right of way, but recognizes a
possible future acquisition of such right of way and provides accordingly for a
minimum degree of resultant disruption to the remaining streets and lots of the
subdivision.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.08  STREET DESIGN STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)    Neighborhood Plan. If a tentative plan has been prepared by the
Planning Commission for the neighborhood of the proposed subdivision, the
street system of the latter shall conform in general thereto.
   (b)    Physical Features. Streets shall be platted with appropriate regard
for topography, creeks, wooded areas and other natural features which would
enhance attractive development.
   (c)    Continuation of Existing Streets. Existing streets, constructed or
recorded in adjoining territory shall be continued at equal or greater width
and in similar alignment in the proposed subdivision, unless variations are
recommended by the Planning Commission.
   (d)    Ease of Circulation. The street pattern shall provide ease of
circulation within the subdivision as well as convenient access to adjoining
streets, thoroughfares or unsubdivided land, as may be required by the Planning
Commission. Minor residential streets should be so planned as to discourage
their use by nonlocal traffic. Where a street will eventually be extended
beyond the Plat but is temporarily dead-ended, an interim turnaround may be
required.
   (e)    Access to Modified Expressway. If a new subdivision involves frontage
on a modified expressway, the street layout should be planned to avoid, as far
as possible, any private residential driveways from having direct access to
such modified expressway. In such cases, access should be provided by means of
a service roadway with motor access at suitably spaced points.
   (f)    Unsubdivided Portion of Tract. If the Plat to be submitted includes
only part of the tract owned by the subdivider, the Planning Commission may
require a sketch of a tentative future street system for the unsubdivided
portion.
   (g)    Half-streets. The street layout shall be planned to avoid half-
streets, if possible. Where there exists a dedicated or platted half-street
adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, the other half shall be platted if
deemed necessary by the Planning Commission.
   (h)    Intersections. Streets shall intersect as nearly at right angles as
possible.
   At the intersection of two streets, property line corners shall be rounded
by an arc of twelve and one-half foot radius.
   All intersecting streets shall have a minimum curb or edge of paving radius
of twenty-five feet.
   The minimum radius, noted above, shall be increased when the smallest angle
of intersection is less than sixty degrees, or in any case where the Planning
Commission considers an increase necessary.
   (i)   Alleys. Except where justified by special conditions, alleys shall not
be approved in residential areas. At an intersection of alleys, a five foot
chord shall cut off each corner. Dead-end alleys are prohibited.
   (j)   Cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs shall not be longer than 800 feet, unless
necessitated by topography or other circumstances beyond the subdivider's
control.
   Where a proposed street ends in a cul-de-sac, a "T" or ball-shaped turn-
around may be acceptable. If a ball-shaped turn-around is proposed, the minimum
curb radius shall be twenty-seven and one-half feet. If a "T" is proposed, the
minimum radius shall be twenty-five feet.
   (k)    Minimum Right of Way Widths.
      (1)    Expressways, modified expressways and thoroughfares as indicated
by the adopted Motorway Plan.
      (2)    Important neighborhood streets, County roads and State roads if
not part of the adopted Motorway Plan: sixty feet. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-
60.)
      (3)    Minor streets: sixty feet. All cul-de-sacs shall terminate in a
circular area with a minimum diameter of eighty feet, unless the Planning
Commission approves a "T" or "Y" type of turning facility.
         (Ord. 68-6. Passed 2-27-68.)
      (4)    Alleys: twenty feet.
      (5)    Crosswalk ways: ten feet.
      (6)    Easements: four feet on each side of the designated center line,
or such width as may be required for necessary maintenance of utility involved.
   (l)    Minimum Pavement Widths. The limits of any proposed pavement shall be
clearly indicated and all streets including side streets and alleys shall be
paved within the limits of the subdivision. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
      (1)    All streets: twenty-nine feet without curb, or thirty feet back to
back of curb where curb or combined concrete curb and gutter are used.
         (Ord. 68-6. Passed 2-27-68.)
      (2)    In case of a thoroughfare or important neighborhood street, the
matter of additional pavement width shall be discussed with the public
officials having jurisdiction, to determine whether or not public expenditures,
if any, for such additional width shall be made simultaneously with the
developer's improvement.
      (3)    Cul-de-sac streets shall terminate in a paved turn-around with a
minimum outside radius of twenty-seven and one-half feet. If a "T" or "Y"
shaped arrangement is approved by the Planning Commission in lieu of a turn-
around, such paved space shall extend the entire width of the right of way, and
shall be at least twelve and one-half feet wide, with the flared portions
rounded by at least a twelve and one-half foot radii.
      (4)    Alleys: twenty feet.
      (5)    Sidewalks at least four feet wide, and normally one foot from the
property line, crosswalks the same width, in the center of crosswalk ways.
   (m)    Vertical and Horizontal Alignment.
      (1)    Vertical. For thoroughfares and important neighborhood streets
profile grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length,
measured horizontally, equivalent to fifteen times the algebraic difference
between the rates of grade, expressed in feet per hundred. For minor streets
and alleys, one-half that minimum.
      (2)    Horizontal - Radii of centerline curvature:
         A.    Thoroughfares: 500 feet.
         B.    Important neighborhood streets: 200 feet.
         C.    Minor streets: 100 feet.
   There shall be a tangent between reverse curves of at least 100 feet,
wherever possible. In any case, standards shall be such as to produce
visibility to the satisfaction of the Municipal Engineer. All horizontal curves
shall show the complete functions of such curve and each P.C. (point of
curvature) and P.T. (point of tangent) shall be stationed.
   (n)    Street Name Signs. Street name signs shall be erected by the
developer in accordance with Municipal specifications.
   (o)    Profiles and Grades. All streets, including side streets and alleys
within the limits of the subdivision shall be graded the full width between
street property lines and all roadways shall be paved.
   All proposed grades shall be the centerline grades of the respective streets
and shall be indicated in complete detail in profiles and referenced to the
stationing shown on the Plan.
   The maximum grades shall not exceed six percent for main and secondary
thoroughfares or twelve percent for minor or local service streets and alleys.
The minimum grade of all streets shall be one-half of one percent. Grades
across intersections shall not be in excess of four percent except at the
discretion of the Municipal Engineer. The maximum grade of a crosswalk shall be
twelve percent, unless supplemented by steps.
   All changes in grade shall be connected by vertical curves of minimum length
equal to fifteen times the algebraic difference in rate of grade. The P.C. and
P.T. of all vertical curves shall be stationed and elevations shall be shown at
least every twenty-five feet within the limits of vertical curves.
   (p)    Construction and Standard Drawings; Typical Sections. All streets
shall have concrete combined curbs and gutters and shall be constructed in
accordance with the State of Ohio, Department of Highways, Construction and
Materials Specifications, including amendments thereto, in effect on the date
of approval of the Improvement Plan.
   Standard pavement drawings shall be either Ohio State Highway standards or
Hamilton County standards, all of which are on file in the office of the
Municipal Engineer and are titled "Typical Sections of Streets Required for
Subdivisions". Typical sections shall be drawn in accordance with Types 1, 2, 3
or 4 of the standard pavement drawings.
   Combined roll type concrete curb and gutter shall be thirty inches wide from
back of curb to inside edge of gutter, and of Class "D" mix concrete. The
entire right of way of all streets shall be graded the full width between
property lines with appropriate slopes for cuts and fills beyond property
lines. Proof of necessary right of way shall be required.
   The street may be Type 2 (reinforced concrete), or, if Type 1, 3 or 4, all
ditches shall be backfilled with gravel.
   (q)    Joints in Concrete Pavement. These provisions shall apply to
reinforced (T-71) and nonreinforced (T-70) pavement.
      (1)    One inch nonextruding expansion joint (Type A or B Dowel Bar Unit)
shall be installed in the pavement on each side of all intersections in
accordance with the standard pavement drawings. Expansion joints shall be
placed not farther than 600 feet apart.
      (2)    Transverse false (dummy) joints shall be constructed every fifteen
feet. Transverse joints between pours shall be standard key joints or standard
construction joints.
      (3)    Longitudinal joints between pours shall be standard key joints.
      (4)    All joints shall be thoroughly cleaned and sealed in accordance
with the applicable section of Ohio State specifications.
      (5)    All inlets, manholes, valve chambers, etc., shall be boxed or
blocked out in accordance with the standard pavement drawings.
         (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.09  BLOCKS.
   (a)    Length. The normal maximum length for blocks is 1,800 feet. In a
block over 900 feet long a crosswalk way may be required.
   (b)    Width. The width of a block shall normally be sufficient to allow two
tiers of lots of appropriate depth.
   (c)    Irregular Shape. Irregularly shaped blocks, including superblocks,
indented by cul-de-sacs, containing interior parks or playgrounds and adequate
parking spaces, will be acceptable when properly designed and covered by
agreements as to maintenance of such park areas.
   (d)    Orientation on Motorway. If frontage on a motorway is involved, the
long dimension of the block shall preferably front thereon in order to create
as few intersections as possible with the motorway.
   (e)    Business or Industrial.  Blocks intended for business or industry
shall be of such length as may be considered most suitable for their
prospective use, including adequate provision for parking and deliveries. (Ord.
60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.10  LOTS.
   (a)    Size, Shape and Orientation. Size, shape and orientation of lots
shall be appropriate to the location of the proposed subdivision and for the
types of development contemplated.
   (b)    Length and Width Ratio. Excessive length in relation to width shall
be avoided.
   (c)    Fronting on Motorways. Lots fronting on motorways should have extra
depth and deep setbacks, if topography permits.
   (d)    Double Frontage. Double frontage lots shall be avoided as far as
possible.
   (e)    Building Setback Lines. When topographical conditions require that
the septic tank and leaching bed be placed on the front portion of the lot, the
County Health Commissioner shall designate the proper building setback line.
   (f)    Side Lot Lines. Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles
or radial to street lines unless, in the opinion of the Planning Commission, a
variation from this rule will give a better street and lot plan.
   (g)    Corner Lots. Corner lots shall have an extra width sufficient to
allow for building setback lines on both front and side, with thirty percent
less required for the side yard setback. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.11  PUBLIC OPEN SPACES AND SITES.
   Where, as indicated by the Master Plan, a proposed subdivision contains,
wholly or in part, a proposed public open space or a proposed site for a public
building, the Planning Commission will immediately notify the public authority
concerned (Council, Park Board, Board of Education, etc.). If within thirty
days thereafter, the Planning Commission is not advised that such property has
been acquired by negotiation and agreement, or within a second period of thirty
days after such notification that such authority has commenced the necessary
procedure to acquire such property by appropriation, then the Planning
Commission will not require that such open space or site be reserved or
included in the Subdivision Plan.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.12  SIDEWALKS.
   (a)    Sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of all streets and in
all crosswalk ways within all subdivisions. One course cement sidewalks of
Class "C" concrete, four feet wide and five inches thick (seven inches thick
across driveways), shall be constructed where shown on the Plan or typical
section and including all walkways. One-half inch expansion joints shall be
placed at intervals not to exceed 100 feet. Final determination of the
necessity for the construction of sidewalks in any specific instance shall rest
with the Planning Commission.
   (b)    All developers and/or builders in development hereinafter of all
residential lots and business lots shall, at the time of such development,
construct sidewalks thereon in accordance with the specifications set forth in
subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 64-48. Passed 5-12-64.)
   1119.13  UTILITY EASEMENTS OUTSIDE STREET LINES.
   Where utilities are located outside of street right-of-way lines, easements
shall be provided. Easements along rear or side lot lines are preferable where
possible.
(Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.14  WATER MAINS.
   (a)    Location. Proposed new water mains in existing roads or streets shall
generally be located on the north or east side of the existing road or street
outside of the existing or proposed pavement area.
   The layout of a new water main system and appurtenances shall be approved by
the engineers of the agency, who will supply the water to the system, either
directly and/or indirectly through the Hamilton County Sanitary Department.
   (b)    Materials and Installation. All materials used and the installation
of those materials in the line shall be in accordance with the specifications
and charges for inspection of the agency, who will supply the water to the main
and/or the Hamilton County Sanitary Department.
   (c)    Fire Hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be placed at approximately 400-
foot intervals.
   (d)    Control Valves. There shall be four control valves at each cross
intersection and three control valves at each "T" intersection. All main line
control valves shall be housed in a standard brick valve chamber. Fire hydrant
control valves may be housed in a standard valve box.
   (e)    Connection to Existing Mains. Wherever it is possible, proposed mains
shall connect to existing mains. Dead-ends shall not be permitted where it is
possible to obtain a closed circuit to existing mains.
   (f)    Main Size. The size of water mains to be installed in a new system
will be determined by the water supply agency and/or the Municipal Engineer,
and installed in accordance with the City-County water contract.
   (g)    Service Branches. All water service branches from the water mains to
the property line will be installed by the water supply agency and/or its
agent, upon application and payment of the tapping charge.
   (h)    Application for Construction. Upon the approval of a water main plant
showing all of the construction details of design, etc., the Hamilton County
Sanitary Department will make a preliminary estimate of cost of construction
for the water main. The subdivider then shall make a formal request for
permission from the Municipality to construct the water main and appurtenances
at his own cost and expense and in accordance with the plans, specifications,
City-County water contract and estimate on file in the Hamilton County Sanitary
Department. The subdivider shall agree to pay to the Municipality, two percent
of the estimated cost for overhead and maintenance charge. He shall agree in
the request to save the Municipality and all its representatives harmless from
all suits, actions or claims of any character brought on account of any
injuries or damages sustained by any person or property in consequence of any
neglect in safeguarding the work or through the use of unacceptable materials
in the construction of the improvement or on account of act or omission by the
subdivider, or his agents. (Ord. 60-11. Passed 6-14-60.)
   1119.15  GAS MAINS.
   All new gas service branch lines shall have a shut off valve at the property
or curb line.
(Ord. 65-48. Passed 9-14-65.)
   1119.16  UNDERGROUND UTILITY DISTRIBUTION, STREET LIGHTING AND COMMUNICATION
FACILITIES.
   (a)    The developer shall have installed by the respective utility
companies, underground distribution facilities, street lighting facilities and
underground communication distribution facilities in all new residential
subdivisions. In all cases, street lighting facilities shall be included by the
developer.
   (b)    As used herein, "developer" means a person or organization who
submits a subdivision plat or other plat to the Planning Commission and/or
Council for their approval.
   (c)    Underground utilities shall serve the subdivision within or along the
right of way of existing or proposed public streets, provided that prior to
installation of such facilities, the developer pays the utility companies'
schedules and/or associated charges and gives written commitment to pay the
utility company for the cost of any relocation of such facilities and to
provide all easements necessary for relocation and for any extensions. The
developer shall provide necessary easements to the utility companies at no
cost.
   (d)    All service lines connecting the customer's service within the
utility company's underground distribution lines shall be installed underground
to connection points on the distribution facilities determined by the utility
company. The customer's service line shall be installed by the developer or
customer, except for communications service lines. The actual connection to the
utility company's facilities shall be made by the utility company. Underground
electrical wiring shall be a minimum of thirty inches below final grade and
shall be bedded in and covered by a minimum of four inches of sand, or shall be
protected by commercially available plastic tile, such as "core-flo" or an
approved equal.
   (e)    Installation of pad mounted transformers and communication
interconnection cabinets are required and nothing in this section shall be
construed as requiring the installation of this equipment underground. The use
of underground transformers shall not be permitted. Prior to paving any street,
the developer shall install, at its own cost, acceptable separate conduit
cross-overs for electric and communication facilities at locations specified by
the utility company. (Ord. 84-48. Passed 8-14-84.)
   1119.17  STREET LIGHTING.
   (a)    The developer shall pay the utility company all charges associated
with the installation of street lights in all subdivisions having underground
utilities. Street light pole standards and fixtures shall be selected by the
developer and approved by the Planning Commission. The selection of standards
and fixtures are limited to those units as listed in the street lighting
contract. The rated lumens and the locations of the standards and fixtures
shall be determined by the City and the utility company.
   (b)    Street lights shall be located at every intersection and at the neck
of every cul- de-sac. At other locations, street lights shall be located as
specified by the Planning Commission.
   (c)    The monthly costs for the street lighting units shall be borne by the
developer until these streets are accepted and dedicated by the City. Upon
acceptance and dedication, the City shall assume the monthly costs for street
lighting as part of its contract with the utility company. (Ord. 84-48. Passed
8-14-84.)

   1121.01  AUTHORITY.
   This Zoning Ordinance has been passed under the authority of Ohio R.C.
Chapter 713. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1121.02  TITLE.
   This Zoning Ordinance is the Zoning Ordinance for the City of Sharonville,
Ohio. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1121.03  PURPOSES AND CONSIDERATIONS.
   This Zoning Ordinance has been made in accordance with a comprehensive plan
and designed to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire
and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide
adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue
concentration of population; and to facilitate the adequate provision of
transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements.
These regulations have been made with reasonable consideration among other
things, to the character of the district, and its peculiar suitability for
particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and
encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the City. (Ord. 82-61.
Passed 1-11-83.)
   1121.04  INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION.
   In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance, they
shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public
health, safety, morals, comfort and general welfare.
   Whenever the regulations of this Ordinance require a greater width or size
of yards or other open spaces; a lower height of building or less number of
stories; greater percentage of lot to be left unoccupied; a lower intensity of
population; a more restricted use of land; or impose higher standards than are
required in any other ordinance or regulations, private deed restrictions or
private covenants, these regulations shall govern, but if the requirements of
the other ordinance, regulation or private covenant is the more restrictive,
then those requirements shall govern. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1121.05  SEPARABILITY; CONFLICTING ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Zoning
Ordinance is for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this Ordinance. All ordinances or
parts of ordinances of the City, in conflict with any regulation, provision,
amendment or supplement of this Ordinance are, to the extent of such conflict,
hereby repealed. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1121.06  FORM OF ORDINANCE.
   This Zoning Ordinance is subdivided by titles. Each title is subdivided by
chapters. Each chapter is subdivided into sections which are numbered in
sequence within the chapter, commencing with the first section of Chapter
1121 which shall be numbered
1121.01. The first four figures before the decimal signify Chapter
1121 and the two figures "01" after the decimal signify the first section of
Chapter
1121. The title and chapter headings herein have been inserted for convenience
in reference and are not intended to define or limit the scope of, or otherwise
affect any provisions of this Ordinance. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)

1131.06(a)
   1123.01  ACCESSORY USE OR STRUCTURE.
   "Accessory use or structure" means any use or structure subordinate to the
principal use of a building on the same lot and serving a purpose customarily
incidental to the use of the principal building.  (Ord. 82-61.  Passed 1-11-
83.)
   1123.02  ADDICTION MEDICINE.
   "Addiction Medicine" The field of healthcare which addresses the needs of
individuals addicted to substances of abuse, including alcohol, legal and
illicit drugs and others.  Addiction medicine may include but is not limited
to: counseling, psychology, social work, psychiatry, internal medicine, and the
administering of medication for treatment purposes.
(Ord. 2019-24.  Passed 5-28-19.)
   1123.03  ADULT ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS.
   “Adult entertainment business"" means a restaurant, coffee shop, juice bar,
bar, or any business establishment in which employees participate in the
conduct of the business in a state of nudity.  (Ord. 96-24-E. Passed 4-9-96.)
   1123.04  ADULT BOOKSTORE, ADULT NOVELTY STORE, OR ADULT VIDEO STORE.
   “Adult bookstore," "adult novelty store," or "adult video store" means a
commercial establishment that, for any form of consideration, has as a
significant or substantial portion of its stock-in-trade in, derives a
significant or substantial portion of its revenues from, devotes a significant
or substantial portion of its interior business or advertising to, or maintains
a substantial section of its sales or display space for the sale or rental of
any of the following:
   (a)    Books, magazines, periodicals, or other printed matter, or
photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, or other
visual representations, that are characterized by their emphasis upon the
exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas;
   (b)    Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia that are designed for use or
marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for
sadomasochistic use or abuse of self or others;
   (c)    “Adult bookstore,"  "adult novelty store," or "adult video store"
includes a commercial establishment as defined in section 2907.38 of the Ohio
Revised Code. An establishment may have other principal business purposes that
do not involve the offering for sale, rental, or viewing of materials
exhibiting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical
areas and still be categorized as an adult bookstore, adult novelty store, or
adult video store. The existence of other principal business purposes does not
exempt an establishment from being categorized as an adult bookstore, adult
novelty store, or adult video store so long as one of its principal business
purposes is offering for sale or rental, for some form of consideration, such
materials that exhibit or describe specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas.
      (Ord. 2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.)
   1123.05  ADULT CABARET.
   “Adult cabaret" means a night club, bar, juice bar, restaurant, bottle club,
or similar commercial establishment, whether or not alcoholic beverages are
served, that regularly features any of the following:
   (a)   Persons who appear in a state of nudity or semi-nudity;
   (b)    Live performances that are characterized by the exposure of specified
anatomical areas or specified sexual activities;
   (c)   Films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, or other photographic
reproductions that are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis upon
the exhibition or description of specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas. 
      (Ord. 2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.)
   1123.06  ADULT ENTERTAINMENT.   
   "Adult entertainment" means the sale, rental, or exhibition, for any form of
consideration, of books, films, video cassettes, magazines, periodicals, or
live performances that are characterized by an emphasis on the exposure or
display of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activity.  (Ord.
2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.)
   1123.07  ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENT.
   "Adult entertainment establishment" means an adult arcade, adult bookstore,
adult novelty store, adult video store, adult cabaret, adult motion picture
theater, adult theater, nude or seminude model studio, or sexual encounter
establishment. An establishment in which a medical practitioner, psychologist,
psychiatrist, or similar professional person licensed by the state engages in
medically approved and recognized therapy, including, but not limited to,
massage therapy, as regulated pursuant to section 4731.15 of the Revised Code,
is not an "adult entertainment establishment.  (Ord. 2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.)
   1123.08  ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER.
   “Adult motion picture theater" means a commercial establishment where films,
motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, or similar photographic reproductions
