multiple family or commercial use.
      (3)    The applicant shall prove that his project would be extremely
difficult or impossible to build within the constraints of the usual zoning
districts. The applicant shall also prove that unusual and substantial benefits
would occur to the City or region as a result of the project.
      (4)    The Special PUD shall either complement an existing activity
center including existing shopping, government buildings, schools, offices,
etc. or create a new activity center at or near a location set forth in the
Comprehensive Plan.
      (5)    The Special PUD shall be in a location where substantial road
widenings or long utility extensions shall not be necessary to serve the
project.
   (c)    Permitted Uses. The following uses shall be permitted:
      (1)    Any use permitted by right in a OB, LB, GB, CBD or RM-D District;
      (2)    Special approved uses in any of the above districts deemed
appropriate by the Commission; and
      (3)    Related recreational facilities such as tennis courts, golf
courses, swimming pools, health clubs, etc.
   (d)    Development Requirements.
      (1)    The application process set forth in Chapter
1157 shall be followed.
      (2)    The site plan for the entire Special PUD shall be submitted to the
Commission for its approval and to Council for its approval.
      (3)    Uses within a Special PUD may be mixed within a single building or
with several separate buildings on the same parcel.
      (4)    In Special PUD's, at least thirty-five percent (35%) of the gross
area of the Special PUD shall be open space. Increased density of housing units
may be allowed by the Commission in return for commensurate amounts of
additional open space.
      (5)    The minimum floor area required in multiple family units in
Special PUD's shall be the same as set forth in Section
1139.04(d)(6)C.
      (6)    Front, side and rear yard requirements shall be the same as for
buildings of a similar use built in the regular zoning districts unless the
developer can show that these would be a hardship or hindrance to the design of
a quality project. The clustering, attaching and combining of uses within
buildings is encouraged.
      (7)    Signs. Sign regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1153.
      (8)    Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading
regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1151.
         (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1139.07  PLANNED INDUSTRIAL PARK.
   (a)    Purpose. This type of PUD is intended to permit and control the
development of preplanned, exclusively industrial areas. It is intended that
this type of PUD afford industry reasonable protection from encroachment by
retail commercial, residential and other incompatible land uses, and that
reasonable protection shall be afforded to adjacent uses.
   (b)    Qualifying Conditions.
      (1)    The minimum area of a Planned Industrial Park shall be twenty
acres with direct access to an arterial street.
      (2)    The Planned Industrial Park shall be located in an area zoned for
industrial use.
      (3)    Utilities, roads and other essential services shall be available
for the immediate use of occupants purchasing or leasing sites in the
industrial park.
   (c)    Permitted Uses. The following uses shall be permitted:
      (1)    Any use permitted by right in the CS, GI and ITC Industrial
District;
      (2)    Offices that are in conjunction with an industrial use or offices
providing services to industry located within the industrial park;
      (3)    Conditional uses in the GI Industrial District may be allowed in
Planned Industrial Parks with special approval of the Planning Commission;
(4)   Research and development laboratories, offices and facilities for the
development of new products and processes; and
(5)    Retail facilities, provided such uses serve the industrial uses in the
general vicinity and provided further that such retail uses shall not exceed
five percent (5%) of the total project land area.
   (d)    Development Requirements.
(1)    The application process set forth in Section
1139.03 shall be followed except as revised in subsection (d)(2) hereof.
(2)    The site plan for the entire Planned Industrial Park shall only be
submitted to the Commission for its approval with the right of appeal to
Council.
(3)    Any private covenants or restrictions applying to the parcels within the
industrial park shall be submitted to the Commission for review and approval.
(4)    All business, services or processing shall be conducted wholly within
enclosed buildings with the exception of outdoor contractor's storage yards
which shall be screened from view.
(5)    Minimum lot area and width.
         A.    The Commission may allow a minimum lot size of 25,000 square
feet and a minimum lot width of 150 feet for industrial buildings with a gross
floor area of 10,000 square feet or less.
         B.    The minimum lot size for a building of more than 10,000 square
feet shall be 40,000 square feet with a minimum lot width of 200 feet.
      (6)    Minimum yard requirements.
         A.    Front Yard. A front yard of thirty-five feet is required which
shall be landscaped with grass and shrubbery or trees. For buildings with
parking in front, there shall be a front setback of seventy-five feet, the
front thirty feet of which shall be landscaped.
         B.    Side Yard. A side yard shall be no less than ten feet wide with
fifty feet of side yard required if it includes parking.
         C.    Rear Yard. A rear yard of no less than twenty-five feet shall be
required.
      (7)    Signs. Sign regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1153.
      (8)    Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading
regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1151.
      (9)    Site plans for individual lots shall be reviewed by the Zoning
Enforcement Officer in regard to their conformance with the overall site plan.
Various lots may be combined to allow larger buildings. Major changes in the
approved site plan shall have the approval of the Commission.
      (10)    Maintenance and utilities. For any areas to be held under common
ownership, a document showing the future maintenance provisions shall be
submitted to the Commission. Such provision shall include mandatory membership
of all property owners in any association designed for maintenance of the
common area. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1139.08  TIME LIMITS FOR PUD APPROVAL.
   (a)    A Planned Unit Development approved pursuant to this chapter shall be
valid for one year from the date of final approval. If construction has not
commenced and proceeded meaningfully toward completion by the end of this one
year period, the Zoning Enforcement Officer shall notify the applicant of the
expiration of approval for a Planned Unit Development.
   (b)   If construction of a Phase I has commenced within one year, this shall
satisfy the requirement even though the total PUD may be a number of years from
completion. One year extensions of PUD approval may be granted by the Planning
Commission for a period of up to three years from the date of the original
approval only with a written request from the owner. Upon expiration of special
approval for a PUD, the land shall revert to the zoning district from which it
was originally rezoned under this Zoning Ordinance.
   (c)   If the total PUD or any major part of the PUD, except individual lots,
is sold, the new owner shall indicate in writing his willingness to abide by
the originally approved site plan. If the new owner does not desire to build
according to the original site plan, he shall submit a new site plan according
to the requirements of Chapter
1157.
(Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
1139.09  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER 1140
High Density Residential Planned Unit Development District (HDR-PUD)
1140.01   Purpose and objectives.
1140.02   Permitted uses.
1140.03   Development requirements.
1140.04   Approval procedure.
1140.05   Prohibited uses.
   1140.01  PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES.
   Traditional zoning, with its rigid separation of uses into different zones
under very restricted placement controls, has now been recognized as being
inappropriate to many medium and large scale developments. Planned
developments, which modify the traditional forms of zoning, permit a developer
to secure advantages which can be passed on to the general public by virtue of
more desirable and more economical development. This chapter provides a
controlled degree of flexibility in the placement of structures and lot sizes
and types of uses, while maintaining adequate planning and development
standards.
   The objectives, principles and standards are intended to guide the applicant
in the preparation of the land use and development plan and they shall be used
as the basis for the evaluation of the plan by the Planning Commission and
Council.
   The following objectives shall be considered in reviewing any application
for any PUD in order to realize the inherent advantages of coordinated,
flexible, comprehensive, long-range, planning and development of such planned
development:
   (a)    To provide more desirable living, shopping and working environments
by preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks,
ponds, floodplains, hills and similar natural assets;
   (b)    To encourage with regard to residential use the provision of open
space and the development of recreational facilities and neighborhood
commercial facilities in a generally central location within a reasonable
distance of all living units;
   (c)    To encourage developers to use a more creative and imaginative
approach in the development of residential areas, especially through the
mixture of several housing types in one development;
   (d)    To encourage underground utilities which can be more efficiently
designed when master planning a larger area;
   (e)    To allow phased construction with the knowledge that subsequent
phases shall be approved as originally planned and approved by the City; and
   (f)    To reserve adequate land areas for schools, parks and other public
uses.
   The High Density Residential Planned Unit Development District is intended
to assure long term protection for those areas that should be developed for
high residential density purposes as identified by the Comprehensive Plan of
the City while allowing for planned unit development flexibility. This district
will assure adjacent land owners that PUD procedures, standards and policies
will apply on all property so designated. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1140.02  PERMITTED USES.
   The following uses shall be permitted within the HDR-PUD District:
   (a)    Any permitted use within the RMD Residential District (see Chapter
1131. Residential Districts);
   (b)    Single family attached dwellings, townhouses or zero lot line single
family dwellings: provided the density of the total PUD does not exceed 10.8
units/net residential acre;
   (c)    Multiple family attached apartments provided the density of the total
PUD does not exceed 10.8 units/net residential acre;
   (d)    Golf courses, tennis clubs and athletic clubs;
   (e)    Customary accessory uses as permitted; and
   (f)    Similar uses as provided for in Chapter
1161 as determined by the Planning Commission. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1140.03  DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   The proposed development shall comply with Section
1139.04(d) (Development Requirements) including the following:
   (a)    Site acreage computation;
   (b)    Density transfer;
   (c)    Permissive minimum lot area;
   (d)    Permissive minimum yard requirements;
   (e)    Minimum floor area;
   (f)    Signs (See Chapter
1153);
   (g)    Off street parking and lighting (See Chapter
1151);
   (h)    Off street loading (See Chapter
1151);
   (i)    Maintenance and utilities; and
   (j)    Any private covenants or restrictions applying to the parcels within
the High Density Residential PUD District shall be submitted to the Planning
Commission. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1140.04  APPROVAL PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for PUD approval shall be the same process as described in
Chapter
1139 (Planned Unit Development) and more specifically in Section
1139.03, Application Procedure.
(Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
1140.05  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER  1142
Office Planned Unit Development District (OFFICE-PUD)
1142.01   Purpose and objectives.
1142.02   Permitted uses.
1142.03   Development requirements.
1142.04   Approval procedure.
1142.05   Prohibited uses.
   1142.01  PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES.
   Traditional zoning, with its rigid separation of uses into different zones
under very restricted placement controls, has now been recognized as being
inappropriate to many medium and large scale developments. Planned
developments, which modify the traditional forms of zoning, permit a developer
to secure advantages which can be passed on to the general public by virtue of
more desirable and more economical development. This chapter provides a
controlled degree of flexibility in the placement of structures and lot sizes
and types of uses, while maintaining adequate planning and development
standards.
   The objectives, principles and standards are intended to guide the applicant
in the preparation of the land use and development plan and they shall be used
as the basis for the evaluation of the plan by the Planning Commission and
Council.
   The following objectives shall be considered in reviewing any application
for any PUD in order to realize the inherent advantages of coordinated,
flexible, comprehensive, long-range, planning and development of such planned
development:
   (a)    To provide more desirable living, shopping and working environments
by preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks,
ponds, floodplains, hills and similar natural assets;
   (b)    To encourage developers to use a more creative and imaginative
approach in the development of office complexes;
   (c)    To encourage underground utilities which can be more efficiently
designed when master planning a larger area;
   (d)    To allow phased construction with the knowledge that subsequent
phases shall be approved as originally planned and approved by the City; and
   (e)    To reserve adequate land areas for schools, parks and other public
uses.
   The intent of the Office PUD is to assure the long term protection for those
areas designated for office use in the Comprehensive Plan for the City. In
addition, the zoning of certain areas in the City will assure adjacent land
owners that these areas will be developed in compliance with PUD procedures,
standards and policies while encouraging flexible site planning. (Ord. 89-58.
Passed 9-12-89.)
   1142.02  PERMITTED USES.
   The following uses are permitted in the Office PUD District:
   (a)    Office buildings for professional, financial, governmental, public
utility, executive and administrative, and sales functions provided only
samples are displayed or stored on the lot and no goods shall be distributed;
   (b)    Similar uses as determined by the Planning Commission in accordance
with the provisions of Chapter
1161; and
   (c)    Accessory buildings and uses as defined in Sections
1123.01 and
1125.02.
      (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   
   1142.03  DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   All proposed Office PUD developments shall comply with the following
development requirements:
   (a)    Minimum Requirements. The development requirements of the district
shall conform to those requirements pertaining to the Office Building District
as set forth in Chapter
1135.
   (b)    Setbacks and Distances Between Buildings. Yards and distances between
principal buildings and use of required yards shall be at least equivalent to
that required by the Office Building District unless the applicant demonstrates
that: a better or more appropriate design can be achieved by not applying the
provisions of that zoning district; and adherence to the requirements of the
zoning district is not required in order to insure health, safety and welfare
of the users of the development.
   (c)    Circulation and Parking.
      (1)    Public and private streets, building location, parking areas,
pedestrian ways and utility easements shall be designed to promote the public
safety, compatibility of uses and minimize friction between uses shall be
consistent with the provisions of the adopted Major Thoroughfare Plan.
      (2)    Adequate access for fire and other emergency vehicles shall be
provided on the site.
      (3)    Parking requirements shall be equal to the sum of the parking
requirements for all uses proposed. However, where it can be demonstrated by
the applicant that due to nonconflicting hours of operation, design of the
circulation and parking plan or any other factor reasonably related to the need
for parking, the total parking requirements can be reduced by the Planning
Commission, provided legal notice of the application specifies that such
reduction has been requested.
      (4)    Driveways and circulation roadways shall be designed to minimize
traffic and congestion within the PUD and to minimize the amount of paving.
      (5)    Where open parking areas are to be located immediately adjacent to
any peripheral boundary, a separation or buffer of a type sufficient to insure
the privacy of the adjacent property shall be provided.
   (d)    Maintenance and Utilities. For any areas to be held under common
ownership, a document showing the future maintenance provisions shall be
submitted to the Commission. Such provision shall include mandatory membership
of all property owners in any association designed for maintenance of the
common area.
   (e)    Open Space and Landscaping. All open space and landscaping shall be
provided in conformity with an approved site plan to be included as a condition
of the PUD.
   (f)    Signs. Sign regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1153.
   (g)    Off-Street Parking and Lighting. Requirements for an allowed use
shall be determined from Chapter
1151.
   (h)    Off-Street Loading. Off-street loading regulations shall be as
required in Chapter
1151.
   (i)    Any private covenants or restrictions applying to the parcels within
the Office PUD District shall be submitted to the Planning Commission.
      (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1142.04  APPROVAL PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for PUD approval shall be the same process as described in
Chapter
1139 (Planned Unit Development) and more specifically in Section
1139.03, Application Procedure.
(Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
1142.05  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER 1144
Commercial/Office Planned Unit Development
District (CO-PUD)
1144.01   Purpose and objectives.
1144.02.01   Permitted uses.
1144.02.02   Conditional uses.
1144.03   Development requirements.
1144.04   Approval procedures.
1144.05   Prohibited uses.
   1144.01  PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES.
   Traditional zoning, with its rigid separation of uses into different zones
under very restricted placement controls, has now been recognized as being
inappropriate to many medium and large scale developments. Planned
developments, which modify the traditional forms of zoning, permit a developer
to receive advantages which can be passed on to the general public by virtue of
more desirable and more economical development. This chapter provides a
controlled degree of flexibility in the placement of structures and lot sizes
and types of uses, while maintaining adequate planning and development
standards.
   The objectives, principles and standards are intended to guide the applicant
in the preparation of the land use and development plan and they shall be used
as the basis for the evaluation of the plan by the Planning Commission and
Council.
   The following objectives shall be considered in reviewing any application
for any PUD in order to realize the inherent advantages of coordinated,
flexible, comprehensive, long-range, planning and development of such planned
development:
   (a)    To provide more desirable living, shopping and working environments
by preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks,
ponds, floodplains, hills and similar natural assets;
   (b)    To encourage developers to use a more creative and imaginative
approach in the development of commercial/office areas;
   (c)    To encourage underground utilities which can be more efficiently
designed when master planning a larger area;
   (d)    To allow phased construction with the knowledge that subsequent
phases shall be approved as originally planned and approved by the City; and
   (e)    To reserve adequate land areas for schools, parks and other public
uses.
   The Commercial/Office Planned Unit Development District (CO-PUD) is intended
to assure long term protection for those areas so designated as commercial/
office areas in the Comprehensive Plan for the City of Sharonville. The zoning
of these areas in the City will assure adjacent land owners that these areas
will be developed in conformance with PUD procedures, standards, and policies
as set forth in the Zoning Ordinance, while allowing for flexible site
planning. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1144.02.01  PERMITTED USES.
   The following uses shall be permitted within the CO-PUD District:
   (a)    Office buildings for: professional, financial, governmental, public
utility, sales, executive and administrative.
   (b)    Retail stores and services with the following conditions:
      (1)    A minimum of twenty percent (20%) land area for each parcel within
the CO-PUD District shall be allowed for freestanding retail and personal
service uses with the following limitations:
         A.    A maximum of two individual stores not exceeding 70,000 square
feet each.
         B.    One store not exceeding 25,000 square feet.
         C.    All other retail/personal service uses shall not exceed 7,500
square feet each
   (c)    Hotels and motels for the traveling public.
   (d)    Sit down restaurants.
   (e)    Similar uses as determined by the Planning Commission in accordance
with the provisions of Chapter
1161.
   (f)    Accessory buildings and uses as defined in Sections
 1123.01 and
1125.02.
   (g)    Related recreational facilities such as tennis courts, golf courses,
swimming pools, health clubs, etc.
   (h)   Drive-Thru Service Windows are permitted provided that the use abides
by the General Standards outlined as a conditional use in Section
1144.02.02.
      (Ord. 2018-32.  Passed 10-30-18.)
   1144.02.02  CONDITIONAL USES.
   (a)   The General Standards for Conditional Use Permits for Drive-Thru
window services are as follows:
      (1)   The principal use is a sit down dine-in restaurant.
      (2)   Property must abut a major arterial roadway.
      (3)   Drive-through shall not be located on building elevation that
fronts a public street.
      (4)   Drive-through hours of operation would generally operate between 6
a.m. and 9 p.m.
      (5)   The restaurant has a minimum of forty percent (40%) of the gross
building area devoted to indoor dining seating.
   (b)   The Planning Commission may add additional conditions or modify any of
these general standards upon review of the Conditional Use Permit application.
(Ord. 2018-32.  Passed 10-30-18.)
   1144.03  DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   The following development requirements shall be met:
   (a)    Minimum Requirements. The development requirements of the general
business and office building districts in which the PUD is located shall be
met, except as modified herein.
   (b)    Setbacks and Distances Between Buildings. Yards and distances between
principal buildings and use of required yards shall be at least equivalent to
that required by the office building and general business districts (Chapter
1135) unless the applicant demonstrates that: a better or more appropriate
design can be achieved by not applying the provisions of the zoning district;
and adherence to the requirements of the zoning district is not required in
order to insure health, safety and welfare of the users of the development.
   (c)    Circulation and Parking.
      (1)    Public and private streets, building location, parking areas,
pedestrian ways and utility easements shall be designed to promote the public
safety, compatibility of uses and minimize friction between uses and shall be
consistent with the provisions of the adopted Major Thoroughfare Plan.
      (2)    Adequate access for fire and other emergency vehicles shall be
provided on the site.
      (3)    Parking requirements shall be equal to the sum of the parking
requirements for all uses proposed. However, where it can be demonstrated by
the applicant that due to nonconflicting hours of operation, design of the
circulation and parking plan or any other factor reasonably related to the need
for parking, the total parking requirements can be reduced by the Planning
Commission, provided legal notice of the application specifies that such
reduction has been requested.
      (4)    Driveways and circulation roadways shall be designed to minimize
traffic and congestion within the PUD and to minimize the amount of paving.
      (5)    Where open parking areas are to be located immediately adjacent to
any peripheral boundary, a separation or buffer of a type sufficient to insure
the privacy of the adjacent property shall be provided.
   (d)    Maintenance and Utilities. For any areas to be held under common
ownership, a document showing the future maintenance provisions shall be
submitted to the Commission. Such provision shall include mandatory membership
of all property owners in any association designed for maintenance of the
common area.
   (e)    Open Space and Landscaping. All open space and landscaping shall be
provided in conformity with an approved site plan to be included as a condition
of the PUD (See Chapter
1157).
   (f)    Signs. Sign regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1153.
   (g)    Off-Street Parking and Lighting. Requirements for an allowed use
shall be determined from Chapter
1151.
   (h)    Off-Street Loading. Off-street loading regulations shall be as
required in Chapter
1151.
   (i)    Any private covenants or restrictions applying to the parcels within
the Commercial/Office PUD District shall be submitted to the Planning
Commission. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1144.04  APPROVAL PROCEDURES.
   The procedure for PUD approval shall be the same process as described in
Chapter
1139 (Planned Unit Development) and more specifically in Section
1139.03, Application Procedure.
(Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
1144.05  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER 1146
Commercial Service/Office Planned Unit
Development District (CSO-PUD)
1146.01   Purpose and objectives.
1146.02   Permitted uses.
1146.03   Development requirements.
1146.04   Approval procedure.
1146.05   Prohibited uses.
   1146.01  PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES.
   Traditional zoning, with its rigid separation of uses into different zones
under very restricted placement controls, has now been recognized as being
inappropriate to many medium and large scale developments. Planned
developments, which modify the traditional forms of zoning, permit a developer
to secure advantages which can be passed on to the general public by virtue of
more desirable and more economical development. This chapter provides a
controlled degree of flexibility in the placement of structures and lot sizes
and types of uses, while maintaining adequate planning and development
standards.
   The objectives, principles and standards are intended to guide the applicant
in the preparation of the land use and development plan and they shall be used
as the basis for the evaluation of the plan by the Planning Commission and
Council.
   The following objectives shall be considered in reviewing any application
for any PUD in order to realize the inherent advantages of coordinated,
flexible, comprehensive, long-range, planning and development of such planned
development:
   (a)    To provide more desirable living, shopping and working environments
by preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks,
ponds, floodplains, hills and similar natural assets;
   (b)    To encourage developers to use a more creative and imaginative
approach in the development of commercial service areas;
   (c)    To encourage underground utilities which can be more efficiently
designed when master planning a larger area;
   (d)    To allow phased construction with the knowledge that subsequent
phases shall be approved as originally planned and approved by the City; and
   (e)    To reserve adequate land areas for schools, parks and other public
uses.
   The Commercial Service/Office Planned Unit Development District is intended
to assure long term protection for those areas designated for Commercial
Service/Office use in the Comprehensive Plan for the City. In addition, the
zoning of certain areas in the City will assure adjacent land owners that these
areas will be developed in compliance with PUD procedures, standards and
policies while encouraging flexible and innovative site planning. (Ord. 89-58.
Passed 9-12-89.)
   1146.02  PERMITTED USES.
   The following uses shall be permitted within the CSO-PUD District:
   (a)    Office buildings for professional, financial, governmental, public
utility, executive and administrative; and sales offices provided only samples
are displayed or stored at the facility and no goods shall be distributed;
   (b)    Research laboratories;
   (c)    General services including:
      (1)    Food and drink preparation: bakeries, canning, freezing,
refrigeration, roasting, ice manufacturing, bottling works and creameries;
      (2)    Shops and offices of carpentry, electrical, masonry, plumbing,
heating, ventilating, air conditioning, painting, ornamental iron, roofing and
sheet metal contractors; packing and crating; monument works; offices for
manufactured products; and tool and die shops;
      (3)    Sale of new lumber and other building materials, public utility
materials and equipment;
      (4)    Veterinarian's office, animal hospitals and kennels;
      (5)    Commercial greenhouses; and
      (6)    Service, office warehouse with or without showroom.
   (d)    Similar uses as determined by the Planning Commission in accordance
with the provisions of Chapter
1161; and
   (e)    Accessory buildings and uses as defined in Sections
1123.01 and
1125.02.
      (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1146.03  DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   All CSO-PUD Districts shall comply with the following requirements:
   (a)    Minimum Requirements. The development requirements of the district
shall conform to those provisions pertaining to the Office Building District
(Chapter
1135) and Commercial Service District (Chapter
1137) depending on the use proposed.
   (b)    Setbacks and Distances Between Buildings. Yards and distances between
principal buildings and use of required yards shall be at least equivalent to
that required by the Office Building and Commercial Service zoning districts
unless the applicant reasonably demonstrates that: a better or more appropriate
design can be achieved by not applying the provisions of that zoning district;
and adherence to the requirements of the zoning district is not required in
order to insure health, safety and welfare of the users of the development.
   (c)    Circulation and Parking.
      (1)    Public and private streets, building location, parking areas,
pedestrian ways, utility easements shall be designed to promote the public
safety, compatibility of uses and minimize friction between uses and shall be
consistent with the provisions of the adopted Major Thoroughfare Plan.
      (2)    Adequate access for fire and other emergency vehicles shall
provided on the site.
      (3)    Parking requirements shall be equal to the sum of the parking
requirements for all uses proposed. However, where it can be demonstrated by
the applicant that due to nonconflicting hours of operation, design of the
circulation and parking plan or any other factor reasonably related to the need
for parking, the total parking requirements can be reduced by the Planning
Commission, provided legal notice of the application specifies that such
reduction has been requested.
      (4)    Driveways and circulation roadways shall be designed to minimize
traffic and congestion within the PUD and to minimize the amount of paving.
      (5)    Where open parking areas are to be located immediately adjacent to
any peripheral boundary, a separation or buffer of a type sufficient to insure
the privacy of the adjacent property shall be provided.
   (d)    Maintenance and Utilities. For any areas to be held under common
ownership, a document showing the future maintenance provisions shall be
submitted to the Commission. Such provision shall include mandatory membership
of all property owners in any association designed for maintenance of the
common area.
   (e)    Any private covenants or restrictions applying to the parcels within
the Commercial Service/Office PUD District shall be submitted to the Planning
Commission.
   (f)    All business, services or processing shall be conducted wholly within
enclosed building.
   (g)    Minimum yard requirements. (See Section
1139.07(d)(6))
   (h)    Signs. Sign regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1153.
   (i)    Off-Street Parking and Loading and Lighting. Off-street parking and
loading and lighting regulations shall be as provided in Chapter
1151.
   (j)    Site plan for individual lots shall be reviewed by the Zoning
Enforcement Officer with regard to their conformance with the overall site
plan. Various lots may be combined to allow larger buildings. Major changes in
the approved site plan shall have the approval of the Planning Commission.
   (k)    Open Space and Landscaping. All open space and landscaping shall be
provided in conformity with an approved site plan to be included as a condition
of the PUD. (Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
   1146.04  APPROVAL PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for PUD approval shall be the same process as described in
Chapter
1139 (Planned Unit Development) and more specifically in Section
1139.03, Application Procedure (Note the exception in subsection
1139.03(e)).
(Ord. 89-58. Passed 9-12-89.)
1146.05  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER 1147
Northern Lights Overlay District
1147.01   Purpose.
1147.02   Creation and boundaries.
1147.03   Effect of Northern Lights Overlay designation.
1147.04   Permitted uses.
1147.05   Development standards.
1147.06   Pre-application meeting.
1147.07   Site plan review process.
1147.08   Ground and pole sign amortization.
1147.09   Prohibited uses.
CROSS REFERENCES
Definitions - see P. & Z.
1123.66.1
   1147.01  PURPOSE.
   (a)   To leverage public dollars invested in the expansion of the
Sharonville Convention Center and improvement of the Chester Road Corridor by
encouraging land uses and site design that complement the Convention Center and
Corridor.
   (b)   To enhance property values, protect property rights, stabilize and
improve the Chester Road Corridor, and increase economic and financial benefits
to Sharonville businesses and inhabitants.
   (c)   To encourage innovative and creative site design, outdoor lighting,
and architecture.
   (d)   To promote development that emphasizes pedestrian connections and
amenities while accommodating automobile access.
   (e)   To encourage mixed use development that creates a vibrant hospitality,
entertainment and office district that responds to changing market demands and
conditions.
   (f)   To prohibit or restrict uses that are disruptive to pedestrians.
(Ord. 2007-67.  Passed 2-12-08.)
   1147.02  CREATION AND BOUNDARIES.
   The boundaries of the district are depicted on the Official Zoning Map.  A
map of the boundaries is also included in the Northern Lights Standards and
Guidelines.  The Northern Lights Overlay District is generally bounded by I-75
to the east, Kemper Road to the north, and the western edge of parcels fronting
on the west side of Lippelman Road to the west.  The southern boundary consists
of Greenwood Road west of Chester Road, and the parcels immediately south of
Greenwood Road on the east side of Chester Road.
(Ord. 2007-67.  Passed 2-12-08.)
   1147.03  EFFECT OF NORTHERN LIGHTS OVERLAY DESIGNATION.
   The Northern Lights Overlay District regulations apply in combination with
underlying base zoning district regulations and all other applicable standards
of this Zoning Code.  When Northern Lights Overlay District standards conflict
with the underlying base zoning district regulations and other standards of
this Zoning Code, the regulations of the Northern Lights Overlay District will
apply.  When the Northern Lights Overlay District does not regulate an issue
that is regulated by an underlying zoning district, the underlying base zoning
district regulations will apply.  In this case, the underlying zoning districts
are the GB General Business District, OB Office Building District, CS
Commercial Service and RM-D Multi-Family Residential District. 
(Ord. 2007-67.  Passed 2-12-08.)
   1147.04  PERMITTED USES.
   No building shall be erected, used or structurally altered, nor shall the
land or premises be used in whole or in part, except for uses permitted in all
underlying zoning districts within the Northern Lights Overlay District except
as otherwise permitted and prohibited in the following additional provisions:
   (a)   The following uses are prohibited:
      (1)   Industrial uses;
      (2)   Vehicle sales and services, repair and service garages, with the
exception of car rental establishments;
      (3)   Wholesale uses and showrooms;
      (4)   Car trailer rental;
      (5)   Car wash service;
      (6)   Outdoor recreation;
      (7)   Retail sales in open yards;
      (8)   Drive-through restaurants;
      (9)   Single-family detached dwellings;
      (10)   Renting of rooms;
      (11)   Raising of domestic animals as described in Section
1131.02(a)(4);
      (12)   Two family dwellings;
      (13)   Mortuaries;
      (14)   General and Special Hospitals and Health Centers;
      (15)   Laundry agencies and laundromat; tailor, pressing and dry cleaning
shop;
      (16)   Repair services for household appliances, shoe and hat, radio and
television;
      (17)   Service stations for the sale of gasoline, oil and auto
accessories, lubrication;
      (18)   Bus passenger repair and storage garages;
      (19)   Production uses;
      (20)   General services, sales and storage establishments;
      (21)   Thrift shop;
      (22)   Sale of motorcycles, recreation vehicles, camper trailers, mobile
homes and manufactured housing boats, out board motors;
      (23)   Cleaning establishments; laundries, dyeing, dry cleaning, carpet
cleaning; towel supply;
      (24)   Shops and offices of carpentry, electrical, masonry, plumbing,
heating ventilating, air conditioning, painting, ornamental iron, roofing and
sheet metal contractors; packing and crating; monumental works; offices for
manufactured products; and tool and die shops;
      (25)   Sale of lumber and other building materials, public utility
materials and equipment;
      (26)   Veterinarian’s office, animal hospitals and kennels;
      (27)   Adult entertainment business;
      (28)   Adult Bookstore, Adult Novelty Store, or Adult Video Store;
      (29)   Adult Cabaret;
      (30)   Adult Entertainment;
      (31)   Adult Entertainment Establishment;
      (32)   Adult Motion Picture Theater;
      (33)   Adult Theater;
      (34)   Sexual Device Shop;
      (35)   Sexual Encounter Establishment;
      (36)   Sexually Oriented Business;
      (37)   Car Title Loan Establishment;
      (38)   Cash Advance Facility;
      (39)   Check Cashing Facility;
      (40)   Pawn Shop;
      (41)   Pay Day Lending Facility;
      (42)   Self-Storage Facility;
      (43)   Smokers Lounge;
      (44)   Alcohol and Drug Addiction Treatment Clinics and Facilities,
Inpatient;
      (45)   Alcohol and Drug Addiction Treatment Clinics and Facilities,
Outpatient;
      (46)   Correctional Facility.
   (b)   Residential uses are permitted on the upper floors of any building in
the Northern Lights Overlay District, provided that other permitted uses occupy
the ground floor.
   
   (c)   Outdoor Dining is permitted as an ancillary use.
   (d)   Similar uses are permitted as determined by the Planning Commission in
accordance with the provisions of Chapter
1161.
(Ord. 2019-24.  Passed 5-28-19.)
   1147.05  DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   Except as otherwise noted, buildings and uses in the Northern Lights Overlay
District shall comply with the architectural and site development standards
established in the Sharonville Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines,
as adopted and amended by City Council.  The Sharonville Northern Lights Design
Standards and Guidelines are hereby adopted by reference, in their entirety, as
if their entire text and substance were a part of this Chapter.  Any Planned
Unit Developments proposed for approval must conform with the land use and
minimum design requirements as regulated by this chapter and the Sharonville
Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines.
   (a)   Unobstructed Sight Distance.  In addition to the provisions of the
Sharonville Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines, no fence, wall,
sign, structure, vehicle, or planting shall be erected, established or
maintained on any lot which will obstruct the view of drivers in vehicles
approaching an intersection of two (2) roads or the intersection of a road and
a driveway or curb cut.  Fences, walls, signs, structures, vehicles or
plantings located in the triangular area described below shall not be permitted
to obstruct cross-visibility between a height of thirty (30) inches and five
(5) feet above the lowest point of the intersecting road(s).  The unobstructed
triangular area is described as follows:
      (1)   Driveway Intersection Sight Triangle.  At intersections of
driveways with streets, the sight triangle shall be established by locating the
intersection of the street curb with the driveway edge, and by measuring from
this point a distance of ten (10) feet along the driveway to a point and a
distance of twenty (20) feet along the street curb to a point and connecting
these points.
      (2)   Street Intersection Sight Triangle.  At street intersections, the
sight triangle shall be formed by measuring at least thirty-five (35) feet
along curb lines and connecting these points.  Within the first twenty (20)
feet of the street intersection sight triangles, no structure or landscaping
material is permitted except required ground cover.  Within the portion of
sight triangle that is located between twenty (20) feet and thirty-five (35)
feet signs and trees shall be permitted only when the pole or trunk is the only
part of a sign or tree that is visible between the ground and five (5) feet
above the ground, or otherwise does not present a traffic visibility hazard. 
(Ord. 2007-67.  Passed 2-12-08.)
   1147.06  PRE-APPLICATION MEETING.
   The developer shall meet with the Zoning Administrator prior to the
submission of a site plan.  The purpose of this meeting is to discuss early and
informally the purpose and effect of the Northern Lights Overlay District and
the criteria and standards contained herein, and to familiarize the developer
with other applicable regulations.
(Ord. 2007-67.  Passed 2-12-08.)
   1147.07  SITE PLAN REVIEW PROCESS.
   The purpose of this section is to create a unique site plan review process
that applies only to properties within the Northern Lights Overlay District. 
This review process streamlines the site plan review and approval process in
return for full compliance with the Sharonville Northern Lights Design
Standards and Guidelines.
   (a)     The Sharonville Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines
contain both mandatory Standards and an elective set of Guidelines. 
Applications must meet 100% of the Standards in order to receive zoning
approval.  Applications that meet 50% or more of the Guidelines, in addition to
meeting 100% of the Standards, will receive an expedited zoning approval. 
Applications that meet less than 50% of the Guidelines are referred to the
Architectural Review Board for review.  The flowchart in Ordinance 2007-67
illustrates the review procedure for the Design Standards and Guidelines.
   (b)     An expedited zoning review consists of a review by City staff,
without the need for Architectural Review Board or Planning Commission meetings
or action.  Staff will utilize the review matrix included with the Sharonville
Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines as a means of evaluating site
plan applications against the Standards and Guidelines.
   (c)     Within fourteen (14) days after the receipt of a complete
application, the Safety Service Director, or designee shall approve, refer to
the Architectural Review Board, or disapprove the site plan application in
conformance with the provisions of the Design Standards and Guidelines.  The
Zoning Administrator shall mark one copy of the site plan as approved, referred
to the Architectural Review Board, or disapproved and forward such copy with a
letter of transmittal to the applicant.
   (d)     The Architectural Review Board reviews site plans that are referred
to it and, consistent with Section
1162.07 of the Zoning Code, makes a recommendation to the Planning Commission. 
The Planning Commission then evaluates the recommendations and site plans and
approves, approves with conditions, or denies the proposal.     
   (e)     The Planning Commission shall schedule a public hearing on the
application for approval of the site plan not less than twenty (20) days or
more than forty (40) days from the date the Architectural Review Board forwards
its recommendation to the Planning Commission.
   (f)     Before conducting the public hearing, notice of such hearing shall
be given in one or more newspapers of general circulation in the City and in
writing by first class mail to all adjacent property owners at least ten (10)
days before the date of said hearing.  The notice shall set forth the time and
place of the hearing, and shall provide a summary explanation of the project
and a description of the nonconforming items.
   (g)     All site plan applications shall comply with the requirements of
Chapter
1157 Site Plan Review and Chapter
1162 Architectural Review Board.
      (Ord. 2017-32.  Passed 9-26-17.)
   1147.08  GROUND AND POLE SIGN AMORTIZATION.
   (a)     Context and Intent.  The City, after a comprehensive study, has
adopted a Master Plan for the revitalization of the Chester Road Corridor (aka
Sharonville Northern Lights District) including recommendations for a
coordinated design of signage on private property.  The Sharonville Northern
Lights Design Standards and Guidelines include design requirements for new
freestanding signs that are consistent with Master Plan recommendations.  The
effect of these requirements is to ensure that freestanding signs created or
erected after the adoption of the Northern Lights Overlay District regulations
will be consistent with the City's stated purposes of encouraging the effective
use of freestanding signs as a means of communication in Sharonville Northern
Lights; maintaining a sustainable and pleasing environment, which attracts to
Sharonville Northern Lights major events of regional, national and
international interest; preserving a community that is attractive to business;
improving pedestrian and traffic safety; minimizing the possible adverse
effects of signs on nearby public and private property; and implementing
relevant provisions of the Sharonville Northern Lights Master Plan, as updated
periodically.  However, there remain in Northern Lights a moderate number of
ground and pole signs that violate the letter and purpose of the new
regulations but that were lawfully erected under regulations applicable to
signs prior to the adoption of this Chapter.  Such signs are protected as pre-
existing nonconforming signs under Section
1153.17.  Although such protection is both fair and rational for the period of
time necessary for the signs' owners to recover reasonable investments in the
signs, it is the intent of the City that these signs should at some point be
improved.  The purpose of this section is to provide for the eventual
improvement of such nonconforming ground and pole signs, after allowing their
owners a reasonable period of use during which to recover their reasonable
investment in such signs. (Within eighteen (18) months of amendment of this
section of the Northern Lights District Zoning Regulations, property owners
with pre-existing ground and pole signs shall present a Sign Improvement plan
to the Planning Commission for review and approval of existing ground and pole
signs.  The Planning Commission may approve, approve with conditions, or deny
any sign improvement plan). 
   (b)     Applicability.  The requirements of Section
1147.08 apply only to existing ground and pole signs that are located in yards
that are adjacent to Chester Road within the Northern Lights Overlay District.
   (c)     Findings.  In support of the purposes of this Chapter and as a basis
for its adoption, the City Council hereby finds that:
      (1)     Certain ground and pole signs erected lawfully in Sharonville
Northern Lights under previous sign regulations are inconsistent with both the
letter and purpose of new freestanding sign regulations adopted by the City;
      (2)     The existence of such signs will in part hinder the purposes of
the City in adopting this Chapter, which was based on careful study and
community discussion;
      (3)     The City recognizes the need to allow an individual to recover a
lawful investment, such as the erection or placement of a sign, but the City
also recognizes that the period of time necessary to recover such an investment
is finite;
      (4)     The Internal Revenue Code and regulations adopted thereunder
allow businesses to depreciate the full cost of a sign over a period of five
years or less;
      (5)     Most signs are financed or leased for a period of five years or
less;
      (6)     Many signs are routinely replaced after a period of five years;
      (7)     Many general advertising signs are erected on property leased for
a period of five years, which may be renewable for an additional period of five
years;
      (8)     There are thus many indications in the market that a reasonable
sign user anticipates recovery of the investment in a sign over approximately
five years;
      (9)     Therefore, the requirement that a sign be removed after a
specified period that is more than five years long will, in most cases, permit
an owner to recover the full investment in the sign;
      (10)     This concept is commonly called the "amortization" of an
investment.
      (11)     A planned expansion of Chester Road may result in some existing
ground and pole signs being located in the right-of-way or public roadway
easement.
   (d)     Action Required.  Any legal ground and pole sign in existence
eighteen (18) months of amendment of this section of the Northern Lights
District Zoning Regulations which does not comply with all of the applicable
requirements of this Chapter for freestanding signs (i.e. Sign Improvement Plan
approved or in process of approval by the Planning Commission), shall be
brought into conformance with the requirements of this Chapter shall be subject
to the following remedy.
   (e)     Remedies.  The Safety Service Director, or designee shall notify the
owner of a ground or pole sign affected by this chapter of the requirements of
said chapter at least thirty (30) days before the date on which such sign must
be brought into compliance with this chapter.  The owner of the sign shall have
a period of thirty days from the date of such notice to bring such sign into
conformance with the requirements of this chapter, whether by removal of the
sign or modification of the sign.  If the sign is not so removed or modified,
the owner shall be subject to a separate penalty under Chapter
1199 for each day for which the sign continues to exist in violation of the
requirements of this chapter.
   (f)     Appeal.
      (1)     The owner of a ground or pole sign affected by this chapter may,
at any time after the effective date of this chapter and before the expiration
of thirty (30) days after the date of notice under Section
1147.08(d), file a hardship appeal with the Board of Zoning Appeals.   
      (2)     The Board of Zoning Appeals shall consider said appeal at its
next regular meeting.  If and only if the Board of Zoning Appeals finds that
the sign owner will not be able to recover reasonable investment in the sign by
the date established by Section
1147.08(c), the Board of Zoning Appeals may extend that date by a reasonable
period which shall not be longer than is necessary to allow the owner to
recover the reasonable investment in the sign and shall in no event extend such
date more than an additional five years.
      (3)     In making its determination, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
consider only the reasonable investment of the owner in the sign prior to the
effective date of this chapter; no considerations of alleged "market value"
shall be considered, nor shall investments made after the effective date of
this chapter.
      (4)     The sign owner shall have the burden of proof in such a matter
and shall be obligated to provide to the Zoning Board of Appeals original or
certified copies of all invoices for work or materials related to the sign and
certified copies of applicable land leases, equipment leases and/or security
agreements related to the sign.  Any appeal of the determination of the Zoning
Board of Appeals shall be to the District Court.
      (5)     For purposes of this section, a sign owner shall be deemed to
have recovered the investment in the sign when:
         A.     For a leased sign, the total lease revenues equal the cost of
the sign plus actual, necessary maintenance expense, plus a net return on
investment equal to three percentage (3%) points above the cost of funds
borrowed for the sign, or if the cost of such funds cannot be determined or if
no funds were borrowed, fifteen percent (15%) per annum; or
         B.     For a sign used by its owner, when the sign has been in use for
one year past the date when it could first have been fully depreciated under
the Internal Revenue Code, regardless of whether the owner actually claimed
such depreciation.
   (g)    Sign Improvement Plan for Existing Chester Road Ground and Pole Signs
As outlined in
1147.08 (a), within eighteen (18) months of amendment of the Northern Lights
District Zoning Regulations, property owners with pre-existing ground and pole
signs shall present an improvement plan to the Planning Commission for review
and approval of existing ground and pole signs.  The Planning Commission may
approve, approve with conditions, or deny any sign improvement plan.
   In order to present the best possible sign improvement plan for
consideration by the Planning Commission, Chester Road property owners are
encouraged to consult the list below for ideas of sign improvements.  Sign
Improvement Plans should not be limited to face change/message area or message
panel changes only. (examples included in Northern Lights Overlay Zone
Standards  and Guidelines).  The intent of the Northern Lights Overlay Zoning
District regulations is to create a modern, vibrant, pedestrian and vehicular
accessible, regional business district destination.
   •   Sign Base cladding (addition of brick, stone, metal or other suitable
material to hide or partially hide existing pole or poles that support the sign
and help give the sign a sense of being permanent, durable, and modern)
   •   Up-lighting
   •   Internal Illumination
   •   External Illumination
   •   Landscaping
   •   Sign face/message area change
   •   Addition of digital electronic message center (EMC), provided there is
no increase in overall sign area up to a maximum of 150 square feet.
      (Ord. 2017-32.  Passed 9-26-17.)
1147.09  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)
CHAPTER 1148
Mosteller Road Economic Development
Overlay (EDO) District
1148.01   Purpose.
1148.02   Creation and boundaries.
1148.03   Effect of Mosteller Road EDO designation.
1148.04   Permitted uses.
1148.05   Development standards.
1148.06   Pre-application meeting.
1148.07   Site plan review process.
1148.08   Conflict with other provisions.
1148.09   Prohibited uses.
   1148.01  PURPOSE.
   (a)   To establish a framework within which the former United States General
Services Administration (GSA) depot can be reused as a high-quality, high-
density employment center.
   (b)   To allow a wide range of office, industrial, technological, research
and similar uses not otherwise contained within a single zoning classification.
   (c)   To enhance property values, protect property rights, stabilize and
improve the area in and around the former GSA depot, and increase economic and
financial benefits to Sharonville businesses and inhabitants.
   (d)   To achieve a singular image and character, a visually harmonious
appearance and an efficient and functional work environment by requiring
compliance with minimum design standards.
   (e)   To promote development that is compatible with surrounding
development, provides the greatest economic benefit to the community and
strengthens the City’s long-term economic position.
   (f)   To prohibit or restrict uses that do not produce the greatest density
of jobs consistent with the City’s goal to facilitate the highest possible
level of economic development.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.02  CREATION AND BOUNDARIES.
   The boundaries of the Mosteller Road EDO District are depicted on the
Official Zoning Map.  The District is generally bounded by the western edge of
parcels fronting on Enterprise Drive to the east, the southern edge of parcels
fronting on Crescentville Road to the north, the northern edge of some parcels
fronting on the north side of Commerce Drive to the south, and the eastern edge
of some parcels fronting on the east side of Mosteller Road to the west.  The
District is also directly bounded by Mosteller Road to the west, Commerce Drive
to the south and has additional frontage on Enterprise Drive and Crescentville
Road.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.03  EFFECT OF MOSTELLER ROAD EDO DESIGNATION.
   (a)   The Mosteller Road EDO District regulations apply in combination with
underlying base zoning district regulations and all other applicable standards
of this Zoning Code.  When Mosteller Road EDO District standards conflict with
the underlying base zoning district regulations and other standards of this
Zoning Code, the regulations of the Mosteller Road EDO District will apply. 
When the Mosteller Road EDO District does not regulate an issue that is
regulated by an underlying zoning district, the underlying base zoning district
regulations will apply.  In this case, the underlying zoning districts are the
General Industrial (GI) District, Industrial Truck Center (ITC) District, and
Commercial Service (CS) District.
   (b)   All permitted uses within the EDO at the time of passage, which are
otherwise made illegal in accordance with Section
1148.04, shall be deemed legal permitted uses and may continue in perpetuity. 
At such time as any use is changed to comply with the EDO they shall not return
to a prohibited use in the District.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.04  PERMITTED USES.
   No building shall be erected, used or structurally altered, nor shall the
land or premises be used in whole or in part, except for uses permitted in all
underlying zoning districts within the Mosteller Road EDO District, unless
otherwise permitted or prohibited:
   (a)   The following uses are permitted throughout the Mosteller Road EDO:
      (1)   All permitted uses in all underlying zoning districts except those
specifically prohibited in subsection (b);
      (2)   Business, professional and administrative offices;
      (3)   Research, development and testing laboratories;
      (4)   Manufacturing and assembly facilities;
      (5)   Similar uses may be permitted as determined by the Planning
Commission in accordance with the provisions of Chapter
1161.
      (6)   Accessory buildings and uses as defined in Section
1123.01 and regulated in Section
1125.02;
   (b)   The following uses are prohibited throughout the Mosteller Road EDO:
      (1)   Warehouse and storage as a primary use;
      (2)   Truck terminals;
      (3)   Refining of petroleum or of its products and petroleum storage
yards;
      (4)   Construction equipment rental, sales, service and/or storage;
      (5)   Construction trades and contractor offices and shops;
      (6)   Commercial/industrial laundries and dry cleaning plants;
      (7)   Self-service storage facilities;
      (8)   Repair establishments: automobile engines, body and paint,
electrical and household appliances;
      (9)   Repair, sale or lease of buses, trucks and machinery and trailers;
      (10)   Outdoor recreation as a primary use;
      (11)   Sale of new lumber and other building materials/products, public
utility materials and equipment;
      (12)   Veterinarian’s office, animal hospitals and kennels;
      (13)   Commercial greenhouses and/or landscape contracting services;
      (14)   Food and drink preparation: bakeries, canning, freezing
refrigeration, roasting, ice manufacturing, bottling works and auto wash;
      (15)   Similar uses may be prohibited as determined by the Planning
Commission in accordance with the provisions of Chapter
1161.
   (c)   Temporary uses shall be regulated by underlying zoning and relevant
ordinances.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.05  DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   Except as otherwise noted, buildings and uses in the Mosteller Road Economic
Development Overlay (EDO) District shall comply with the architectural and site
development standards established in the Sharonville Northern Lights Design
Standards and Guidelines, as adopted and amended by City Council.  The
Sharonville Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines are hereby adopted
by reference, in their entirety, as if their entire text and substance were a
part of this chapter.  Any Planned Unit Developments proposed for approval must
conform with the land use and minimum design requirements as regulated by this
chapter and the Sharonville Northern Lights Design Standards and Guidelines.
   (a)   Design Standards for Office/Professional/Laboratory and Similar Uses. 
For Office/Professional/Laboratory and similar uses located within the
Mosteller Road EDO, the following standards shall apply:
      (1)   Building Materials.  Materials such as brick, stone, wood, split-
faced block are preferred.
         A.   Smooth-faced non-decorative block shall not be permitted.
         B.   Dry-Vit, stucco and similar exterior building systems shall be
only utilized as an accent treatment occupying no more than twenty percent
(20%) of the exterior building wall area.
         C.   Material that is glazed or highly reflective shall be only
utilized as an accent treatment occupying no more than twenty percent (20%) of
the exterior building wall area.
         D.   Use of materials which have colors and tones that are compatible
with or complementary to the predominant colors and tones of existing buildings
shall be utilized when such existing structures, as determined by the Planning
Commission, to be appropriate for their location.
      (2)   Building Articulation.  Exterior building walls shall not contain
expansive areas of blank walls with no articulation.  Articulation may be
provided through the use of windows, simulated windows, vertical columns or
horizontal banding of a different material, color or texture, cornice
treatments or other means.  Decorative down lighting or up lighting can also be
utilized to enhance the appearance.  Landscaping, if at least 1/3 the height of
the building, can also provide a visual break in order to soften the appearance
of a large wall area.
      (3)   Side and Rear Building Wall Articulation.  Rear and side of
building facades shall be subject to the same requirements as specified in the
above subsection (2).  Planning Commission may make a determination that a
lesser treatment is acceptable if the wall facade is not visible from public
streets or adjacent properties.
      (4)   Roof Treatment.  If pitched, roofs should be articulated with the
introduction of dormers and other roof features appropriate to the building
design.  Expansion areas of roof with no articulation shall not be permitted.
      (5)   Screen of Dumpsters and Mechanical Equipment.
         A.   Mechanical equipment on the roof of buildings shall be screened. 
Acceptable screening methods shall include, but not be limited to the
following:
            1.   Locating such equipment on the roof in such a way that it is
not visible from adjacent property or a public right-of-way at a height of five
(5) feet from the ground; or
            2.   Constructing a parapet wall or other structure that utilizes
the exterior building material to a sufficient height so that the mechanical
equipment is not visible from adjacent property or a public right-of-way at a
height of five (5) feet above the ground.
         B.   All other exterior mechanical equipment, dumpsters or the storage
of goods or supplies used in the operation of the establishment shall be
screened from public rights-of-way and adjacent property with a solid masonry
wall constructed of the same material, color and detailing as the principal
building.  Gates for dumpster enclosures shall not be constructed with chain
link fencing.
   (b)   Design Standards for Industrial Uses.  For light and other industrial
uses in the Mosteller Road EDO, the following standards shall apply:
      (1)   A minimum of 25% of the front facade shall consist of a masonry
material.
      (2)   Loading docks shall not be located adjacent to public rights-of-way
or screened from normal view.
      (3)   Rooftop mechanical units for industrial buildings shall be screened
to the extent possible.
      (4)   All other exterior mechanical equipment, dumpsters or the storage
of goods or supplies used in the operation of the establishment shall be
screened from public rights-of-way and adjacent property with a solid masonry
wall or an opaque vegetative buffer.
   (c)   Yard and Area Regulations.  Yard and area regulations, including but
not limited to building setback, parking setback, location of open yard uses,
shall comply with the Schedule of Yard Regulations as set forth in Section
1137.04.
   (d)   Parking Regulations.  Parking regulations shall comply with the
provisions of Chapter
1151.
   (e)   Lighting Design Standards.
      (1)   In no case shall lighting cause glare or unnecessary diffusion that
impairs the safe movement of traffic on adjacent streets or highways.
      (2)   Light fixtures shall be located so that the light sources are
directed into parking areas.
      (3)   No light sources shall be located on building facades directed
outward toward property boundaries except that the architectural, landscape and
decorative lighting is permitted provided that the light emissions are limited
to the building facade or other illuminated object.
      (4)   All outdoor lighting not necessary for security purposes shall be
reduced, activated by motion sensor devices, or turned off during non-operating
hours.
   (f)   Signs.  All signs, permanent and temporary, shall be in compliance
with the provisions of Chapter
1153.  (Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.06  PRE-APPLICATION MEETING.
   The developer shall meet with the Zoning Administrator prior to the
submission of a site plan.  The purpose of this meeting is to discuss early and
informally the purpose and effect of the Mosteller Road EDO District and the
criteria and standards contained herein, and to familiarize the developer with
other applicable regulations.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.07  SITE PLAN REVIEW PROCESS.
   A proposal for development on a tract of land that lies within the Mosteller
Road EDO shall comply with the administrative provisions set forth as follows:
   (a)   Site Plan Review, Approval and Conformance of a General Site Plan. 
Following the pre-application meeting, an applicant may submit a general site
plan for review by the Planning Commission.  Such general plan shall encompass
the entire area proposed for development, show existing and proposed
development areas including uses, phases of development, roads, drainage ways,
external and internal lot lines, utility easements, topography, parking areas
and building location(s).   
   (b)   Site Plan Review, Approval and Conformance of a Detailed Site Plan.  A
detailed site plan is required for each phase of development.  If a development
is to be completed in one phase, only one detailed site plan is required.  In
the case of a single-phased development, the applicant may bypass the general
approval step in Section
1148.07(a).  The detailed site plan shall meet the requirements and provisions
in Section
1157.05 Final Site Plan.
   (c)   Significance of an Approved Plan.  An approved site plan shall become
a binding commitment for the development of the specific elements approved for
development.  The approved site plan may be transferred to another person,
corporation, or group of individuals or corporations prior to the issuance of a
building permit.
   (d)   Changes to an Approved Plan.  All construction and development under
any building permit shall be in accordance with the approved site plan.  Any
departure from the approved plans shall be resubmitted for approval in
accordance with the Mosteller Road EDO Regulations.
      (Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
   1148.08  CONFLICT WITH OTHER PROVISIONS.
   Specific provisions of the Mosteller Road EDO District shall prevail over
those in relevant chapters to the district where provisions of this chapter are
inconsistent or in conflict thereunder.  Otherwise, all other applicable
portions of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Sharonville shall apply with
full force and effect.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 6-10-08.)
1148.09  PROHIBITED USES.
   No medical marijuana retail dispensary, medical marijuana cultivation,
medical marijuana processing, or medical marijuana-related business or home
occupation may be established, operated, or maintained within the City of
Sharonville, nor shall any provision of the Zoning Code be construed to permit
the use of any property for that purpose.
(Ord. 2017-17. Passed 7-11-17.)

   1151.01  INTENT.
   Off-street parking and loading requirements and regulations are established
in order to achieve, among others, the following purposes:
   (a)   To relieve congestion so the streets can be utilized more fully for
movement of vehicular traffic;
   (b)   To promote the safety and convenience of pedestrians and shoppers by
locating parking areas so as to lessen car movements in the vicinity of
intensive pedestrian traffic;
   (c)    To protect adjoining residential neighborhoods from on-street
parking;
   (d)    To promote the general convenience, welfare and prosperity of
business, service, research, production, manufacturing and distribution
developments which depend upon off-street parking facilities; and
   (e)    To provide regulations and standards for the development of accessory
off-street parking and loading facilities in accordance with the objectives of
the General Plan of the City. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1151.02  SCOPE OF REGULATIONS.
   Accessory off-street parking and loading facilities shall be provided as a
condition precedent to occupancy of all residential, institutional, business,
office, research, production, distribution, service and industrial uses in
conformance with the provisions of this chapter:
   (a)    Whenever a building is constructed or a new use established;
   (b)    Whenever an existing building is altered and there is an increase in
the number of dwelling units, seating capacity and the floor area of building;
and
   (c)    Whenever the use of an existing building is changed to a more
intensive use which requires more off-street parking facilities, except certain
nonconforming uses may continue as provided in Section
1155.09.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1151.03  APPLICATION AND DESIGN.
   (a)    Application for Providing Facilities. Any application for a permit to
construct a building or parking area, or for a Certificate of Occupancy for a
change in use of land or building, shall include a site plan drawn to scale and
fully dimensioned showing the proposed design of the parking area and loading
facilities to be provided in compliance with the provisions of Chapter
1157, Site Plan Review. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   (b)    Determination of Required Parking Facilities. The minimum number of
spaces required for accessory off-street parking shall be determined by
applying the parking area design standards in subsection (c) hereof, the
schedule of parking requirements for the various uses in Section
1151.05 and any other applicable provisions of this Zoning Ordinance. Where the
computation results in a fractional space, it shall be counted as one
additional space required. Handicapped parking is required and shall be
designed according to the Ohio Basic Building Code, Section 515.0 (4101:2-5-
15). (Ord. 83-53. Passed 9-13-83.)
   (c)   Parking Area Design Standards. The plan for parking spaces of a
parking area included with an application to construct a building or parking
area, or change in use, shall be designed and dimensioned in accordance with
the following:
      (1)    A parking space shall not be less than nineteen feet in length by
nine feet in width and in conformance with Appendix II of this Ordinance,
"Parking Area Design Standards";
         (Ord. 82-61.  Passed 1-11-83.)
      (2)    All parking spaces shall be permanently surfaced of either
blacktop or concrete in accordance with construction standard as required by
the City; and
         (Ord. 00-59.  Passed 1-9-01.)
      (3)    All parking areas shall include appropriate access roads between
spaces in accordance with Appendix II of this Ordinance.
         (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1151.04  SCHEDULE OF PARKING REQUIREMENTS.
   Accessory off-street parking facilities shall be provided in quantities not
less than set forth in the following schedule:
