         Plan definitions - see P. & Z.
1123.74
   1157.01  DESCRIPTION AND PURPOSE.
   Certain land uses are quite necessary to the proper development of a
community, but likewise, possess characteristics which warrant special
treatment. These characteristics, in many situations, can easily become
undesirable to some degree, basically because their intricate needs and/or
appearance have a wide-ranging influence beyond their own perimeter. In
conformance with the purpose of this Zoning Ordinance, it is hereby deemed
prudent and necessary to apply limits and guidelines which shall both encourage
good development and discourage undesirable effects on surrounding development.
(Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.02  REGULATIONS.
   In accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the Planning Commission
shall be furnished a site plan of the proposed development in the following
circumstances:
   (a)    Prior to the creation of a use or erection of a building in the
districts and conditions cited below; and/or
   (b)    In connection with a rezoning request in any district, the Commission
may require a preliminary site development plan.
   (c)    Once a site plan is approved with or without conditions, the
developer is expected to follow such plan unless changes are proposed by the
developer, submitted to the Commission and approved with changes.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.03  SITE PLAN REQUIRED.
   A site plan shall be submitted unless specifically waived by the Planning
Commission or exempted in Section
1157.04 in connection with the following:
   Permitted uses in the following districts:
      R2-C       Residential District
      RM-D    Residential District
      PF       Public Facility District
      OB       Office Building District
      LB       Local Business District
      GB       General Business District
      CB       Central Business District
      CS       Commercial Service District
      GI       General Industrial District
      ITC       Industrial-Truck Center District
      PUD       All uses permitted under PUD designation.
   (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.
   
   1157.04  EXEMPTIONS.
   All site plans exempted from review by the Planning Commission shall be
subject to approval by the Zoning Enforcement Officer and City Engineer prior
to issuing a building permit. If the site plan submitted to the Zoning
Enforcement Officer and City Engineer is disapproved by either of the above,
the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the Commission. The following
shall be exempt from Commission review of their site plans:
   A single-family dwelling on a lot on which there exists no other building or
use and in a district where such use is permitted. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-
83.)
   1157.05  FINAL SITE PLAN.
   Each final site plan submitted shall contain the following information,
unless specifically waived by the Planning Commission, in whole or in part:
   (a)    The date, north arrow and scale. The scale shall be not more than one
inch equals 100 feet although supplementary site plans at a one foot equals
fifty feet or larger scale are encouraged;
   (b)    The name and firm address of the professional individual responsible
for the preparation of the site plan, including imprint of his professional
seal;
   (c)    The name and address of the property owner or petitioner, and proof
of ownership or option to purchase;
   (d)    A locational sketch drawn to scale;
   (e)    Legal and common or popular description of the subject property;
   (f)    The size in acres and square feet of the subject property;
   (g)    All lot and/or property lines are to be shown with bearings and
dimensions, including building setback lines on corner lots;
   (h)    The location of all existing structures within 100 feet of the
subject property's boundary;
   (i)    The location and dimensions of all existing and proposed structures
on the subject property;
   (j)    The location and dimensions of all existing and proposed drives,
sidewalks, curb openings, signs, exterior lighting, curbing, parking areas
including total number of parking spaces showing dimensions of a typical
parking space, unloading areas, recreation areas, common use areas and areas to
be conveyed for public use and purpose;
   (k)    The location, pavement width and right of way width of all abutting
roads, streets, alleys or easements. Land shall be reserved and shown on the
site plan for any major streets proposed on the Official Thoroughfare Plan that
would go through any part of the site;
   (l)    The existing zoning of all properties abutting the subject property;
   (m)   The location of all existing and proposed landscaping and vegetation
and the locations, heights and type of existing and proposed fences and walls;
   (n)    Size and location of existing and proposed hydrants and utilities
including proposed connections to public sewer or water supply systems;
   (o)    The location and size of all subsurface and surface water drainage
facilities, existing and proposed and any established floodplain areas, bodies
of water or other unbuildable areas if present on the site;
   (p)    For all site plans, contour intervals shall be shown at five foot
intervals; and
   (q)    Summary schedules and views should be affixed as applicable in
residential developments, which give the following data:
      (1)    The net residential site expressed in acres and in square feet,
including breakdowns of both measured for any sub-areas or staging areas;
      (2)    The number of dwelling units proposed, by type, including typical
floor plans for each type of dwelling unit;
(3)    The number of location, by code if necessary, of efficiency and one or
more bedroom units;
(4)    Typical elevation view of the front, side and rear of each type of
building; and
      (5)    Proposed density of the new residential site.
   (r)   Building Elevations: All proposed non-residential construction shall
provide a colored building elevation plan as part of the Final Site Plan review
showing the proposed architectural design and color for all sides of the
proposed building(s) or structure(s).  (Ord. 2017-40.  Passed 9-26-17.)
   1157.06  PRELIMINARY SITE DEVELOPMENT PLAN.
   For a Planned Unit Development or other larger scale developments where the
development shall be undertaken in several phases, a preliminary site
development plan may be submitted when initial approval is sought from the
Planning Commission and Council. If the initial approval is granted, a final
site plan incorporating all of the items specified in Section
1157.05 shall then be submitted to the Commission before the development of
each phase. Each preliminary site development plan shall contain the following
information unless specifically waived by the Commission in whole or in part:
   (a)    The date, north arrow and scale. The scale shall not be more than one
inch equals 100 feet;
   (b)    The name and firm address of the professional individual responsible
for the preparation of the site plan, including imprint of his professional
seal;
   (c)    The name and address of the property owner or petitioner, and proof
of ownership or option to purchase;
   (d)    A locational sketch drawn to scale;
   (e)    Legal and common or popular description of the subject property;
   (f)    The size in acres and square feet of the subject property;
   (g)    All lot and/or property lines are to be shown with bearings and
dimensions, including building setback lines on corner lots;
   (h)    The location of all existing structures within 100 feet of the
subject property's boundary;
   (i)    The location of all existing and proposed structures on the subject
property;
   (j)    The location and dimensions of all existing and proposed drives,
sidewalks, curbs openings, parking areas including total number of parking
spaces, recreation areas, common use areas and areas to be conveyed for public
use and purpose;
   (k)    The location, pavement width and right of way width of all abutting
roads, streets, alleys or easements. Land shall be reserved and shown on the
site plan for any major streets proposed on the Official Thoroughfare Plan that
would go through any part of the site;
   (l)    The existing zoning of all properties abutting the subject property;
   (m)    The preliminary site development plan shall be certified by a
registered professional engineer as to whether the preliminary layout of the
building can be adequately serviced by sanitary sewer, public water and storm
drainage facilities;
   (n)    The location and size of any established floodplain areas, bodies of
water or other unbuildable areas if present on the site;
   (o)    For all site plans, contour intervals shall be shown at five foot
intervals; and
   (p)    Summary schedules and views should be affixed as applicable in
residential developments, which gives the following data:
      (1)    The net residential site as expressed in acres and square feet,
including breakdowns of both measured for any sub-areas or staging areas;
      (2)    The number of dwelling units proposed, by type;
      (3)    Typical lot size dimensions if detached housing is contemplated;
      (4)    Typical elevation views of the front, side and rear of each type
of building; and
      (5)    Proposed density of the net residential site.
         (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.07  SUBMITTAL AND APPROVAL.
   (a)    The site plan, including additional or related information required
by the Planning Commission, shall be presented to the Zoning Enforcement
Officer by the petitioner or property owner or his designated agent in ten
copies. The Zoning Enforcement Officer shall cause the submittal to be placed
on the agenda of the next regular Commission meeting upon payment by applicant
of a fee.
   (b)    The Commission shall have the responsibility and authorization to
approve, disapprove or approve subject to conditions, the subject site plan in
accordance with this chapter and the purposes of this Zoning Ordinance.
   (c)    Any conditions or modifications desired by the Commission shall be
recorded in the minutes of the appropriate Commission meeting. The Commission
may, as it deems necessary to promote the purposes of this Ordinance, require
landscaping, walls, fences, drives and other improvements. When approved, at
least two copies of the final approved site plan shall be signed and dated by
the Secretary of the Planning Commission. When a variance is also involved,
these two copies shall also bear a dated signature of the Chairman of the Board
of Zoning Appeals. One of these two approved copies shall be kept on file by
the City Clerk, and the other approved copy shall be returned to the petitioner
or his designated representative. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.08  PLAT REQUIREMENTS.
   In those instances in which Ohio R.C. Chapter 711, and
Title Three Platting and Subdivision Regulations for the City of Sharonville is
involved, the owner shall, after site plan approval, submit the preliminary and
final plats to the proper officer in conformance with State and local laws and
ordinances, and in accordance with all other applicable codes, acts and
ordinances. Such plats shall remain in conformance with the approved site plan.
(Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.09  CHANGES IN THE APPROVED SITE PLAN.
   (a)    Major changes such as increased density, additional buildings, etc.,
to the approved final site plan shall be applied for by the applicant to the
Planning Commission. Any major changes approved in the final site plan shall be
recorded with the site plan and shall bear the signature of the Commission
Secretary and the date of the approval.
   (b)    Any minor changes, such as dimension changes, building location,
parking and drives, etc. may be approved by the Building Official. The approved
changes shall be noted on the site plan and bear the signature of the Building
Official.
   (c)    No changes are to be considered as a waiver of conditions or
covenants, and all rights to enforce such conditions or covenants against any
changes permitted by this Zoning Ordinance are expressly reserved. (Ord. 82-61.
Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1157.10  APPEAL.
   If any person shall be aggrieved by the action of the Planning Commission,
appeal in writing to Council may be taken within ten days after the date of
such action. Council shall fix and notify the appellant for a time and a place
for a public hearing to be published, in the newspaper of general circulation
in the City not less than thirty days prior to the hearing. All parties in
interest shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard thereat. After such
hearing Council shall affirm or reverse the action of the Commission, stating
its findings and the reasons for its action and a written copy of such
findings, reasons and action shall be given to the appellant. (Ord. 82-61.
Passed 1-11-83.)
   1157.11  REVIEW STANDARDS.
   The following standards shall be utilized by the Planning Commission in the
review of all site plans. These standards are intended to provide a frame of
reference for the applicant in the preparation of the site plans as well as for
the reviewing authority in making a judgment concerning them. These standards
shall not be regarded as inflexible requirements. They are not intended to
discourage creativity, invention or innovation.
   (a)    Landscape Preservation. The landscape shall be preserved in its
natural state, insofar as practical, by minimizing tree and soil removal, and
any grade changes shall be in keeping with the general appearance of
neighboring developed areas.
   (b)    Relation of Buildings to Environment. Proposed structures shall be
related harmoniously to the terrain and to the existing buildings in the
vicinity that have a visual relationship to the proposed buildings. The
achievement of such relationship may include the enclosure of space in
conjunction with other existing buildings or other proposed buildings and the
creation of focal points with respect to avenues of approach, terrain features
or other buildings.
   (c)    Drives, Parking and Circulation. With respect to vehicular and
pedestrian circulation, including walkways, interior drives and parking,
special attention shall be given to location and number of access points,
general interior circulation, separation of pedestrian and vehicular traffic
and arrangement of parking areas that are safe and convenient and, insofar as
practical, do not detract from the design of the proposed buildings and
structures and the neighboring properties.
   (d)    Surface Water Drainage. All surface water drainage plans shall
conform to the Water Retention Ordinance for the City of Sharonville (see
Ordinance No. 80-46). A letter from the City shall be obtained indicating
conformance.
   (e)    Utility Service. Any utility installations remaining above ground
shall be located so as to have a harmonious relationship to neighboring
properties and the site.
   (f)    Advertising Features. The size, location and lighting of all
permanent signs and outdoor advertising structures or features shall be
consistent with the requirements of Chapter
1153.
   (g)    Special Features. Exposed storage areas, exposed machinery
installations, service areas, truck loading areas, utility buildings and
structures, and similar accessory areas shall be subject to such setbacks,
screen plantings or other screening methods as shall reasonably be required to
prevent their being incongruous with the existing or contemplated environment
and the surrounding properties.
   (h)    Other. Public health, safety and general welfare shall also be
considered.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
1157.12  ARCHITECTURAL AND BUILDING DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (a)   Purpose.  The purpose of this section is to establish architectural
and building design standards that encourage higher quality development and
function in order to protect property values, and protect real estate from
impairment or destruction of value. These architectural and building design
criteria can encourage quality development through the use of a variety of
design and site techniques while continuing to provide for a wide range of
economic development.
   (b)   Applicability.
      (1)   This section shall apply to all new buildings and development in
the Local Business (LB), General Business (GB), and Office Building (OB) zoning
districts and any accessory structure or use over 500 square feet in floor area
located within the LB, GB, or OB zoning district.
      (2)   All new buildings shall be subject to review by the Planning
Commission in accordance with Chapter
1157 Site Plan Review to ensure conformance with this section.
   (c)   General Requirements for All Nonresidential Buildings in the LB, GB
and OB Districts.
      (1)   Buildings should generally be parallel to the street they front,
unless an alternate orientation is consistent with existing adjacent
development and is approved by the Planning Commission during site plan review.
      (2)   The primary entrances of buildings should be oriented:
         A.   Towards a street along the perimeter of the development or
towards a public space, if located adjacent to the proposed project; or
         B.   Towards streets in the interior of the development if none of the
building's facades has frontage on a public street; or
         C.   As approved by the Planning Commission during Site Plan Review
process.
      (3)   Building Facades.
         A.   Blank building walls visible from public streets (including
alleys adjacent to non-residential or mixed use buildings) are prohibited.
These requirements shall not generally apply to those walls that are not
visible from a street or are completely hidden due to topography or natural
features preserved as open space.
      (4)   Building Materials.
         A.   A combination of materials, textures, colors, and finishes should
be utilized to create visual interest. Vinyl siding and corrugated metal or
steel siding material shall be prohibited unless specially approved by the
Planning Commission during Site Plan Review.
      (5)   Mechanical Equipment.
         A.   Wall mounted mechanical, electrical, communication equipment,
downspouts, gutters, service doors, and other building-mounted utility
fixtures, shall be painted and maintained to match the building or be screened
from view.  All rooftop mechanical equipment, unless screened from view, should
match the color of the structure or be visually compatible with the structure.
         B.   Mechanical equipment such as transformers and HVAC units should
not be located in front yards, unless appropriately screened from view.
         C.   All mechanical equipment, including both ground-mounted and roof-
mounted equipment, shall be screened from view from adjacent public rights-of-
way, as well as from all property zoned or used for residential purposes. 
         D.   Screening elements may include walls (same material and color as
principal structure), landscaping, mounds, parapets or enclosures constructed
of the same materials used on the majority of the principal structure or any
combination or as otherwise approved or required during site plan review. (See
Figure I-A)
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3834.jpg]
 
                    (Figure I-A)
   (d)   Architectural Standards for the LB, GB, and OB Zoning Districts.  The
following shall apply to all nonresidential buildings or mixed-use buildings in
the LB, GB, and OB districts unless specifically stated.
      (1)   Building Design and Mass.
         A.   All architectural elevations of principal buildings shall consist
of a base, a body, and a cap (See Figure I-B.).
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3838.jpg]
 
         
                           ( Figure I-B )
         B.   The base shall occupy the lowest portion of the elevation, and
should have a height no less than 8% of the average wall height.  The base
shall be composed of brick, tile, stone or cast or cultured stone, concrete or
pre-fab concrete panels, split-face block, or other material if specially
approved by the Planning Commission during Site Plan Review.
         C.   The body shall occupy the middle portion of the elevation, and
should have a height no less than 60% of the average wall height.  The body may
be composed of brick, stone, cast or cultured stone, stucco (EFIS), or other
material if specially approved by the Planning Commission during Site Plan
Review.
         D.   The cap shall occupy the highest portion of the elevation,
excluding the roof, and should have a height no less than eight percent 8% of
the average wall height, not to exceed the height of the base.  The cap may
composed of brick, tile stone or cast or cultured stone, concrete or pre-fab
concrete panels stucco (EFIS), or other material if specially approved by the
Planning Commission during Site Plan Review.
         E.   The cap shall consist of at least one (1) of the following
architectural features: (See Figures i-v)
            i.   A cornice;
            ii.   A parapet;
            iii.   An awning;
            iv.   A canopy; or
            v.   Eaves.
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3843.jpg]
 
 
                    Figure  i. Cornice                                         
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3849.jpg]
 
Figure ii. Parapet
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3856.jpg]
 
 
  Figure iii. Awning       
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3864.jpg]
 
   
Figure iv. Canopy                       
   
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3873.jpg]
 
Figure v. Eaves
         F.   The base and cap shall be clearly distinguishable from the body
through changes in color, material, pattern, profile, or texture. 
         G.   This section shall not be construed to prohibit metal roofs,
flashing, aluminum storefront associated with windows, or high-quality metal
siding applications such as copper, bronze, or other decorative metal.
      (2)   Architectural elevations for all new buildings shall include
design, massing, materials, shape, and scale that creates a unified design on
the premises.
      (3)   Exposed metal panels (such as copper, bronze, or other decorative
metal) may be permitted on building elevations in the LB, GB and OB districts
as an accent or minor exterior material.
      (4)   Façade Massing.
         A.   Offset Required
Facades that are visible from a public street and that are sixty feet wide or
wider shall incorporate wall offsets of at least two feet in depth (projections
or recesses) a minimum of every forty feet.  Each required offset shall have a
minimum width of twenty feet. (See Figure I-C)
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3883.jpg]
 
                       
                      (Figure I-C)
         B.   Offset Alternative
The following alternatives, generally following the same dimensional standards
as of offset requirements, can be used in place of the required front façade
offsets. (See Figure I-D)
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/ab82d8f1db4a6bc63007897521cd6515d079fa03/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3894.jpg]   
 
                  ( Figure I-D )
            i.   Façade material changes following the same dimensional
standards as the offset requirements; or
            iii.   Pilasters having a minimum depth of one foot, minimum width
of one foot, and a minimum height of 80 % of the facades height
      (5)   Wall Openings (Doors and Windows).
         A.   Blank walls, those devoid of openings such as windows and
transparent doors, shall be prohibited on the front facade of any building. In
no case shall a building have blank walls parallel to a public street or to its
tangent, if the street is curved.
         B.   Building elevations that are visible from a public street should
contain window and door openings that occupy at least 30 % of the total wall
surface area. The bottom edge of the windows shall not be higher than three
feet above grade on the ground floor.
         C.   Doors and windows should be positioned to create a uniform
pattern or visual rhythm along the building elevation.
         D.   All doors and windows shall be articulated through the use of
lintels, sills, and thresholds.
         E.   Doors and windows shall be rectangular in shape and vertical in
orientation.
         F.   The pattern of architectural features, such as windows and doors,
shall be placed upon the facade of a building in a pattern that creates a
building fenestration that has a constant rhythm, a harmonious appearance, and
is proportional to one another and surrounding buildings.
         G.   These requirements shall apply to all street facing building
facades and the first 20% of any non-street facing façade located perpendicular
to any street.
      (6)   Roof Styles.
         A.   The height of any pitched roof shall not exceed one-half of the
overall building height.
         B.   Roof Line Changes
            i.   Roofline changes shall include changes in roof planes or
changes in the top of a parapet wall, such as extending the top of pilasters
above the top of the parapet wall.
            ii.   When roofline changes are included on a façade that
incorporates wall offsets or material or color changes, roof line changes shall
be vertically aligned with the corresponding wall offset or material or color
changes.
         C.   Flat Roofs
            i.   When flat roofs are used, parapet walls with three-dimensional
cornice treatments shall conceal them. The cornice shall include a
perpendicular projection a minimum of eight inches from the parapet façade
plane.
            ii.   Thin parapets that extend more than two feet above the roof
and have a depth of less than two feet from the façade surface, are prohibited.
      (7)   Refuse Facilities.
Refuse Facilities shall be enclosed by fences or walls and shall be compatible
with the architectural materials and patterns of the principal structure or be
comprised of a material as approved by  the Planning Commission during Site
Plan Review.
      (8)   Modification or Waiver of this Section.
The requirements of this Section may be modified or waived upon specific review
and approval by the Planning Commission during Site Plan Review process. 
         (Ord. 2018-11.  Passed 4-24-18.)
CHAPTER 1159
Conditional Use Permits
1159.01   Purpose.
1159.02   Conditional use approval procedures.
1159.03   Conditional use standards.
1159.04   Design standards.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Definitions, general  - see P. & Z. Ch.
1123
      Conditional use defined - see P. & Z.
1127.02(c)
   1159.01  PURPOSE.
   (a)   This section provides a set of procedures and standards for
conditional use of land or structures, which, because of their unique
characteristics, require special considerations in relation to the welfare of
adjacent properties and the community as a whole.
   (b)   Conditional use permits shall be required for certain types of main
uses as defined in Chapters
1131 to
1139, generally publicly-operated or a facility which affects the public
interest.  Such use may be permitted and desirable in certain districts, but
not without consideration in each case of the effect of the use upon
neighboring land and the public need for the particular use at the particular
location.  The application of the planning standards for determining the
location and extent of such use is a planning function, and not in the nature
of a variance or appeal.
   (c)   For purposes of this Zoning Ordinance, the following conditional use
categories are identified which, together with cited conditional uses within
the various districts, are operational under the conditions and standards of
Chapter
1157:
      (1)   Public works facilities such as public water supply reservoir,
tower and pumping station and public sewage treatment works in residential
districts;
      (2)   Home occupations in residential districts;
      (3)   Parking and garage facilities in residential districts;
      (4)   Home professional offices in residential districts;
      (5)   Room houses, fraternal organizations and private clubs in an RM-
D residential district;
      (6)   Freestanding television antennae and satellite dish antennae in all
districts;
      (7)   Temporary buildings and enclosures in residential districts;
      (8)   Day care centers in a local business district;
      (9)   Motels, assembly halls, bus passenger stations and hotels in local
business district;
      (10)   Automotive service stations in the General Business District;
      (11)   Bulk distribution station for gasoline and oil in the general
industrial district;
      (12)   Drive-in restaurants; and

   1159.02  CONDITIONAL USE APPROVAL PROCEDURES.
   The application for a conditional use shall be submitted and processed under
the following procedures:
   (a)   An application shall be submitted through the Zoning Enforcement
Officer on a special form for that purpose.  Each application shall be
accompanied by the payment of a fee as established by Council.  In the event
the allowance of a desired use requires both a rezoning and permission for a
conditional use, both requests may be submitted jointly subject to the
following:
      (1)   The ordinance procedures for each shall be followed as specified;
and
      (2)   All applicable standards and specifications required by the
ordinance shall be observed.
   (b)   The following is required for all conditional uses:
      (1)   The application shall be completed in full by the applicant,
including a statement that Chapter
1159 can be complied with; and
      (2)   A complete site plan as specified in Section
1157.05 for structural change.
   (c)   The application, together with all required data, shall be transmitted
to the Planning Commission for review.
      (1)   At the initiative of the Commission, or upon the request of the
applicant for conditional use authorization, or a property owner or the
occupant of a structure located within 300 feet of the boundary of the property
being considered for a conditional use, a public hearing with notification as
required for a notice of a request for conditional use approval may be held
before a decision on the request which is based on discretionary grounds.  If
the applicant or the Commission requests a public hearing, only notification of
the public hearing need be made.  A decision on a conditional use request shall
not be made unless notification of the request for conditional use approval, or
notification of a public hearing on a conditional use request is given as may
be required by this section.
      (2)   The Commission may deny, approve or approve with conditions,
requests for conditional use approval.  The decision on a conditional use shall
be incorporated in a statement of conclusions relative to the request under
consideration.  The decision shall specify the basis for the decision, and any
conditions imposed.
   (d)   A conditional use permit granted pursuant to this chapter, shall be
valid for a  period of one year from the date of approval. If construction has
not commenced and proceeded meaningfully toward completion by the end of this
one year period, Director of Community Development shall notify the applicant
in writing of the expiration of approval for the conditional use.
   (e)    The Commission shall have the authority to revoke any conditional use
permit after the applicant has failed to comply with any of the applicable
requirements of this chapter, or any other applicable sections of this Zoning
Ordinance.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1159.03  CONDITIONAL USE STANDARDS.
   An application for a conditional use permit shall not be approved unless the
following conditions and standards are complied with as set forth for the
following districts:
   (a)    Residential Districts.
      (1)    That the proposed use is properly located in relation to any
adopted Land Use or Thoroughfare Plan, particularly to the collector and local
street systems and pedestrian circulation;
      (2)    That when located on a local street, the proposed use shall not
noticeably increase traffic through a residential neighborhood, in the opinion
of the Planning Commission;
      (3)    That the location, design and operation of such use shall not
discourage the appropriate development or impair the value of the surrounding
residential districts; and
      (4)    That for temporary structures every conditional use permit shall
be reviewed every six months and may be renewed only while the construction
operations are pursued diligently.
   (b)   Business, Research, Service and Industrial Districts.
      (1)    That the proposed use be necessary to serve the community needs
and that existing similar facilities located in a less restrictive, or more
remote districts in which the use may be permitted by right, are inadequate;
      (2)    That the proposed use not be closer than appropriate in the
particular situation to schools, churches and other places of assembly;
      (3)    That the location, extent and intensity of the proposed use, shall
be such that its operation shall not be objectionable to nearby dwellings by
reason of noise, smoke, dust, odors, fumes, vibrations or glare than is normal
or is permitted by the performance standards of the district;
      (4)    That the proposed use shall form a harmonious part of the
business, research, service and industrial district, taking into account among
others, convenience of access and relationship of one use to another;
      (5)    That the proposed use shall be permitted in a more restrictive
district than in which it is permitted by right only because of its limited
extent, modern equipment and processes; and
      (6)    That the hours of operation concentration of vehicles in
connection with proposed use shall not be more hazardous or dangerous than the
normal traffic of the district. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1159.04  DESIGN STANDARDS.
   Those uses specified in Section
1159.01 as permitted by a conditional use permit in accordance with this Zoning
Ordinance, shall be subject to the requirements of that district in which such
use is located, in addition to all the applicable conditions, standards and
regulations regarding site design and development as are cited in the
following:
   (a)    Public Works Facilities. Public work facilities such as public water
supply reservoir, tower and pumping station, public sewage treatment works: The
proposed use shall comply with the standards as set forth in Section
1159.03.
   (b)    Home Occupations in Residential Districts. Including home crafts such
as baking, dressmaking, millinery, weaving, home decorating; services such as
repairing furniture and radios and sharpening tools; office space for business
or services such as real estate, selling or taking orders for merchandise and
contracting work, provided:
      (1)    Only members of the family residing within the dwelling shall work
therein;
      (2)    The occupation is conducted wholly within a building and the space
used for production and sale does not occupy more than twenty-five percent
(25%) of the floor area of a detached building;
      (3)    No merchandise shall be sold except that which is produced or
processed on the premises;
      (4)    No mechanical equipment shall be used which shall create any dust,
noise, odors, glare, vibrations or electrical disturbances beyond the lot;
      (5)    The residential character of the dwelling exterior or accessory
building shall not be changed; and
      (6)    Trucks or other mobile equipment shall not be parked overnight in
driveways or open yards, and the occupations do not attract any greater number
of automobiles to the premise than permitted in accordance with the provisions
of Sections
1151.05 and
1151.08.
      (7)   A letter from each affected neighbor is required.  (Please provide
below.)
      (8)   Please attach a statement explaining the type of business you are
operating from your residence.

   (g)    Temporary Buildings and Enclosures in Residential Districts.
Buildings and enclosures shall be deemed necessary for construction operations
of the dwellings and accessory buildings of the area for which a building
permit has been issued.
      (1)    Such structures shall be limited to offices, yards and buildings
for the storage of lumber, equipment and other building material and workshops
for prefabricating building components.
      (2)    The operations and activities carried on within such structure
shall not adversely affect the use of nearby dwellings by reason of noise,
smoke, dust, odor, fumes, vibration, electrical disturbance or glare to a
greater extent than normal in a residential district that is being developed.
      (3)    The hours of operation shall be restricted to the hours between 7:
00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., and the concentration of vehicles attracted to the
premises in connection with such use shall not be more hazardous than normal
traffic in a residential district that is being developed.
      (4)    All temporary structures shall be located at least 100 feet from
the nearest occupied residential dwelling.
      (5)    All structures and yard storage areas shall be enclosed by a
fence.
   (h)    Day Care Centers in a Local Business District.
      (1)    No dormitory facilities shall be permitted.
      (2)    For each child cared for, there shall be provided, equipped and
maintained, on the premises, a minimum of 150 square feet of usable outdoor
play area, minimum total area of 5,000 square feet per facility, in addition to
the minimum lot requirements of the district in which the use is located.
      (3)    The outdoor play area shall be fenced in for safety and screened
by a heavily planted greenbelt from any abutting residential uses.
   (i)    Main Uses Enumerated in the General Business District in Local
Business District.
The proposed use shall comply with standards as set forth in Section
1159.03(b).
   (j)    Automotive Service Stations in all Business Districts.
      (1)    No subject facility existing on the effective date of this Zoning
Ordinance shall be structurally altered so as to provide a lesser degree of
conformity with the provisions of this section than existed on such date.
(EDITOR'S NOTE: The effective date of Zoning Ordinance 82-61 is February 10,
1983.)
      (2)    Service stations shall be located not less than fifty feet from
any right-of- way line or from any side or rear lot line abutting residentially
zoned property unless separated therefrom by a street or alley.
      (3)    Where adjoining residentially used or zoned property, a solid wall
or solid fence having a minimum height of four feet and a maximum height of six
feet shall be erected and maintained along the connecting interior lot line, or
if separated by an alley, then along the alley lot line.
      (4)    The minimum frontage shall be 150 feet and the minimum lot area
shall be 32,000 square feet.
      (5)    Pump islands shall be a minimum of thirty-five feet from any
public right of way or lot line.
      (6)    Driveways shall be a minimum of twenty-seven feet from street
intersections. This distance shall be measured along the curb line from the
point of intersection of street right-of-way lines. Driveways shall be a
minimum of ten feet from abutting properties as measured along the curbline.
      (7)    Curb cuts shall not exceed thirty-six feet at curb line and thirty
feet at lot line. The angle of driveway approaches shall not be less than
forty-five degrees from lot line.
      (8)    Access drives or approach aprons shall not open or extend into or
across alleys.
      (9)    Driveways, service areas and parking areas shall be provided with
pavement having a bituminous or Portland cement binder so as to provide a
permanent, durable and dustless surface and shall be so graded and drained as
to dispose of all surface water accumulated within the area.
      (10)    All exterior lighting, including signs, shall be erected and
hooded so as to shield the glare of such lights from view by adjacent
properties. There shall be no flashing or revolving lights.
      (11)    Accessory buildings shall not be permitted.
      (12)    All repair work shall be done within the building.
      (13)    All storage of materials, merchandise and equipment other than
liquid fuel shall be within the building.
      (14)    All lubrication, repair and servicing equipment other than liquid
fuel shall be within the building.
      (15)    All outside storage areas for trash, used tires, auto parts and
similar items shall be enclosed by a six foot high solid wall or fence.
      (16)    No operator shall permit outside storage of automobiles, trucks
or trailers for a period in excess of seventy-two hours.
      (17)    The rental of trucks, trailers and any other vehicles on the
premises is expressly prohibited without specific approval by the Planning
Commission. If such use is permitted, proper screening, landscaping and
additional parking area shall be provided in accordance with the requirements
set forth by the Commission.
      (18)    Gasoline and other flammable mixtures shall not be used to wash
down the premises.
      (19)    Sanitary drains located on the premises without approved
separators in the trap are prohibited.
      (20)   No operator shall deposit or cause to be deposited upon the
roadways adjacent to the premises, snow, ice or other debris cleared from the
premises.
      (21)    In the event that an automotive service station has been
abandoned or not used as a vehicle service station for a period of one year,
any application to operate such premises as an automotive service station shall
be considered as an application for a new automotive service station.
      (22)    In the event that an automotive service station has been
abandoned or not used for a period of more than one year, all underground
gasoline storage tanks shall be removed from the premises. Upon a finding by
the Zoning Enforcement Officer that practical difficulties or unnecessary
hardships preclude removal of gasoline storage tanks in the ground as in the
case of structures above or sub-grade structures near the tank, the Zoning
Enforcement Officer may, upon application to him in writing, authorize that in
lieu of removal of the tanks, the applicant may be permitted to fill the tank
or tanks with sand, liquid concrete or other noncombustible solid material
approved by the Zoning Enforcement Officer.
   (k)    Bulk Distribution Station for Gasoline and Oil in the General
Industrial District.
The proposed use shall comply with the standards as set forth in Section
1159.03(b) and the performance standard as identified in the General Industrial
District, Section 1137.25.
   (l)    Drive-In Restaurants.
      (1)    The main and accessory buildings shall be set back a minimum of
sixty feet from any adjacent right-of-way line or residential property line.
      (2)    Public access to the site shall be located at least seventy-five
feet from any intersection as measured from the nearest right-of-way line to
the near edge of such access.
(3)    A six foot high masonry site obscuring wall shall be provided adjacent
to residential districts.
   (m)    Funeral Homes.
      (1)    A minimum lot area of one acre with a minimum width of 150 feet.
      (2)    A well-designed and landscaped off-street vehicle assembly area
shall be provided in support of funeral procession activity. This area shall be
in addition to required off-street parking area or its related maneuvering
space.
      (3)    A caretaker's residence may be provided within the principal
building.
      (4)    The proposed site shall front upon an arterial or collector street
as classified by the Official Thoroughfare Plan for the City. All ingress and
egress shall be from such thoroughfare. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   (n)   Self Service Storage Facilities. Not exceeding fifty percent (50%) of
lot or parcel coverage, which are authorized as a conditional use specific
zoning districts shall comply with the following standards:
      (1)    Site plan to show property lines, setbacks, street paving, curb
cuts, landscaping, location of all structures including buildings, designated
parking spaces, travel lanes, drainage areas and structures, location of walls
and fences.
      (2)    Lot shall not front on a local residential road nor shall access
be permitted to a local residential road.
      (3)    Facility shall be used only for dead storage of materials or
articles and shall not be used for assembly, fabrication, processing or repair
of any kind.
      (4)    No business or sales shall be conducted from the storage unit. Nor
shall the facility be used for practice rooms, meeting rooms, etc.
      (5)    No exterior storage shall be permitted.
      (6)    Storage of explosive or highly flammable material shall be
prohibited. Commercial transfer and active storage operations shall not be
permitted nor shall the space be used for service or repair. Garage sales and/
or flea markets are prohibited.
      (7)    All such facilities shall provide for and maintain a caretaker's
quarters to ward against inferior after-hour activities.
      (8)    Facilities shall be screened with landscape material on all
property boundaries which abut residential districts.
      (9)    Property shall be enclosed with a six foot high fence and shall
have a single controlled entrance and exit.
      (10)    Height of storage buildings shall not exceed one story.
      (11)    All light shall be shielded to direct lights onto the facility
and away from adjacent property, however, should be of sufficient intensity to
discourage vandalism and theft. (Ord. 84-4. Passed 2-28-84.)
   (o)    Electronic Message Center (EMC)  in all Zoning Districts where
Electronic Message Center Signs are Permitted.  Conditional Use Permits may be
issued by the Department of Community Development when submitted on approved
forms by the Applicant.  The following conditions must be met in order for the
Applicant to receive a valid Conditional Use Permit for Electronic Message
Center without the need for a hearing before the Sharonville Planning
Commission:
      (1)   Any electronic message display shall automatically dim to a
corresponding reduction in ambient light depending on the time of day or
weather conditions;
      (2)   Any electronic message display shall be static and may not display
animated, scrolling, moving or flashing messages or video which simulates such
animation.
      (3)   Each static message shall remain on the screen for not less than
eight seconds and shall take no longer than two seconds to change;
      (4)   EMC signs shall be maintained in accordance with Section
1153.16 (Maintenance of Signs) of the Sharonville Zoning Code; and
      (5)   Any EMC application which does not meet the listed conditions shall
be submitted by the Department of Community Development to the Sharonville
Planning Commission for review and determination as set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 2014-39.  Passed 1-13-15; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   (p)    The following conditions shall be met in order to maintain a valid
conditional use permit for a Solid Fence:
      (1)   Fence is allowed in the rear yard only.
      (2)   Solid fence may be no higher than 6'.
      (3)   Fence must be weather resistant and must be well maintained.
      (4)   Finished side of the fence must face the abutting properties.
      (5)   There may be only a single fence.  No back-to-back fences.
         Exception: Back-to-back fences are permitted with a separation of 2'-
6" or greater.
      (6)   A signature from each affected neighbor is required.  (Please
provide below.)

   (q)    Day care centers in Office Building Districts provided that:
      (1)    No dormitory facilities shall be permitted.
      (2)    For each child cared for, there shall be provided, equipped and
maintained, on the premises, a minimum of 150 square feet of usable outdoor
play area with a minimum total area of 5,000 square feet per facility, in
addition to the minimum lot requirements of the district in which the use is
located.
      (3)   The outdoor play area shall be fenced in for safety and screened by
a heavily planted greenbelt from any abutting residential uses.
      (4)   The day care facility shall be designed and planned for the primary
use of the tenants and employees of tenants of the office building complex
within which it is located, and it is presumed that such primary use shall
involve greater than fifty percent (50%) of tenant and employee usage.
         (Ord. 86-60.  Passed 9-30-86.)
   (r)   Day-Care Centers in Commercial Service Districts.  Day-care centers
shall be permitted in Commercial Service Districts provided that:
      (1)   The day-care center is not adjacent to or in the same physical
structure where the uses delineated in Section
1137.02(a)(2)A., C. and D. are carried out;
      (2)   No dormitory facilities shall be permitted;
      (3)   For each child cared for, there shall be provided, equipped and
maintained on the premises a minimum of 150 square feet of usable outdoor play
area with a minimum lot requirement of the district in which the use is
located;
      (4)   The outdoor play area shall be fenced in for safety.
   (s)   Veterinarian clinics shall be permitted in a general business district
as long as no kennels or other means of boarding animals is permitted.
   (t)   Adult Entertainment Businesses or Sexually Oriented Businesses in
Commercial Service Districts.  Adult entertainment businesses and sexually
oriented businesses shall be permitted in Commercial Service Districts provided
that each of the following conditions have been complied with:
(1)   The parcel of land upon which the adult entertainment business or
sexually oriented business is located shall be at least 1,000 feet in distance
from all parcels of land having upon them the following uses:  a parcel of land
on which a liquor permit exists; a parcel of land containing a church which
regularly operates religious services; a parcel of land containing a day care
center or nursery school; a parcel of land containing a hotel or motel; a
parcel of land containing a public park or playground; a parcel of land
containing a library; a parcel of land containing another adult entertainment
business or sexually oriented business; and a parcel of land containing a
residential use, including retirement homes, nursing homes, multiple family
structures, tourist homes, townhouses, and single family homes.
(2)   The zoning authority of the City of Sharonville is provided with
confirmation that all of the applicable State, County and local health district
regulations have been satisfied.
(3)   Prior to commencing business, the applicant provides satisfactory
information, including the following data:
         A.   The address and legal description of the premises upon which the
business is to be located;
         B.   The identification of the individual acting as applicant, and
whether he or she is applying in his or her individual capacity, or on behalf
of a business entity, including partnership (general partnership or limited
partnership), corporation, limited liability company, or any other business
entity;
C.   The name, date of birth and social security number of all owners,
partners, and limited partners, shareholders if a corporation, and owners of
limited liability companies;
         D.   If a business entity (including corporation, limited or general
partnership, and limited liability company), the address of the principal place
of business of the entity and the name and address of the statutory agent in
the State of Ohio upon whom service of process may be issued:
         E.   The name, date of birth and social security number of each
employee (or contemplated employee) who will be employed in the business
enterprise;
         F.   A statement regarding each of the owners and the applicant
identifying all prior Ohio or other State liquor permit violations or
revocations involving such individuals;
         G.   A description of the physical layout of the structure, including
the exterior signage, exterior lighting, and exterior sound system, if any, and
the exterior parking requirements. The signage and parking requirements shall
be as provided in Chapter
1151 (Parking and Loading Facilities) and Section
1153.11 (Signs/Industrial District);
         H.   A statement by the applicant on behalf of himself or herself and
on behalf of all owners that the City Police Department is authorized to
conduct a background check on the applicant, all owners, and employees
regarding prior criminal activity, if any, and prior liquor permit violations.
      (4)   No individual under age eighteen may be employed in an adult
entertainment business establishment;
      (5)   No interior portion of the adult entertainment business may be
visible from the outside, either through windows, doors or any other openings:
      (6)   The City Planning Commission shall act upon the application for
conditional use permit for adult entertainment businesses within thirty days
after the time when all required data has been submitted to it.
      (7)   No sexually oriented business shall be or remain open for business
between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. on any day, except that a sexually
oriented business that holds a liquor permit pursuant to Chapter 4303 of the
Ohio Revised Code may remain open until the hour specified in that permit if it
does not conduct, offer, or allow sexually oriented entertainment activity in
which the performers appear nude.
      (8)   No patron who is not a member of the employee's immediate family
shall knowingly touch any employee while that employee is nude or semi-nude or
touch the clothing of any employee while that employee is nude or semi-nude. 
      (9)   No employee who regularly appears nude or semi-nude on the premises
of a sexually oriented business, while on the premises of that sexually
oriented business and while nude or semi-nude, shall knowingly touch a patron
who is not a member of the employee's immediate family or another employee who
is not a member of the employee's immediate family or the clothing of a patron
who is not a member of the employee's immediate family or another employ who is
not a member of the employee's immediate family or another employee who is not
a member of the employee's immediate family to touch the employee or the
clothing of the employee.
      (10)   Whoever violates Condition 7 of this section is guilty of
illegally operating a sexually oriented business, a misdemeanor of the first
degree.
      (11)   Whoever violates division (8) of this section is guilty of illegal
sexually oriented activity in a sexually oriented business.  If the offender
touches a specified anatomical area of the patron or employee, or the clothing
covering a specified anatomical area, a violation of division (8) of this
section is a misdemeanor of the first degree. If the offender does not touch a
specified anatomical area of the patron or employee, or the clothing covering a
specified anatomical area, a violation of division (8) of this section is a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
         (Ord. 2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.) 
   (u)   Cellular or Wireless Personal Communication System.
   (v)   Sidewalk Signs and Business Display in Central Business and General
Business- Apartment Districts.  Sidewalk signs may be permitted, and business
items may be displayed on sidewalks which are too narrow in such zoning
districts under specifications and plans approved by the Sharonville Planning
Commission such that a reasonable sign, display or vendor location may be
permitted without undue burden on free pedestrian movement on such sidewalk.
   (w)   Residential parking facilities for recreational vehicle, boat on a
trailer or one trailer greater than 24 feet in length or other vehicles not
specifically listed in this Zoning Ordinance.
The following chart should be used as a recommendation to the Planning
Commission to establish setbacks from property lines:

                                                      Yard Setback

Note:    In case of where the topography or other physical features of the
tract or its relation to surrounding property may make complete compliance with
the yard setback recommendations as prescribed in this section unnecessary or
undesirable, the City Planning Commission may modify such recommendation to the
extent warranted by such conditions, provided the surrounding property and the
public welfare are adequately protected.
   (x)   Churches and Similar Places of Religious Assembly in Support Mixed-
Downtown (SM-D) District.  Consistent with the Vision and Goals of the Downtown
Strategic Master Plan, limited Conditional Use approval of Churches and similar
places of religious assembly would provide places of destination and offer
complementary uses to the district.  Consideration should be given to the SM-
D district as a whole, and approvals should be proportioned to allow a larger
percentage of residential and commercial uses overall.    The following
standards and criteria shall be considered as part of the approval process:
      (1)   Front, side, and rear yard setbacks shall be consistent with those
established in Section
1135.04, Schedule of Minimum Yard and Setback Dimensions as listed for Support
Mixed Use.
      (2)   Density (land coverage) shall be consistent with the Central
Business District, or 25% of total area of parcel being developed.  Increases
may be approved by Planning Commission as described in Section
1135.04 (b). 
      (3)   Height shall be consistent with the Central Business District, or
three stories/thirty-five feet.  Increases may be approved by Planning
Commission as described in Section
1135.04 (d).
      (4)   Conditional Use approvals for churches and similar places of
religious assembly shall not exceed 6% of total land area in the District,
either for single or multiple sites.  Once approvals are granted that total 6%
of total land area in the District, no more approvals for Churches and Similar
Places of Religious Assembly shall be granted.  The SM-D District contains
approximately 16.5 acres.  6% equals approximately 1 acre. 
      (5)   Applications for Conditional Use approval shall first be reviewed
by the Architectural Review Board.  Design of the proposed building and grounds
shall be consistent with the general appearance of the downtown and in
accordance with the Standards and Criteria in Chapter
1162 of the Sharonville Zoning Code.
      (6)   Parking shall be in compliance with Chapter
1151, Parking and Loading Facilities, which may, upon Planning Commission
approval, include provisions and allowances for shared parking and the use of
available Municipal parking.
         (Ord. 2012-8.  Passed 4-10-12; Ord. 2016-1.  Passed 2-23-16.)

   1161.01  INTENT.
   (a)    Administrative procedures for administering, interpreting and
enforcing this Zoning Ordinance are herein established in order to achieve,
among others, the following
purposes:
      (1)    To provide for the review of an application for a building permit;
      (2)    To provide for the inclusion of necessary facilities, services and
other uncommon uses through conditional use permits;
      (3)    To provide the inclusion of uses which are uncommon but which have
characteristics similar to permitted main uses;
      (4)    To provide that no work shall be started on the relocation,
construction, reconstruction or structural alteration of a building until the
proposed building or use is found to comply with all the provisions of this
Ordinance;
      (5)    To assure that in the construction of new buildings, alterations
or change of use are complete, and all required provisions have been complied
with by requiring a certificate before occupancy;
      (6)    To provide for the enforcement of this Ordinance through measures
where there is noncompliance, to keep records of actions in regards to the
enforcement of the Ordinance; and
      (7)    To provide supplementary administrative procedures in conformity
with the objectives of the City General Plan and this Ordinance.
   (b)    In administering this Ordinance, the provisions shall be regarded as
establishing minimum requirements and shall be used specifically to further the
underlying purposes, objectives and intent set forth in the preamble to each
chapter.
   (c)    The relationship of this Ordinance to other laws, rules and
regulations and the relationship if two or more specific provisions of this
Ordinance apply to the same subject are set forth in Section
1121.04. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1161.02  GENERAL PROCEDURES.
   (a)    The administration of this Zoning Ordinance is vested in the
following officials, commissions and boards of the City:
      (1)    Planning Commission;
      (2)    Safety-Service Director;
      (3)    Director of Community Development;
      (4)    City Engineer;
      (5)    The City Architect;
      (6)    Board of Zoning Appeals;
      (7)    The Architectural Review Board;
      (8)    Zoning Enforcement Officer; and
      (9)    Building Official.
   (b)    Compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance shall be obtained
by:
      (1)    Applying for and the issuance of a building permit including the
following, if applicable:
         A.    Site plan review;
         B.    Application and approval for PUD;
         C.    Application for a conditional use permit;
         D.    Application for determination of similar use; and
         E.    Appeal for an interpretation or a request for a variance.
      (2)    Application for a certificate of occupancy issued upon completion
of the building or land improvement.
   (c)    Enforcement of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be obtained by
inspection and order for removal of violations. Failure to comply with such
order shall constitute an offense which may be followed with civil action.
(Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1161.03  BUILDING PERMIT.
   Excavations for buildings or site improvements shall not be started, or
buildings or structures, or parts thereof, shall not be erected, altered or
moved until a building permit has been applied for and issued by the Building
Official.
   (a)    Approval of Site Plans. Whenever a site plan has been submitted by
the developer as required by this Zoning Ordinance, the preliminary plan and
final plan of the project area shall have been approved by the Planning
Commission, and, in the case of a Planned Unit Development (PUD) by Council,
before a building permit may be issued by the Building Official.
   (b)    Compliance to Zoning Regulations. Permits for the construction of a
building or improvements or change in use may be issued by the Safety-Service
Director only if the work described in an application clearly complies with all
provisions of the Zoning and other ordinances of the City. If the proposed
building or use does not clearly comply, the Safety-Service Director shall not
have the power to grant variances or make exceptions unless specifically so
empowered.
   (c)    Conditional Use Permit. Whenever a determination for a conditional
use is required, a building permit for the building or use requiring a
conditional use permit shall not be issued until such permit has been applied
for and approved by the Commission.
   (d)    Determination of Similar Use. Whenever a determination for a similar
use is required, a building permit for the building or use shall not be issued
until the inclusion of such use as a permitted use has been made by the
Commission and confirmed by Council. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 2015-
36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1161.04  WITHHOLDING PERMITS.
   (a)    Amendment Pending. No building permit shall be issued during the
period in which an amendment which would affect the building or use applied for
has been recommended by the Planning Commission or introduced by Council.
However, an application for a permit or certificate shall not be withheld for
more than ninety days after the application was officially submitted.
   (b)   Nonconforming Lot. No building permit shall be issued for a one or
two-family building unless the residential lot shall abut upon a dedicated
street; the utilities, pavement and all other required improvements have been
constructed or their construction guaranteed; and the lot be located in a duly
recorded subdivision or approved by the Commission and no plat required, or
resubdivided in accordance with the provisions of Section
1125.06 so as to conform with the requirements of this Zoning Ordinance. (Ord.
82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1161.05  REQUIRED DRAWINGS.
   In addition to drawings required by the provisions of the Building Code,
application for a building permit shall be accompanied by:
   (a)    A plat showing dimensions of the lot to be developed, lot number, a
topographic data and evidence that the lot has been surveyed and certified by a
registered surveyor or engineer;
   (b)    A site plan drawn to scale showing the location of proposed and
existing buildings, driveway and parking areas, and proposed finish grades;
also the location and use of buildings on adjoining lots within distances
specified in other sections of this Zoning Ordinance. For residential
developments the size and location of a garage shall be shown; and
   (c)    Such other drawings and information as may be required by the
provisions of Chapter
1137 for Commercial Service, General Industrial and Industrial-Truck Center
Districts, and Chapter
1139 for planned development areas.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1161.06  APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS.
   (a)    Application. Application for building permits and accompanying
drawings shall be submitted to the Safety-Service Director or his designate.
After processing the same, as to general conformance to the Building Code, he
shall submit to the Planning Commission those applications which require its
approval, and to the Board of Zoning Appeals if the application involves any
interpretation required by it.
   (b)    Approval. The Director, having received reports of approval from
Council, the Commission and the Board, as may be applicable, and finding the
drawings, specifications and all documents comply with this Zoning Ordinance
and other relevant Codes of the City, may issue, upon payment of required fees,
a building permit.
   (c)    Disapproval. If Council, the Commission, the Board or the Director do
not recommend approval of the application, they shall suggest changes in the
drawings as may be necessary to accomplish the purpose of this Ordinance. In
such instances, conferences with applicants may be held and the application
revised or resubmitted, as may be required.
(Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   (d)   Waiver of Permit Fee.  The Director of the Department of Community
Development may waive some or all of the fees for building permits associated
with a specific commercial project for the purposes of carrying out an economic
development program.  A project must meet one or more of the following criteria
in order to be qualified for such fee waiver:
      (1)   The project qualifies for a job creation tax credit from the State
of Ohio.
      (2)   The project involves the development or redevelopment of under-
utilized property into a preferred development which benefits the economic
community surrounding it.
      (3)   As a result of the project, new permanent jobs are created within
the City of Sharonville. 
(Ord. 2003-87.  Passed 12-23-03; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1161.07  CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   (a)    A certificate of occupancy shall be applied for by the owner or his
agent and shall be issued by the Safety-Service Director as a condition
precedent to the occupancy and/or use of a building and land as follows:
      (1)    Occupancy of a building erected or altered. A certificate of
occupancy shall be required before occupancy of a new building, or before
occupancy of an existing building which has been altered, moved, changed in use
or increased in off-street parking requirements. Such certificate shall only be
issued after the erection or alteration of a building, or a component thereof,
or after a required accessory use has been provided and found by inspection to
be in conformity with the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance and the Building
Code.
      (2)    Change in use of conforming building or land. A certificate of
occupancy shall be required before occupancy of a conforming building or land
where the use has been changed, provided the use is different than the prior
use, and shall be issued, when found by inspection, to be in conformity with
provisions of this Ordinance.
      (3)    Change in use of nonconforming building or land. A certificate of
occupancy shall be required whenever a nonconforming building or land is
changed, and shall not be issued until the Planning Commission has approved the
change in accordance with the provisions of Chapter
1155.
   (b)   Record of Existing Building and Land Use. Upon application by the
owner, or his agent, the Director shall inspect a building or tract of land
existing on the effective date of this Ordinance and shall issue a certificate
of occupancy therefor, certifying:
      (1)    The present use of the building or land;
      (2)    If such use conforms to all the provisions of this Ordinance; and
      (3)    If it is a lawfully existing nonconforming use. (EDITOR'S NOTE:
The effective date of Zoning Ordinance 82-61, is February 10, 1983.)
   (c)    Application for Certificate.
      (1)    Applications for a certificate of occupancy may be submitted
separately or may accompany an application for a building permit. Accurate
information shall be furnished by the owner or his agent, as to size and
location of the lot, buildings or structures occupying the lot, the dimensions
of all yards and open spaces, the use of land or building, and all such
information as may be included on a form to be furnished by the City.
      (2)    A record of all applications and certificates issued shall be kept
on file in the office of the Director and copies shall be furnished, upon
request, to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building
or land affected. (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83.)
   1161.08  ENFORCEMENT.
   The duty of administering and enforcing the provisions of this Zoning
Ordinance is hereby conferred upon the Safety-Service Director. The Director
may promulgate rules and regulations as he may determine necessary to
supplement the administration of this Ordinance. After certification by
Council, such rules of the Director shall have the same force and effect as the
other provisions of this Ordinance.
   (a)    Duties. It shall be the duty of the Director to enforce this
Ordinance. The Director shall receive applications required by this Ordinance,
and issue permits and furnish the required certificates. He shall examine
premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary
inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with. He shall
enforce all laws relating to the construction, alteration, repair, removal,
demolition, equipment, use and occupancy location of buildings and structures,
except as may be otherwise provided for. He shall, when requested by the Mayor
or Council, or when the interests of the City so require, make investigations
in connection with matters referred to in this Ordinance and render written
reports on the same. For the purpose of enforcing compliance with law, he shall
issue such notices or such orders as may be necessary.
   (b)    Inspections. Inspections shall be made by the Director or a duly
appointed assistant.
   (c)    Rules. The Director may adopt rules consistent with this Ordinance
for carrying its provisions into effect.
   (d)    Records. The Director shall keep careful and comprehensive records of
applications, permits issued, certificates issued, inspections made, reports
rendered and notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of all
papers in connection with building work so long as any part of the building or
structure to which they relate may be in existence. All such records shall be
open to public inspection, at reasonable hours, but shall not be removed from
the office of the Director.
   (e)    Cooperation of Other Officials. The Director may request and shall
receive, so far as may be necessary in the discharge of his duties, the
assistance of the Municipal Engineer in fixing grades, of the Chief of Police
in enforcing orders, of the Law Director in the prosecution of violations and
of other City officials. In addition, the Director may delegate, at his/her
discretion, the administration of this Ordinance and the building permit
process to other City officials and shall receive assistance from these
officials such as the Director of Community Development, the Zoning Enforcement
Officer and the Building Official.
      (Ord. 82-61. Passed 1-11-83; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
   1161.09  RESERVED.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section is reserved for future legislation.)

this schedule are payable upon submission of completed application for
approvals.  The application fee shall be applied to the main fee upon issuance
of approval.

within thirty days from the date of issuance of the approval or permit.  Refund
shall be at the discretion of the Building Official.  No refunds shall be
granted where the fee is $30.00 or less.

or all of the fees for approvals and/or other permits for the purposes of
carrying out an economic development program in accordance with Ord. 2003-87
and Section
1161.06(b).

accordance with the Ohio Building Code and the Residential Code of Ohio.  The
Director of Community Development may seek confirmation or verification that
the reported valuation is consistent with actual cost of improvement.
      (Ord. 2015-27.  Passed 8-11-15; Ord. 2015-36.  Passed 9-8-15.)
